§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   This codification of ordinances by and for the Village of Schiller Park
shall be designated as the New Millennium Code of the Village of Schiller Park
and may be so cited.
(Ord. 01-2301, passed 12-11-01)
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required, the
same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state law.
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation, shall apply to
ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code unless
otherwise specifically provided.
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and
section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   General rule. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, or
ordinary and usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a
peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their
technical import.
   (B)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOARD, BOARD OF TRUSTEES or VILLAGE BOARD shall be construed to mean the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park.
   CODE, THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. This municipal code as modified
by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.
   CORPORATE LIMITS; VILLAGE LIMITS. The legal boundaries of the village.
   COUNTY. Cook County, Illinois.
   FULL-TIME EMPLOYEE. An employee who is in the classified Village service,
having been appointed by the Board of Fire and Police Com- missioners to a
position in the Fire Department or in the Police Department, or an employee in
the non- classified Village service who is appointed by the Village President
to a position within the Village employ requiring at least 1,850 hours of
service annually.
(Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-14-95)
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
   OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be
equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, DEPART- MENT, or COMMISSION. An officer, office,
employee, commission, or department of this municipality unless the context
clearly requires otherwise.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to
any unincor- porated entity shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers or agents thereof.
   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before or next after, respectively.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   STATE. The State of Illinois.
   SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a heading in
the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the chapter,
setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of the heading.
Not all chapters have subchapters.
   TEMPORARY EMPLOYEE. Any employee other than a full-time employee of the
Village of Schiller Park.
(Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-14-95)
   VILLAGE, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, or MUNICIPALITY. The Village of Schiller
Park, Illinois.
   WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed, equivalent to the words
YEAR OF OUR LORD.
(Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-8-08)
§ 10.06 RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
   The construction of all ordinances of this municipality shall be by the
following rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of
the legislative body or of the context of the same ordinance:
   (A)   AND or OR. Either conjunction shall include the other as if written
“and/or,” if the sense requires it.
   (B)   Acts by assistants. When a statute or ordinance requires an act to be
done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, such
requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of such act by an authorized
agent or deputy.
   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses. Words denoting the masculine
gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall include the
singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
   (D)   General term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
   (E)   In the event of any conflict between or among the any Codes adopted by
reference in this Code of Ordinances, the more stringent provision shall apply
and control.
(Ord. 02-2312, passed 1-8-02)
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its application to
any person or circum- stance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect
other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision or
application.
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of this municipality exercising the powers,
duties, or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any
transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express such intent, such spelling shall be corrected and such word
or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall
be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of
such error.
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
   (A)   Central Standard Time shall be the official time for the transaction
of business; except from 2:00 a.m. on the last Sunday in April of each year,
the official time shall be advanced one hour to central daylight savings time,
until 2:00 a.m. of the last Sunday in October, at which time the official time
shall return to Central Standard Time.
   (B)   All clocks and other timepieces in or upon public buildings or other
premises maintained by or at the expense of the village shall be set and run at
the official time prescribed by this section.
('73 Code, § 2-6)
§ 10.12 REASONABLE TIME.
   (A)   In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in a
reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, reasonable time or
notice shall be deemed to mean the time which is necessary for a prompt
performance of such act or the giving of such notice.
   (B)   The time within which an act is to be done, as herein provided, shall
be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day
be Sunday, it shall be excluded.
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
§ 10.15 EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.
   All ordinances passed by the legislative body re- quiring publication shall
take effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise
expressly provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from
their passage and approval, unless otherwise expressly provided.
§ 10.16 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
   (A)   As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage
date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending ordinances,
if any, are listed following the text of the code section.
   (B)   If an ILCS cite is included in the history, this indicates that the
text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute. Example: (ILCS
Ch. 24, § 3-2-1) (Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85).
(Ord. 97-2060, passed 5-27-97)
§ 10.17 RESERVED.
(Ord. 97-2060, passed 5-27-97)
§ 10.18 RESERVED.
(Ord. 97-2060, passed 5-27-97)
§ 10.19 ISSUANCE OF LICENSES, CERTIFICATES AND/OR PERMITS; PAYMENT OF UNPAID
CHARGES AND ASSESSMENTS.
   Prior to the issuance of any license, certificate or permit required
pursuant to this Code, the Village Manager/Comptroller, or his duly designated
agent, shall ascertain that there are no unpaid charges for water and sewer
service, other municipal services, or any other municipal fees, fines,
judgments or levies then due and unpaid. No such license, certificate or permit
shall be approved or issued until such time as the applicant presents to the
appropriate department a certificate of the Village Manager/Comptroller, or his
duly designated agent, indicating that all charges, fees, assessments, fines,
judgments and levies owed to the Village have been paid in full.
(Ord. 04-2475, passed 7-27-04)
§ 10.20 ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION OF COSTS FOR EXTRAORDINARY COSTS FOR
EMERGENCY AND OTHER SERVICES.
   (A)   From time to time, Village departments that provide public safety,
flood control, sewer and potable water, street and sidewalk maintenance, and
health services encounter the need to hire or retain third parties in order to
provide certain emergency and other services, e.g. for plumbing work, removal
of vehicles, testing to determine life safety issues, the handling and/or
disposal of toxic substances or hazardous materials, or other services
necessitating the use of special equipment — all or some of which services may
generate the expenditure of money (herein "extraordinary costs") payable by the
Village to third parties (herein "provider") for such provider's rendering of
such emergency or other services. Whenever the Village incurs such
extraordinary costs, the Village shall be reimbursed the actual amount of such
extraordinary costs by the person (herein "recipient") receiving the benefit of
the services which generated the extraordinary costs.
      (1)   Upon receipt by the Village Manager/ Comptroller of a notification
that such extraordinary costs have been incurred by the Village, the Village
Manager/Comptroller shall cause a Village invoice to be issued to such
recipient along with a copy of the statement received from the provider of such
services.
      (2)   In the event the Village is not in receipt of payment within 30
days from the date of such invoice, the Village Manager/Comptroller is
authorized to undertake such action as provided by law as may be necessary for
the recovery of such extraordinary costs as well as the Village's attorneys'
fees and other costs associated with such recovery.
   (B)   As used herein the term "provider" shall not include any officer,
employee of the Village or family member of any officer or employee of the
Village rendering such extraordinary services.
(Ord. 05-2544, passed 11-8-05)
§ 10.21 CONFLICTS WITH CERTAIN HOME RULE ORDINANCES OF COOK COUNTY.
   (A)   For the purposes of this Section, the term EMPLOYEE means an
individual permitted and/or hired to work by an employer regardless of the
number of persons the employer employs, or the number of hours worked, and the
term EMPLOYER means any person, firm or corporation employing one or more
employees, or seeking to employ one or more employees, if the employer has its
principal place of business within the Village, or does business within the
Village. For the purposes of this Section, the term EMPLOYER does not mean:
      (1)   The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned
by the government of the United States;
      (2)   An Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe;
      (3)   The government of the state or any agency or department thereof; or
      (4)   The government of any municipality.
   (B)   Employers located within the Village shall comply with all federal and
state employment laws and guidelines with regard to paid sick leave and the
payment of minimum wage. Employee eligibility for paid sick leave and payment
of minimum wage shall be pursuant to all federal and State employment laws and
guidelines.
   (C)   No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave or payment of
minimum wage, including, without limitation, any additional obligations adopted
by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners, shall apply to employers located
within the Village, and the Village opts out of any such regulations or
requirements, except those required by federal and state law or the Village.
(Ord. 17-4006, passed 6-1-17)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this code for
which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be
subject to a fine not exceeding $ 500. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day a violation occurs or continues.
Statutory reference:
   Limitations on penalties, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 1-2-1.
   Authority to imprison for certain ordinance violations, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act
5, § 1-2-1.1.

word, “seal,” in bold letters in the center thereof and the words, “Village of
Schiller Park, Illinois” on the outer edge thereof.
('73 Code, § 2-3)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 30.001 VILLAGE ELECTIONS; INAUGURATION ; COMMENCEMENT OF TERMS
   (A)   Elections of Village officers shall be conducted in accordance with
the general election law, ILCS Ch. 10, Act 5, §§ 1-1 et seq.
   (B)   An official of the Village may be inaugurated at any time following
the proclamation of the results of the regular municipal election at which such
official was elected. Inauguration shall be accomplished by taking and
subscribing the oath or affirmation required by the Illinois Constitution. The
subscribed oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the Village
Clerk.
   (C)   Following their inauguration, the terms of elected officials of the
Village shall commence following the first regular meeting or special meeting,
whichever first occurs, of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village
in the month of May following the proclamation of the results of the regular
municipal election at which such officials were elected.
('73 Code, § 2-4) (Am. Ord. 97-2060, passed 5-27-97; Am. Ord. 05-2523, passed
5-24-05)
§ 30.002 SURETIES ON BONDS.
   (A)   Generally. When a surety bond to indemnify the Village is required as
a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the
issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of any special privilege,
the surety on the bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do
business in this state as a surety company, in the absence of specific
provision to the contrary by ordinance.
('73 Code, § 2-5)
   (B)   Additional sureties. When, in its opinion, additional sureties may be
needed on any bond to indemnify the Village against loss or liability because
of the insolvency of the existing sureties or for any other reason, the Village
may order new sureties to be secured for the bond. If these new sureties are
not procured within ten days from the time the order is transmitted to the
principal of the bond or his assignee, the Board of Trustees shall declare the
bond void and thereupon the principal or assignee shall be deemed to have
surrendered the privilege or position as a condition of which the bond was
required.
('73 Code, § 2-5)
   (C)   Amount determined by Board. Every officer and employee, if required by
the Board of Trustees upon entering upon the duties of office, shall give a
bond in the amount and with sureties as may be determined by the Board,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office or
position.
('73 Code, § 2-33)
§ 30.003 VILLAGE OFFICE HOURS.
   (A)   The offices of the Village Hall shall be open Mondays through Fridays
from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and on Saturdays from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m.
   (B)   All the offices of the Village Hall shall be closed on legal holidays
and Sundays. All times shall be official time, as provided in §
10.11.
('73 Code, § 2-7) (Ord. 65-732, passed 9-7-65; Am. Ord. 75-1142, passed 6-19-
75; Am. Ord. 75-1153, passed 9-18-75)
§ 30.004 PERSONNEL POLICY MANUAL.
   Any personnel policy manual and any amending ordinances of the Village
adopted by the President and Board of Trustees shall merely be a guide to
personnel polices of the Village.
('73 Code, 2-20) (Ord. 88-1687, passed 5-19-88; Am. Ord. 93-1856, passed 9-28-
93; Am. Ord. 15-3001, passed 2-19-15)
§ 30.005 SCOPE OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply alike to all officers and
employees of the Village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office
or the employee's position.
('73 Code, 2-21)
§ 30.006 APPOINTMENTS; TERMS; VACANCIES.
   (A)   All officers, other than elected officers, shall be appointed by the
Village President and Board of Trustees, as is provided by statute; provided,
all employees, in the absence of any provisions to the contrary, shall be
appointed by the President.
('73 Code, 2-22)
   (B)   Every appointive officer of the Village shall hold office until May 1
following his or her appointment or until a successor is appointed and
qualified, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. In case of a vacancy in any
office, it shall be filled in the same manner in which appointments are made,
in the absence of provisions to the contrary.
('73 Code, 2-23)
§ 30.007 DUTY OF OFFICERS TO MAKE MONTHLY DELIVERIES OF RECEIPTS, REPORTS AND
THE LIKE TO THE VILLAGE TREASURER.
   Every officer of the Village, at least once each month, shall turn over all
money received by him or her in his or her official capacity to the Village
Treasurer with a statement showing the source from which the same was received.
('73 Code, 2-24)
§ 30.008 OATH OF OFFICERS.
   Every officer of the Village, before entering upon his or her duties, shall
take the oath prescribed by statute.
('73 Code, 2-25)
§ 30.009 COMPENSATION.
   (A)   All officers of the Village shall receive the salary as, from time to
time, may be provided by ordinance.
('73 Code, 2-26)
   (B)   The compensation of Village employees shall be as is set, from time to
time, by the Village Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, 2-27)
§ 30.010 RESERVED.
§ 30.011 RESERVED.
§ 30.012 HOLIDAYS.
   (A)   The following named holidays are designated as days on which time off
and compensation thereof will be allowed to all regular full-time employees of
the Village except police officers, fire fighters, members of the emergency
medical services unit and seasonal or temporary employees:
      (1)   New Year's Day;
      (2)   Martin Luther King's Birthday;
      (3)   President's Day;
      (4)   Memorial Day;
      (5)   Independence Day;
      (6)   Labor Day;
      (7)   Veterans Day;
      (8)   Thanksgiving Day;
      (9)   Friday after Thanksgiving;
      (10)   Christmas Day.
   (B)   When any of the holidays listed in division (A) falls on a Saturday,
the preceding Friday will be observed as such holiday for the purposes of this
section.
   (C)   When any of the above holidays listed in division (A) above falls on a
Sunday, the following Monday will be observed as such holiday for the purposes
of this section.
('73 Code, 2-30) (Ord. 84-1533, passed 3-22-84; Am. Ord. 86-1607, passed 2-6-

§ 30.013 INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   All records kept by any officer of the Village shall be open to inspection
by the Village President or any member of the Board of Trustees at all
reasonable times, whether or not the records are required to be kept by statute
or ordinance.
('73 Code, 2-31)
§ 30.014 SURRENDERING OF VILLAGE PROPERTY UPON TERMINATION.
   Every officer and employee of the Village, upon the expiration of his or her
term for any cause, shall deliver to his or her successor all books and records
which may be the property of the Village and, if no successor has been
appointed within one week after the termination of office, the property shall
be delivered to the Village Clerk or Village Treasurer.
('73 Code, § 2-34)
§ 30.015 IMPERSONATION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate any Village officer or
employee.
('73 Code, § 2-35)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 30.016 INTERFERENCE.
   It shall be unlawful to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of
the Village while engaged in the duties of his or her office or employment.
('73 Code, § 2-36)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 30.017 ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES FOR COMPLIANCE WITH THE FAIR LABOR STANDARDS
ACT.
   (A)   Non-covered employees. The following employees of the Village hereby
are declared to be non-covered employees for purposes of the Fair Labor
Standards Act:
      (1)   Village Clerk.
      (2)   Deputy Village Clerk.
      (3)   Administrative Assistant to the Village President.
   (B)   Exempt employees. For purposes of the Fair Labor Standards Act, the
following employees of the Village are declared hereby to be exempt employees,
in that they are executive, administrative, professional, and/or temporary
employees working for the Recreation Department:
      (1)   Manager/Comptroller.
      (2)   Treasurer.
      (3)   Finance Officer.
      (4)   Director of Streets, Sanitation, and Water.
      (5)   Chief of Police.
      (6)   Police Captain.
      (7)   Police Lieutenant.
      (8)   Police Sergeant.
      (9)   Fire Chief.
      (10)   Firefighters working additional hours while assigned to the Chief
Inspector [of the Bureau of Fire Prevention] as the Building Official/
Administrator.
      (11)   Fire Lieutenant.
      (12)   Chief Inspector of the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
      (13)   Director of Emergency Medical Services.
      (14)   Assistant to the Village Manager/ Comptroller.
      (15)   Director of Parks and Recreation.
      (16)   Director of Community Development.
('73 Code, § 2-37) (Ord. 74-1109, passed 9-19-74; Am. Ord. 75-1145, passed 7-
17-75; Am. Ord. 85-1593, passed 10-10-85; Am. Ord. 88-1682, passed 3-24-88; Am.

§ 30.019 RESERVED.
§ 30.020 COMPENSATION WHILE ON RESERVE MILITARY DUTIES.
   In the event a full-time employee of the Village is absent from work because
the employee is required to engage in reserve military duties for the United
States government, the employee shall be compensated at his or her regular rate
of pay for the period of absence, less any compensation received during the
period of service to the United States government.
('73 Code, § 2-40) (Ord. 79-1349, passed 6-7-79)
§ 30.021 COMPENSATION WHILE ON JURY DUTY.
   In the event a full-time employee of the Village is absent from work because
the employee is required to act as a juror for the United States, the state or
the county, the employee shall be compensated at his or her regular rate of pay
for the period of absence, less any compensation received for acting as a
juror.
('73 Code, § 2-41) (Ord. 79-1349, passed 6-7-79)
§ 30.022 RESERVED.
§ 30.023 RESERVED
§ 30.024 STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT ADOPTED.
   (A)   The regulations of Sections 5-15 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 5-15) and
Article 10 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 10-10 through 10-40) of the State Officials
and Employees Ethics Act, ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as “Act” in this Section), are hereby adopted by reference and made
applicable to the officers and employees of the Village to the extent required
by ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5.
   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or
accepted under the Act, by any officer or any employee of the Village, is
hereby prohibited.
   (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an
officer or employee of the Village under the Act, is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by
any officer or employee of the Village, is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   For purposes of this Section, the terms “officer” and “employee” shall
be defined as set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(c).
   (F)   The penalties for violations of this Section shall be the same as
those penalties set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 50-5 for similar violations
of the Act.
   (G)   This Section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of Village officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less
restrictive than this Section, however, the provisions of this Section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(a).
   (H)   Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this Section shall be incorporated into this Section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be
incorporated into this Section by reference without formal action by the
Corporate Authorities of the Village.
   (I)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this Section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
Supreme Court’s decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This Section shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the Corporate Authorities of the Village if the Act is found unconstitutional
by the Illinois Supreme Court.
   (J)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the Act,
or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the Act as
adopted by this Section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this Section relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by the Corporate Authorities of
the Village.
(Ord. 04-2465, passed 5-11-04)
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
§ 30.030 ELECTION; TERM.
   The Village President shall be elected for a term of four years and shall be
the President of the Board of Trustees, as is provided by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-43)
§ 30.031 DUTIES; GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Village President shall be the chief executive officer of the
Village and shall perform all duties that may be required by statute or
ordinance.
('73 Code, § 2-44)
   (B)   The President shall have supervision over all executive and appointive
officers of the Village and shall have the power and the authority to inspect
all books and records kept by any Village officer or employee at any reasonable
time.
('73 Code, § 2-44)
   (C)   When there is a question as to the respective duties or powers of any
appointed officer of the Village, it shall be decided by the President, and the
President shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which
is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform that
duty.
('73 Code, § 2-45)
§ 30.032 BOND; OATH.
   (A)   Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village President shall
give a bond with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of his or her duties, in the sum of at least
$3,000 or a higher sum as may be directed by the Board.
   (B)   The President shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-46)
§ 30.033 COMPENSATION.
   The Village President shall receive a salary of $21,450 per year, payable in
12 equal monthly installments.
('73 Code, § 2-47) (Ord. 68-864, passed 10-7-68; Am. Ord. 81-1435, passed 4-2-
81; Am. Ord. 84-1540, passed 7-19-84; Am. Ord. 90-1761, passed 12-6-90; Am.
Ord. 04-2476, passed 7-27-04)
§ 30.034 PRESIDENT PRO TEM.
   During a temporary absence or disability of the Village President, the Board
of Trustees shall elect one of its number to act as President Pro Tem, who,
during the absence or disability of the President, shall perform the duties
pertaining to that office.
('73 Code, § 2-48)
§ 30.035 EMERGENCY POWERS.
   (A)   In accord with the statutes of the state, made and provided, the
corporate authorities of the Village hereby grant to the Village President the
extraordinary power and authority, by executive order, during a state of
emergency, such of the powers normally reserved to the corporate authorities as
may be reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency.
   (B)   The Village President shall not exercise such extraordinary power and
authority except after his signing a statement, under oath, that a state of
emergency exists. Such sworn statement shall set forth facts substantiating
such findings, describing the nature of the emergency and declaring that a
state of emergency exists and shall be based upon the following standards for
determination. The existence of:
      (1)   A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual
force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power
to exercise same by three or more persons acting together without authority of
law; and/or
      (2)   Any natural disaster or man-made calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion resulting in the death
or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such extent that the
extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety, and
welfare.
   (C)   Such statement shall be in the form of a sworn proclamation and
following its signing shall be filed with the Village Clerk as soon as
practicable.
   (D)   Unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the Village President
indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists, the Village President's
emergency proclamation shall terminate at the end of 48 hours or the next
regular meeting of the President and Board of Trustees, whichever first occurs.
The Village President shall have the power by sworn proclamation to reinstate
his statement of the existence of a civil emergency upon the expiration of the
original sworn proclamation.
   (E)   Upon the issuance of the original sworn proclamation authorized in
division (D) above, the Chief of Police shall notify the news media situated
within the Village and shall cause three copies of the proclamation declaring
the existence of the emergency to be posted at the municipal building, the post
office, and the fire department headquarters.
   (F)   After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the Village President
may, in the interest of public safety and welfare:
      (1)   Order the closing of all retail alcoholic liquor stores, including
taverns and private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of
intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted.
      (2)   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer.
      (3)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, or giving away
of any gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any
container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle.
      (4)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or
giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever.
      (5)   Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the
protection of life and property.
(Ord. 93-1835, passed 6-22-93)
VILLAGE CLERK
§ 30.040 ELECTION; TERM.
   The Village Clerk shall be elected and shall serve a four-year term until a
successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-56)
§ 30.041 BOND.
   Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village Clerk shall execute a
bond in the amount provided by statute, conditioned upon the faithful
performance of duties.
('73 Code, § 2-57)
§ 30.042 COMPENSATION.
   The Village Clerk shall receive a salary of $14,650 per year, payable in 12
equal monthly installments.
('73 Code, § 2-58) (Ord. 68-864, passed 10-7-68; Am. Ord. 81-1435, passed 4-2-
81; Am. Ord. 84-1540, passed 7-19-84; Am. Ord. 90-1761, passed 12-6-90; Am.
Ord. 04-2476, passed 7-27-04)
§ 30.043 DUTIES, GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Village Clerk shall perform the duties and functions required by
statute, unless modified by ordinance or other direction of the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village.
   (B)   The Village Clerk shall maintain and keep current the official zoning
map of this Village. In addition the Village Clerk shall receive and review all
petitions for zoning consideration. Upon receipt of such applications, the
Village Clerk shall forward all such applications to the respective officer,
board, or commission for action.
   (C)   Annually, within 30 days of receipt of the Annual Account of the
Village Treasurer, the Village Clerk shall not publish the account of the
Village Treasurer pursuant to the statutes of the state made and provided, but
instead shall publish a notice in a newspaper having general circulation within
the corporate limits of the Village stating that the account of the Treasurer
is available for inspection in the office of the Village Clerk during regular
business hours; however, the Village Clerk shall file a copy of the complete
Annual Account of the Village Treasurer with the County Collector of Taxes
together with an affidavit of the Village Clerk stating that such copy is a
true and correct copy of such Annual Account filed with him.
('73 Code, § 2-59) (Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 94-1894, passed 11-
9-94; Am. Ord. 95-1920, passed 4-25-95)
§ 30.044 SIGNATURES.
   The Village Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the Village and all
licenses, permits and other documents as shall require this formality.
('73 Code, § 2-60)
§ 30.045 MONEY RECEIVED.
   The Village Clerk shall turn over all money received by him or her on behalf
of the Village to the Village Collector promptly upon receipt of it, and with
that money he or she shall give a statement as to the source thereof.
('73 Code, § 2-61)
§ 30.046 ACCOUNTS.
   The Village Clerk shall keep accounts showing money received, and the source
and disposition thereof and the other accounts as may be required by statute or
ordinance.
('73 Code, § 2-62)
§ 30.047 RECORDS.
   In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the Village
Clerk is required by statute to keep, the clerk shall keep a record showing all
of the officers and regular employees of the Village and other records as may
be required by the Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 2-63)
§ 30.048 SEAL.
   The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of the Village seal and shall affix
its impression on documents when required.
('73 Code, § 2-64)
§ 30.049 DOCUMENTS.
   The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the
Village which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer.
('73 Code, § 2-65)
§ 30.050 INDICES.
   The Village Clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents
and records kept by the office of the clerk, so ready access thereto and use
thereof may be had.
('73 Code, § 2-66)
§ 30.051 VACANCIES.
   In case the office of Village Clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the
Village President and Board of Trustees shall appoint a successor, as provided
by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-67)
§ 30.052 DEPUTY CLERK.
   (A)   Created. There hereby is created the office of Deputy Clerk. The
Village Clerk is authorized to appoint a Deputy Clerk with the advice and
consent of the President and Board of Trustees, which Deputy Clerk shall have
the power and duty to execute all documents required by law or ordinance to be
executed by the Village Clerk and affix the seal of the Village thereto,
whenever required.
   (B)   Manner of signature. When signing any document, the Deputy Clerk shall
sign the name of the Village Clerk, followed by the word “by” and the Deputy
Clerk's own name and the words “Deputy Clerk.”
   (C)   Powers and duties. The powers and duties described in this subchapter
for the Clerk shall be exercised by the Deputy Clerk only in the absence of the
Village Clerk from his or her office in the Village Hall, and only when either
written direction has been given by the Village Clerk to exercise that power or
the Board of Trustees has determined by resolution that the Village Clerk
temporarily or permanently is incapacitated to perform the function. The Deputy
Clerk shall have the authority and powers herein described and the further
power and authority as may be provided by statute.
   (D)   Compensation. The Deputy Clerk shall receive compensation in the
amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees shall fix from time to
time in the annual budget.
('73 Code, § 2-68) (Ord. 72-1010, passed 7-6-72; Am. Ord. 1292, passed 5-4-78;
Am. Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-14-95)
CORPORATION COUNSEL
§ 30.060 OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT.
   There hereby is created the office of the Corporation Counsel, an executive
office of the Village, which shall include the Office of Village Attorney. The
Corporation Counsel shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice
and consent of the President and Board of Trustees and shall enjoy all of the
emoluments of the office whether appointed and holding office as an independent
contractor or as an employee. During his term, the Corporation Counsel shall
receive such compensation as may be fixed by contract from time to time. He
shall have direct communication with the Village Board and its members
individually as well as with other Village officials. The Corporation Counsel
may be removed from office by the President with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 2-76) (Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 15-3020, passed 10-
15-15; Am. Ord. 19-4171, passed 8-1-19)
§ 30.061 DUTIES.
   The Corporation Counsel shall be responsible for legal matters pertaining to
the Village. Upon request by the Village President or Board of Trustees, he
shall render any given legal opinion in writing. If Corporation Counsel is
required to retain Special Counsel to represent or advise the Village, any such
engagement of Special Counsel must be approved by the Board of Trustees prior
to representation. Examples of the duties of the Corporation Counsel follow:
   (A)   The Corporation Counsel shall prosecute or cause to be prosecuted any
violation of any of the provisions of this code or any other ordinance of the
Village, including complaints of zoning and housing violations and shall advise
and assist all Village officers or employees on questions of law involved in
filing complaints, and preparing for prosecutions. He shall prosecute or
defend, as the case may be, administrative law actions and any and all suits or
actions at law or in equity to which the Village may be a party, or in which it
may be interested — including those brought against or by any officer of the
Village in the capacity of such person as an officer or on behalf of the
Village.
   (B)   The Corporation Counsel shall be the legal advisor to the Boards and
Commissions of the Village, and render opinions on Village bond issues.
('73 Code, § 2-78) (Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 15-3020, passed 10-
15-15; Am. Ord. 19-4171, passed 8-1-19)
VILLAGE TREASURER
§ 30.070 OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   There hereby is created the office of Village Treasurer, who shall be
appointed by the Village President by and with the consent of the Board of
Trustees. The Treasurer shall serve for one year.
('73 Code, § 2-86)
§ 30.071 BOND.
   The Village Treasurer shall give a bond before entering upon the duties of
office, in the sum required by the Board of Trustees, but the amount shall not
be less than that required by statute. This bond shall be conditioned upon the
faithful performance of duties by the Treasurer and shall be conditioned to
indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act
of the Treasurer.
('73 Code, § 2-87)
§ 30.072 DUTIES, GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Treasurer shall perform the duties that are prescribed by statute
or ordinance, except that the Treasurer shall not publish nor file his annual
report pursuant to the statutes of the state made and provided, but instead
shall file his report with the Village Clerk, who shall make copies thereof
available to the President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
   (B)   The Treasurer shall receive all money paid into the Village, whether
directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of another officer
or employee as may receive it, and shall pay out money only on voucher or
orders properly signed by the Village President and Village Clerk.
('73 Code, § 2-88) (Am. Ord. 95-1920, passed 4-25-95)
§ 30.073 DEPOSITS OF FUNDS; LIMITATIONS.
   The Village Treasurer shall deposit the Village funds in the depositories
as, from time to time, may be selected as provided by law. The Treasurer shall
keep the deposit of the Village money separate and distinct from the treasurers
own money and shall not make private or personal use of any Village money.
('73 Code, § 2-89)
§ 30.074 RECORDS.
   The Village Treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him
or her, showing the source from which it is paid and the purpose for which it
is paid and shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the
Village.
('73 Code, § 2-90)
§ 30.075 ACCOUNTING.
   The Treasurer shall keep books and accounts as may required by statute or
ordinance and shall keep them the manner required by the Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 2-91)
§ 30.076 HANDLING OF SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUNDS.
   All money received on any special assessment shall be held by the Treasurer
as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the improvement, or
bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with the interest thereon, for
which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no other
purpose, unless to reimburse the Village for money expended for improvement.
Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the statutes and
the law and the Treasurer shall keep his or her books and accounts in a manner
so proper prorations in payments of principal and interest can be made and
ascertained.
('73 Code, § 2-92)
§ 30.077 TRANSFER OF FUNDS, DRAWING OF WARRANTS.
   (A)   All warrants drawn on the Treasurer must be signed by the Village
President and countersigned by the Village Clerk, stating the particular fund
or appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom
payable. No money shall be other- wise paid except as may be provided by
statute.
   (B)   Money shall not be transferred by the Treasurer from one fund to
another, after it has been received by him or her, nor appropriated to any
other purpose than that for which it has been collected or paid, except as may
be ordered by the Village President and Board of Trustees in a manner and form
prescribed by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-93)
§ 30.078 COMPENSATION.
   The Village Treasurer shall receive compensation in such amount and manner
as the Village President and Board of Trustees shall fix, from time to time, by
ordinance or resolution.
('73 Code, § 2-94) (Ord. 72-1011, passed 7-6-72; Am. Ord. 78-1294, passed 5-4-
78)
VILLAGE COLLECTOR
§ 30.080 OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT.
   (A)   There is established hereby the office of Village Collector, an
executive office of the Village. The Village Collector shall be appointed for
an indefinite term by the Village President by and with the consent of the
Board of Trustees and shall receive such annual salary as is approved by the
President and Board of Trustees in the annual budget.
   (B)   The Village Clerk may hold the office of Village Collector, if so
appointed as set forth in subsection (A) of this section.
(Ord. 04-2456, passed 4-13-04)
§ 30.081 DUTIES OF THE VILLAGE COLLECTOR.
   The Village Collector shall have the following duties:
   (A)   As may be required by the Village Manager/Comptroller, the Village
Collector shall collect and receive money due the Village and keep such records
pertaining to such collections;
   (B)   At the end of each day, the Village Collector shall turn over to the
Village Treasurer all monies collected from any source; and
   (C)   The Village Collector shall make the following reports:
      (1)   Monthly, to the Village Manager/Comptroller, demonstrating what
money has been received by the Collector and the source thereof;
      (2)   Between the first and tenth of April of each fiscal year, file with
the Village Clerk, an annual statement of: (i) All money collected by the
Village Collector during the previous twelve months, (ii) the particular
warrant, special assessment, or other account on which collected; (iii) the
balance uncollected on all warrants in the Village Collector’s possession; and
(iv) the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all
warrants that the Village Collector returned to the Village Treasurer during
the preceding fiscal year.
(Ord. 04-2456, passed 4-13-04)
§ 30.082 AUTOMATIC REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.
   The Village Collector is prohibited hereby from keeping the money of the
Village in the possession of the Village Collector or in the possession of any
other person, firm or corporation beyond the time prescribed for payment of
same to the Village Treasurer. Failure of the Village Collector to abide by
this regulation shall constitute immediate and unequivocal surrender of office
as Village Collector.
(Ord. 04-2456, passed 4-13-04)
§ 30.083 EXAMINATION/AUDIT.
   (A)   All of the books, vouchers and papers required to be maintained by, or
pertaining to the office of, the Village Collector may be examined at any time
by the Village President, Village Clerk, Village Manager/Comptroller or a
committee of the President and Board of Trustees.
   (B)   The office of the Village Collector shall be included in the annual
audit of the Village Treasurer.
(Ord. 04-2456, passed 4-13-04)
VILLAGE COMPTROLLER/ VILLAGE MANAGER
§ 30.090 OFFICE ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There hereby is created the office of Village Comptroller, an
administrative office of the Village.
   (B)   There hereby is created the office of Village Manager, an
administrative office of the Village.
   (C)   Both of these offices, with their functions, duties and
responsibilities, shall be combined and held by one person, to be known as the
Village Manager/Comptroller.
   (D)   Throughout this code of ordinances whenever reference is made to
“Village Comptroller/ Manager”, “Village Manager”, “Village Manager/
Comptroller”, and/or “Village Comptroller”, such term shall be construed to
mean “Village Manager/ Comptroller”.
('73 Code, § 2-101) (Ord. No. 01-2301, passed 12-11-01)
§ 30.091 APPOINTMENT; COMPTROLLER PRO TEM.
   (A)   The Village Comptroller shall be appointed by the Village President,
by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees.
      (1)   The nominee for Village Comptroller shall be considered by the
Board of Trustees solely on the basis of executive and administrative
qualifications, with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of
accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office hereinafter set forth
and the requirements and qualifications hereby are desired to be of a nature as
to require technical training or knowledge.
      (2)   No Trustee or the President shall receive such appointment during
the term for which he or she shall have been elected, nor within one year after
the expiration of his or her term.
   (B)   During the absence or disability of the Village Comptroller/Manager,
the President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may
designate some properly qualified person to act as Comptroller/Manager pro
tempore to perform the duties of the office.
('73 Code, § 2-102)
§ 30.092 TERM.
   The Village Comptroller/Manager shall be appointed annually by the Village
President, by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees, at the first
meeting of each fiscal year or when a vacancy shall exist in the office.
('73 Code, § 2-103) (Ord. 84-1536, passed 5-17-84)
§ 30.093 BOND; OATH.
   (A)   Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village Comptroller/
Manager shall furnish a surety bond to be approved by the Village President and
Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of
his or her duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the Village.
   (B)   Before entering upon the duties of office, the Comptroller/Manager
shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by statutes.
('73 Code, § 2-104)
§ 30.094 COMPENSATION.
   The Village Comptroller/Manager shall receive compensation in the amount and
manner as the Village President and Board of Trustees shall fix from time to
time in the annual budget.
('73 Code, § 2-105) (Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-14-95)
§ 30.095 POWERS AND DUTIES AS FISCAL AGENT.
   (A)   The Village Manager/Comptroller shall be the fiscal agent of the
Village and as such shall be charged with and shall exercise general
supervision over, and establish procedures for, all officers of the Village
charged in any manner with the receipt, collection or disbursement of the
Village revenues and/or funds, including funds required to be in the custody of
the Village Treasurer.
   (B)   The Comptroller/Manager shall have custody and control of all
documents, including debts, mortgages, leases, contracts, judgement orders,
notes, bonds and evidence of indebtedness belonging to the Village except such
as are directed by law or ordinance to be deposited elsewhere. He or she shall
have supervision of the issuance and sale of all bonds, warrants and
obligations and shall have supervision over the accounting work of the Village.
   (C)   Specifically, but not in limitation of the above, he or she shall have
the following powers and duties:
      (1)   Before the annual budget ordinance is prepared by the corporate
authorities, he or she shall submit to the corporate authorities a report of
the estimate of the money necessary to defray the expenses of the Village
during the next fiscal year and in that report shall classify and detail the
purposes of expenditure, the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, the
Village liabilities and other information as is necessary to assist the Village
President and Board of Trustees to adopt an annual budget.
      (2)   For the purpose of preparing the aforesaid estimate, he or she is
authorized to require all officers to submit statements of the condition and
expenses of their respective offices or departments, a description of proposed
Village improvements and the probable expense thereof, a description of all
unperformed contracts and a statement of the amount of all unexpired
appropriations of the preceding year.
      (3)   He or she shall recommend to the President and Board the salaries
to be paid each appointive subordinate employee of the Village.
      (4)   With the approval of the President and Board, may consolidate,
combine, reorganize or unite positions under his or her jurisdiction.
      (5)   He or she shall purchase all materials, supplies or equipment
subject to and pursuant to directives and appropriations made and provided by
the President and Board and subject also to the statutes of the state
pertaining to creation of liabilities against the Village and pertaining to the
expenditures or appropriations of the money of the Village.
      (6)   Each month, he or she shall cause to be prepared and shall present
to the President and Board a statement showing the exact financial condition of
the end of the preceding month.
      (7)   He or she shall give additional reports and information concerning
the fiscal matters of the Village as, from time to time, may be required by the
President and Board.
      (8)   He or she shall perform the duties and have the powers as are fixed
and conferred upon him from time to time by the President and Board.
      (9)   He shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ILCS Ch.
65, Act 5, or as may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the
President and Board of Trustees, including but not limited to the conveying of
a license, that is, an incorporeal hereditament or a nonpossessory interest in
land, to any person, firm, or corporation for the construction, installation,
and/or maintenance upon or over public land owned or controlled by the Village
by such person, firm, or corporation of awnings, automatic lawn sprinkling
systems, private roadway improvements, and roadway entrance markers or other
public, charitable, or aesthetic insignia.
         (a)   The license shall not be granted or conveyed, however, until:
            1.   The grantee shall have presented to the Village specific
drawings, plans, and specifications for the improvement to be erected and
constructed upon the public lands involved.
            2.   The grantee and the Village Comptroller/Manager shall sign an
agreement approved by the Corporation Counsel, which agreement shall include
but not be limited to provisions: whereby the grantee shall hold harmless the
Village, its agents, employees, and representatives from any causes of action
arising out of such construction, installation, and/or maintenance of such
improvement in, upon, or over the said public property; whereby the grantee
shall pay for an insurance policy naming the Village as an insured party, and
providing coverage for liability (including defense of actions) arising out of
incidents resulting from the issuance of such license; and whereby the grantee
shall reimburse the Village for its engineering, legal, and inspectional costs
encountered by its issuance of such license.
         (b)   The document containing the license shall set forth the legal
description of the land, shall clearly indicate that the grantee will have no
possessory interest or estate in the land so described, and shall terminate at
the pleasure of the Village.
         (c)   Both the license and the hold harmless agreement above-described
shall be filed with the Village Clerk within 10 days after their execution,
whereupon the Director of Bureau of Fire Prevention of the Village shall have
the power and authority to issue a building permit pursuant to the terms of
said license.
('73 Code, § 2-106) (Ord. 93-1854, passed 9-28-93; Am. Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-
14-95; Am. Ord. 04-2456, passed 4-13-04)
§ 30.096 VILLAGE MANAGEMENT.
   (A)   In addition to the duties listed in §
30.095, the Village Comptroller/Manager shall perform the other duties that are
herein provided:
      (1)   The Comptroller/Manager shall be the chief administrative officer
of the Village and shall be responsible to the Village President and to the
Board of Trustees for the management and operation of all of the affairs and
the departments of the Village. As that administrative officer, he or she shall
have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to the
operation and maintenance of the properties of the Village and of all of the
departments of the Village.
      (2)   He or she also shall have supervision of other administrative
agencies and departments and officers as may be hereafter created by the
President and Board, unless the management and control of those departments and
officers is expressly delegated elsewhere.
   (B)   Specifically, but not in limitation of the division (A) above, the
Comptroller/Manager shall have the following additional powers and duties:
      (1)   He or she may recommend to the President and Board the appointment
of all officers of the Village who are required by law to be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board, and he may recommend to the
President the appointment of employees and officers who are required to be
appointed by the President. He or she further shall recommend the removal or
suspension of any such officer or employee when removal or suspension shall be
consistent with the best interests of the Village. All recommendations for
appointment or removal shall be based upon merit and upon the qualifications or
disqualifications of the officer or employee without regard to political belief
or affiliation.
      (2)   He or she shall supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies,
and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget, and for that purpose
he is authorized to make expenditures in accordance with the purchasing policy
of the Village, as from time to time supplemented or amended by the President
and Board; receive bids for purchases or contracts for any purpose, including
but not limited to those affecting the operation and maintenance of Village
services; and advise the President and Board of Trustees on the advantages or
disadvantages of the contract or merchandise on which such bids have been
received; with the understanding that all expenditures and payments, regardless
of amount, shall be subject to the confirmation or approval of the President
and Board of Trustees and to the limitations imposed by adoption of the budget.
      (3)   He or she shall attend all meetings of the President and Board
unless excused therefrom by the President and Board, except when his or her
removal is under consideration by the Board. He or she shall have the privilege
of taking part in the discussion of all matters coming before the Board and
shall be entitled to notice of all meetings, regular and special, of the Board.
      (4)   He or she shall make investigations into the affairs of the Village
or any department or division thereof and shall investigate all complaints in
relation to matters concerning Village services and Village administration.
      (5)   He or she shall devote his or her entire time to the discharge of
official duties.
      (6)   He or she shall perform the other duties as may be required of him
or her by the President and Board consistent with the Village ordinances or
state statutes.
      (7)   In the absence or vacancy in office of the Village Comptroller/
Manager, wherever in this code of ordinances or in the ordinances adopted by
the President and Board of trustees reference is made to the Village
Comptroller/Manager, Village Manager or Village Comptroller, the duties of such
Village Comptroller/Manager, Village Manager, or Village Comptroller shall be
undertaken by the Village President during the period of such absence or
vacancy.
('73 Code, § 2-107) (Ord. 93-1861, passed 12-14-93; Ord. 93-1854, passed 9-28-
93; Ord. 23-4368, passed 7-6-23)
DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
§ 30.105 DEPARTMENT CREATED.
   (A)   There is established hereby a Department of Community Development to
further and to implement the continued growth of the Village into a well-
balanced community, providing for its residential, commercial, and industrial
inhabitants the orderly development for all phases of suburban living by:
      (1)   Continued encouragement of con- struction of high quality
residences;
      (2)   Continued development of office, commercial, and industrial
facilities;
      (3)   Reappraisal of the needs of industrial and commercial areas and
assistance in fulfillment of those needs;
      (4)   Providing for the efficient allocation and arrangement of land uses
and the gradual correction of deficiencies;
      (5)   Guiding physical and economic development toward achieving accepted
community objectives;
      (6)   Guiding of investors and developers to build within the Village's
development objectives, and provide a base for development and zoning;
      (7)   Promoting the general enhancement of the community through
beautification efforts and projects designed to instill community spirit and
pride;
      (8)   Monitoring of the various activities of the Village boards,
commissions, and departments charged with improving the quality of life in
Schiller Park and assisting them in achieving their objectives.
   (B)   The Department of Community Develop- ment has furthermore been
established:
      (1)   To recommend changes, from time to time, in the official
comprehensive plan;
      (2)   To prepare and recommend plans for specific improvements in
pursuance of the official Comprehensive Plan;
      (3)   To aid municipal officials charged with the direction of projects
for improvements embraced within the official Comprehensive Plan, to further
the making of these projects, and generally to promote the realization of the
official comprehensive plan;
      (4)   To oversee the Building Department, including all inspectors other
than those attached to the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
(Ord. 95-1931, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02)
§ 30.106 DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT.
   The head of the Department of Community Development shall be known as the
Director of Community Development and shall be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the President and Board of Trustees.
The Director of Community Development shall serve at the discretion of the
Village President. The Department of Community Development shall be composed of
such other employees as may be necessary to carry out the functions of the
Department pursuant to financing authorized by the President and Board of
Trustees in the annual budget of the Village.
(Ord. 95-1931, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 17-4030, passed 11-2-17)
§ 30.107 DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the Director:
   (A)   To analyze the economic, commercial, and residential needs relative to
development within the corporate limits of the Village;
   (B)   To oversee and enforce the building and zoning ordinances and
undertake land planning activities of the Village and to coordinate all
development authorized by the corporate authorities of the Village;
   (C)   To act as Economic Development Commis- sioner and maintain familiarity
with the needs and desires of private industry within the Village and project
future demands upon Village services, and to that end:
      (1)   Perform duties related to planning and overseeing private
development and public financing through development methods such as enterprise
zones, free trade zones, and tax-incentive programs;
      (2)   Be knowledgeable of available property for development and provide
promotional information for its subsequent development;
      (3)   Structure economic development programs, and prepare and
periodically revise short and long range plans for the economic development of
the Village;
      (4)   Enlist the aid of volunteers and groups of interested individuals
or organizations for purposes of furthering the objectives of economic
development within the Village;
   (D)   To act as executive secretary to the Zoning, Planning and Appeals
Commission and/or any other board and/or commission charged with the responsi-
bility of zoning, planning, and development activities;
   (E)   To serve as liaison between the Village and the Chamber of Commerce
and other service organizations in order to maintain contacts with the
commercial and industrial communities;
   (F)   With the approval of the Village President and Board of Trustees of
the Village, to arrange and conduct publicity relative to the activities of
Community Development;
   (G)   To undertake such surveys and other informational activities to
promote and establish historical and prospective trend information on
development characteristics;
   (H)   To recommend commercial restoration, redevelopment, and other
community development programs;
   (J)   To propose and implement programs for the distribution of information
and education of the general public on community development projects and
programs;
   (K)   To promote the tourism industry of Schiller Park;
   (L)   To recommend beautification projects and clean-up activities to
enhance the general appearance of the Village; and
   (M)   To cooperate with the Building Inspector to insure that all new
construction and remodeling is in accord with the Village zoning ordinance and
comprehensive plan.
(Ord. 95-1931, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-
2355, passed 8-13-02; Am. Ord. 06-2555, passed 1-24-06)
§ 30.108 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DEPARTMENT. The Department of Com- munity Development of the Village of
Schiller Park.
   DIRECTOR. The Director of the Department of Community Development of the
Village of Schiller Park.
   ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSIONER. The Director of the Department of
Community Development of the Village of Schiller Park.
   PRESIDENT. The President of the Village of Schiller Park.
   PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park.
   ZONING, PLANNING, AND APPEALS COMMISSION. The Zoning, Planning, and Appeals
Commission of the Village of Schiller Park.
(Ord. 95-1931, passed 5-23-95)
PLUMBING INSPECTOR
§ 30.140 OFFICE ESTABLISHED.
   There hereby is created the position of Plumbing Inspector, who shall be
appointed by the Village President, with the consent of the Village Board of
Trustees.
('73 Code, § 26-43)
§ 30.141 POWERS.
   The Plumbing Inspector shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to
enter any building in the discharge of his or her official duties or for the
purpose of making an inspection or test of the plumbing equipment therein. He
or she shall have the authority to enforce all the ordinance provisions
relating to plumbing, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and all drainage
facilities within the Village.
('73 Code, § 26-44)
§ 30.142 INSPECTIONS.
   The Plumbing Inspector shall make all inspections necessary to see to the
enforcement of the Village ordinances, and no pipe, water main, sanitary sewer
or storm sewer shall be covered until inspected and approved.
('73 Code, § 26-45)
§ 30.143 REPORT TO THE BUILDING OFFICIAL.
   The position of Plumbing Inspector shall be part of the Building Division of
the Department of Community Development. The Plumbing Inspector shall have all
of the powers and duties of any other employee of the Building Division,
including but not limited to the power to issue stop work orders.
(Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02)
ADVISOR TO THE MAYOR ON AIRPORT NOISE
§ 30.190 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is hereby created the position of Advisor to the Mayor on
Airport Noise to be filled upon the appointment of the Mayor for an indefinite
period of time. The duties and responsibilities involved with this position
shall include attendance at all Suburban O'Hare Commission meetings and
meetings of other organizations whose purpose includes reductions of airport
noise and/or bettering of the environment, and undertaking such other duties
and responsibilities as may be assigned from time to time by the Mayor.
   (B)   The Advisor to the Mayor on Airport Noise shall receive compensation
in the amount of $2,500 per year.
(Ord. 93-1832, passed 6-8-93)
DIRECTOR OF STREETS, SANITATION, AND WATER
§ 30.200 OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the Office of Director of Streets, Sanitation, and
Water which shall oversee and direct the Bureau of Streets, Sanitation, and
Water, which is also created hereby and which shall include the Street and
Highway Department and the Water and Sewer Department. The Director of the
Bureau of Streets, Sanitation, and Water shall be appointed by the President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93)
§ 30.201 DUTIES.
   In addition to his oversight and supervision of the Street and Highway
Department and the Water and Sewer Department:
   (A)   The Director of the Bureau of Streets, Sanitation, and Water shall
enforce all federal, state, and local laws, statutes, ordinances, rules, and
regulations pertaining to safety of Village personnel, including but not
limited to installation and maintenance of equipment, enforcement of safety
procedures, investigation of accidents involving public employees and equipment
and shall keep accurate records regarding all such matters.
   (B)   The Director of the Bureau of Streets, Sanitation, and Water shall
supervise the construction and maintenance of all streets, alleys, lanes,
sidewalks and highways within the Village.
   (C)   The Director of the Bureau of Streets, Sanitation, and Water shall
have direct input to the Zoning, Planning, and Appeals Commission in connection
with its review of proposed plats of subdivision; and the Director shall assist
and advise the Commission with respect to existing Village utilities,
thoroughfares, and the need for easements and the dedication of additional
rights-of-way or portions thereof, if any.
(Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95)

   See Garbage; Trash; and Refuse,
