   See Water,
Ch. 53
BUILDING DIVISION
§ 30.225 DIVISION ESTABLISHED.
   There is created hereby a division of the Department of Community
Development of the Village, namely: the Building Division. It shall consist of
the Building Official, who shall serve as the administrator of the Building
Division and shall be composed of such other officials, assistants and
employees, including inspectors and clerks, to carry out the functions of the
Department as may be authorized and assigned to it by the Village President.
   All of such assistants and employees, including inspectors other than those
attached to the Bureau of Fire Prevention, shall be under the oversight and
supervision of the Director of Community Development.
(Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02)
§ 30.226 BUILDING OFFICIAL; CODE OFFICIAL; APPOINTMENT.
   There is created hereby the office of Building Official, the holder of which
shall be appointed by the Village President. Wherever within this Municipal
Code or any other ordinance, directive, order, and/or resolution of the Village
reference is made to “Chief Building Official”, “Chief Inspector”, and/or "Code
Official”, such reference shall be construed to designate and mean the
“Building Official”, the office created hereby.
(Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02)
§ 30.227 DUTIES OF THE BUILDING OFFICIAL.
   The Building Official shall have the following duties:
   (A)   To receive all applications required under the Building Code, being
Chapter 150 of this Code, issue permits in accordance with applicable
ordinances of the Village, and furnish the certificates prescribed by the
Building Code.
   (B)   To enforce all ordinance and statutory provisions related to
buildings, permits and zoning, including but not limited to the provisions of
the Building Code and such other ordinances for the Village as may, from time
to time, be committed to the jurisdiction of the Building Department for
administra- tion and enforcement in accordance with the ordinances of the
Village and to issue stop work orders on construction or alteration or repair
of buildings in the Village when such work is being done in violation of any
provision of any ordinance relating thereto or in violation of the zoning
ordinance.
   (C)   To make all the required inspections or accept reports of inspections
by authoritative and recognized services or individuals and, while premises are
in the process of being constructed, altered, repaired or removed, to examine
premises for which permits and certificates have been issued and to make
necessary inspections to see that there has been compliance with all provisions
of the Building Code and other applicable ordinances of the Village, and that
such construction is proceeding and is completed, in accord with the plans for
which a building permit has been issued.
   (D)   To supervise and coordinate housing code enforcement, including but
not limited to inspection and enforcement relating to multi-family dwellings,
and to inspect existing structures as frequently as may be necessary or as
provided in this Code to ascertain whether there is compliance with the
ordinances of the Village and the applicable statutes of the State and, when
necessary, the removal of any existing obstructions, such as laths, plastering,
boarding or partitions which may prevent a perfect inspection, and in addition:
      (1)   To enforce all ordinances relating to plumbing and electrical
wiring and equipment and have the current in any wire or conduit turned off
whenever this is necessary for the protection of life and property.
      (2)   To enforce the Village ordinances in connection with the plumbing
and electrical codes, making inspections of all electrical equipment installed
or altered, except such electrical equipment as may be lawfully exempt, and
shall require conformity with the electrical regulations of this Code, issue
all necessary notices and orders to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to
require the necessary safeguards during construction, to require adequate
exitway facilities in existing buildings and structures, and to ensure
compliance with all requirements for the safety, health and general welfare of
the public.
   (E)   To supervise all employees within the Building Division, including but
not limited to, those performing electrical, plumbing, and heating, ventilat-
ing and air conditioning inspections.
   (F)   As may be necessary in the interest of the public safety, health and
general welfare, to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations to interpret and
implement the provisions of the Building Code to secure the intent thereof and
to designate requirements applicable because of local climatic or other
conditions; but such rules shall not have the effect of waiving working
stresses or fire resistive requirements specifically provided in the Building
Code or violating accepted engineering practice involving public safety.
   (G)   To forward daily to the Village Manager/ Comptroller such monies
collected by him on behalf of the Village and, at least annually, to submit to
the Village Manager/Comptroller a written statement of operations in the form
and content as shall be prescribed, and to perform such other duties delegated
by the Village Manager/Comptroller, the Village President, and/or the President
and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02)
§ 30.228 POWERS OF THE BUILDING OFFICIAL.
   In addition to the duties set forth in §
30.227 above, the Building Official shall have all power and right as may be
necessary to carry out the duties of the Office and the Building Division,
including but not limited to the power to issue permits and certificates
pursuant to all ordinance and applicable statutory provisions related to
buildings and zoning, and to issue stop orders, either orally or in writing,
when work is being done in violation of any applicable zoning, building, or
other ordinance. In furtherance of the foregoing:
   (A)   The Building Official and/or any duly authorized assistant, inspector,
or agent of the Department of Community Development shall have the power to
make or cause to be made entry into any building or other premises at any
reasonable hour upon reasonable notice for the purpose of making an inspection
authorized by this Municipal Code or applicable State statute.
   (B)   Whenever a Village Official (including a member of the Village Police
Department) the Building Official and/or any duly authorized assistant,
inspector (including the Plumbing Inspector), or agent of the Building Division
or the Department of Community Development issues a stop order, work shall not
be resumed after the issuance of such stop order, except upon the written
permission of the Building Official or the Director of the Department of
Community Development. In the event such stop order is issued orally, it shall
be reduced to writing within 24 hours of its issuance.
   (C)   When necessary and in accord with applicable ordinances and statutes,
the Building Official shall cause the removal of any existing building or other
structure.
   (D)   As may be necessary, the Building Official shall have such other power
to delegate powers of the Building Official to other employees of the Building
Division in order to carry out the duties of the office of Building Official.
   (E)   The Building Official and the employees of the Building Division shall
have authority to issue citations and sign complaints in a court of competent
jurisdiction for the violation of ordinances or statutes.
(Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02; Am. Ord. 11-
2848, passed 11-22-11)
§ 30.229 OFFICE OF FOOD SANITARIAN ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established the office of Food Sanitarian. The Food
Sanitarian shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. The Food Sanitarian must be an individual
meeting the requirements of the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation
for the position of "Licensed Environmental Health Practitioner" for the
purpose of inspecting the preparation, storage, and sale of edible foodstuffs
to the general population. The Food Sanitarian shall hold office at the
pleasure of the Village President and shall be compensated at such salary as
shall be determined from time to time by the President and Board of Trustees.
In all matters, the Food Sanitarian shall be under the supervision of the
Department of Community Development and Health Authority and shall perform such
other duties as directed.
(Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02; Am. Ord. 11-
2848, passed 11-22-11; Am. Ord. 23-4361, passed 5-18-23)
§ 30.230 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   DIVISION. The Building Division of the Depart- ment of Community Development
of the Village of Schiller Park.
   BUILDING OFFICIAL. The administrator of the Building Division of the
Department of Community Development of the Village of Schiller Park.
   FOOD SANITARIAN. The Food Sanitarian of the Village of Schiller Park.
   PRESIDENT.  The President, also known as the Mayor, of the Village of
Schiller Park.
   PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park.
(Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 02-2355, passed 8-13-02; Am. Ord. 11-
2848, passed 11-22-11)
VILLAGE PRIVACY OFFICER
§ 30.240 OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT.
   (A)   There is established hereby the office of Privacy Officer, who shall
be appointed for an indefinite term by the Village President by and with the
consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (B)   The President and Board of Trustees also may designate a contact
person to receive complaints and to respond to questions about Village of
Schiller Park privacy polices and procedures and to respond to requests for
notice of the Village's privacy policies and procedures.
(Ord. 03-2393, passed 2-11-03)
§ 30.241 COMPENSATION.
   The Privacy Officer shall receive compensation in such amount and manner as
the Village President and Board of Trustees shall fix, from time to time, by
ordinance or resolution.
(Ord. 03-2393, passed 2-11-03)
§ 30.242 DUTIES OF THE PRIVACY OFFICER.
   The Privacy Officer shall:
   (A)   Oversee all ongoing activities related to the development,
implementation, maintenance of, and adherence to the Village of Schiller Park
policies and procedures covering the privacy of, and access to, patient health
information in compliance with federal and state laws.
   (B)   Train all Village employees in regards to the privacy policies and
procedures and maintain documentation of all training so provided.
   (C)   Put administrative, technical and physical safeguards into practice in
order to protect the privacy of protected health information to avoid
intentional and unintentional prohibited uses and/or disclosures.
   (D)   Establish a process for employees to make complaints about the privacy
policies and procedures, and to report alleged violations and a mechanism for
the documentation of reports and/or complaints.
   (E)   Provide development guidance and assist in the identification,
implementation, and maintenance of information concerning the privacy policies
and procedures of the Village in coordination with the Village Manager/
Comptroller and the Corporation Counsel.
   (F)   Work with the Village Manager/Comptroller to establish a Privacy
Oversight Committee and serve in a leadership capacity for the Privacy
Oversight Committee's activities.
   (G)   Perform initial and periodic information privacy risk assessments and
conduct related ongoing compliance monitoring activities in coordination wits
the Village's other compliance and operational assessment functions.
   (H)   Work with the Corporation Counsel and other Village officials,
departments and committees to ensure the Village has and maintains appropriate
privacy and confidentiality consent, authorization forms, and information
notices and materials reflecting current Village practices and requirements.
   (I)   Oversee, direct, deliver, or ensure delivery of initial and privacy
training and orientation to all employees, volunteers, medical and professional
staff, contractors, alliances, business associates, and other appropriate third
parties.
   (J)   Participate in the development, implemen- tation, and ongoing
compliance monitoring of all business associate agreements, to ensure all
privacy concerns, requirements, and responsibilities are addressed.
   (K)   Establish a mechanism to track access to protected health information,
within the purview of the Village and as required by law, and to allow
qualified individuals to review or receive a report on such activity.
   (L)   Oversee patient rights to inspect, amend, and restrict access to
protected health information when appropriate.
   (M)   Establish and administer a process for receiving, documenting,
tracking, investigating, and taking action on all complaints concerning Village
privacy policies and procedures in coordination and collaboration with other
similar functions and, when necessary, legal counsel.
   (N)   Ensure compliance with privacy practices and consistent application of
sanctions for failure to comply with privacy policies for all individuals in
the Village of Schiller Park workforce, extended workforce, and for all
business associates, in cooperation with the Village Human Resources,
information security officer, administration, and legal counsel as applicable.
   (O)   Initiate, facilitate and promote activities to foster information
privacy awareness within the Village and related entities.
   (P)   Serve as a member of, or liaison to, the Village of Schiller Park
Privacy Oversight Committee, should one exist and also serve as the information
privacy liaison for users of clinical and administrative systems.
   (Q)   Review all system-related information security plans throughout the
Village government network to ensure alignment between security and privacy
practices, and act as a liaison to the information systems department.
   (R)   Work with all Village personnel involved with any aspect of release of
protected health information, to ensure full coordination and cooperation under
Village policies and procedures and legal requirements.
   (S)   Maintain current knowledge of applicable federal and state privacy
laws and accreditation standards, monitor advancements in information privacy
technologies to ensure Village adaptation and compliance.
   (T)   Serve as information privacy consultant to the Village for all Village
departments and entities.
   (U)   Cooperate with the Office of Civil Rights, other legal entities, and
Village officers in any compliance review or investigations.
   (V)   Work with Village administration, its Corporation Counsel and other
related parties to represent the information privacy interests of the Village
when federal or state government adopt or amend privacy legislation,
regulation, or standards.
(Ord. 03-2393, passed 2-11-03)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.01 ELECTION; TERM; DESIGNATION AS THE LEGISLATIVE BODY; DUTIES.
   The Board of Trustees, consisting of seven members, shall be elected to
office for a four year term, according to the method provided by statute. This
Board shall be the legislative department of the Village government and shall
perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated by statute to it.
('73 Code, § 2-119) (Ord. 93-1858, passed 11-23-93; Am. Ord. 95-1915, passed 3-
14-95)
§ 31.02 OATH.
   The members of the Village Board of Trustees shall take the oath of office
prescribed by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-120)
§ 31.03 COMPENSATION.
   Each Village Trustee shall receive an annual salary of $8,450 per year,
payable in 12 equal monthly installments.
('73 Code, § 2-121) (Ord. 65-740, passed 10-18-65; Am. Ord. 83-1506, passed 2-
3-83; Am. Ord. 84-1540, passed 7-19-84; Am. Ord. 90-1761, passed 12-6-90; Am.
Ord. 04-2476, passed 7-27-04)
§ 31.04 PRESIDENT AND TRUSTEES DECLARED CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE; POWERS OF
ARREST.
   The Village President and members of the Board of Trustees, as well as all
members of the Police Department, hereby are declared to be conservators of the
peace with the powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the peace
by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-32)
§ 31.05 CENSURE; EXPULSION.
   Any member of the Village Board of Trustees acting or appearing in a lewd or
disgraceful manner, or who uses opprobrious, obscene or insulting language to
or about any Board member, or who does not obey the order of the chair, shall
be, on motion, censured or expelled by a majority vote of the members present
or expelled by a majority vote of all members elected, or as otherwise required
by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-132)
§ 31.06 STANDING COMMITTEES.
   (A)   Specified. The following shall be the standing committees of the
Village Board of Trustees:
      (1)   Committee on Police, Fire, Emergency Management, 911, and EMS.
      (2)   Committee on Parks, Special Events, Senior Services, Library, and
Historical Commission.
      (3)   Committee on Business, Liquor, Ordinances, Utilities, and General
Permits.
      (4)   Committee on Streets, Water, Storm Water, Engineering, and Fleet/
Building Maintenance.
      (5)   Committee on Human Resources, Insurance, Bills, and Legal.
      (6)   Committee on Planning, Zoning, Health, Building, Environment, and
Transportation.
   (B)   Membership; appointment. Each regular committee shall consist of a
Chairman and two members to be appointed by the Village President.
   (C)   Reports. Any report of a committee shall be deferred for final action
thereon to the next regular meeting after the report is made, upon the request
of any two members of the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-168) (Ord. 89-1709, passed 4-20-89; Am. Ord. 91-1773, passed 6-
6-91; Am. Ord. 93-1835, passed 6-22-93; Am. Ord. 95-1949, passed 8-8-95; Am.
Ord. 01-2302, passed 12-11-02; Am. Ord. 05-2516, passed 4-26-05; Am. Ord. 15-
3010, passed 6-4-15; Am. Ord. 18-4060, passed 5-17-18)
MEETINGS; GENERALLY
§ 31.15 REGULAR.
   The Village Board of Trustees shall hold regular meetings in the Village
Hall on the first and third Thursday of each month at 7:00 p.m., provided that
when the day fixed for any regular meeting of the Board falls on a day
designated as a holiday in Section
30.012 of this Code, the meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next
succeeding day not a holiday. Notice of the regular meeting shall be posted as
provided by law.
('73 Code, § 2-122) (Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 04-2451, passed 1-
27-04; Am. Ord. 13-2934, passed 8-27-13)
§ 31.16 SPECIAL.
   Special meetings may be called by the President or any three Trustees upon a
48 hour written notice to both the public in accord with ILCS Ch. 5, Act 120, §
2.02 and to all of the President and Board of Trustees. Such notice shall be
given by the Village Clerk and shall specify the time and purpose of such
meeting and shall be delivered to each member of the Village Board personally,
if he can be found, and if he cannot be found, then by leaving a copy of such
notice at the home of such board member in the presence of an adult member of
the family of such member; provided that the requirement of written notice to
the President and Trustees shall not be binding in any special meeting at which
all of the members of the Village Board are present.
(Ord. 93-1828, passed 4-28-93)
§ 31.17 OPEN TO THE PUBLIC.
   Unless portions thereof may be exempted by statute, all meetings shall be
open to the public, as required by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-124)
MEETINGS; ORDER OF BUSINESS; PROCEDURE
§ 31.30 PRESIDENT TO SERVE AS PRESIDING OFFICER.
   The Village President shall be the presiding officer at all regular and
special meetings of the Village Board of Trustees and at all times when the
Board meets as committee of the whole. The presiding officer shall preserve
strict order and decorum at all meetings of the Board, shall state every
question coming before it, shall announce the decision of the Board on all
subjects and shall decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to the
Board, in which event a majority vote of its members shall govern and
conclusively determine the question of order.
('73 Code, § 2-126)
§ 31.31 DUTY OF PRESIDING OFFICER.
   (A)   Besides preserving order and decorum, the presiding officer may speak
to points of order in preference to other members and shall decide all
questions of order, subject to appeal.
   (B)   In case of any disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding
officer shall have the power to require the chamber to be cleared.
('73 Code, § 2-143)
§ 31.32 AGENDA.
   All committee reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract
documents or other matters to be submitted to the Village Board of Trustees,
shall, at least five days before the date of each Board meeting, be delivered
to the Village Clerk, who shall arrange a list of the meetings according to the
order of business three days in advance of the Board meeting. The Board may
consider urgent matters properly brought before it by a member of the Board or
administrative official even if it does not appear on the agenda, provided
first that a unanimous consent to do so is granted by the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-125) (Am. Ord. 92-1796, passed 1-16-92)
§ 31.33 OPENING OF MEETINGS.
   The Village President shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed
for the Board of Trustees' meeting and immediately shall call the meeting to
order. In the absence of the President, the Village Clerk shall call the
meeting to order, whereupon a temporary presiding officer shall be elected by
the members of the Board present. Upon the arrival of the President, the
temporary presiding officer immediately shall relinquish the chair upon the
conclusion of the business immediately before the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-140)
§ 31.34 QUORUM.
   A majority of the members of the Village Board of Trustees or three Trustees
and the Village President shall constitute a quorum to do business.
('73 Code, § 2-141)
§ 31.35 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   (A)   The order of business shall be as follows:
      (1)   Call to order by the presiding officer.
       (2)   Roll call.
      (3)   The reading of the journal minutes of the proceedings of the last
previous meeting or meetings, and correction and approval of them,
unlessdispensed with by the Village Board of Trustees and correction of the
minutes of the proceedings of previous meetings; provided, it shall not be
necessary to read the minutes of a meeting verbatim when copies thereof have
been provided to the Village President and each member of the Board and
distributed to department heads at least three full days before the
commencement of the meeting at which the minutes are to be presented.
      (4)   Reports and communications from the Village President and other
Village officers.
      (5)   Reports of standing committees, which shall be in writing and be
read by the Village Clerk unless consent to make an oral report is given to the
committee Chairman by a majority of the members present.
      (6)   Reports of special committees, which shall be governed by the rules
set forth in division (5) above.
      (7)   Presentation of communications, petitions, resolutions, orders and
ordinances.
      (8)   Unfinished business.
      (9)   Miscellaneous business.
      (10)    Adjournment.
   (B)   All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by
the chair without debate, subject to appeal.
('73 Code, § 2-142)
§ 31.36 CONDUCT OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   While the presiding officer is putting a question, no member of the
Village Board of Trustees shall walk across or out of the Board's chamber.
   (B)   Every member, previous to his making a motion or seconding the same,
shall address himself to the presiding officer and shall not proceed with his
or her remarks until recognized and named by the chair. He or she shall confine
himself or herself to the question under debate, avoiding personalities and
refraining from impugning the motives of any other member's argument or vote.
   (C)   When two or more members address the presiding officer at the same
time, the presiding officer shall name the member who is first to speak.
('73 Code, § 2-144)
§ 31.37 ADDRESSING THE BOARD.
   Any person shall be permitted an opportunity to address the Village Board
under the rules established and adopted by the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-145) (Am. Ord. 10-2809, passed 12-14-10)
§ 31.38 PRESENTATION OF COMMUNICATIONS; PETITIONS.
   When a member of the Village Board of Trustees wishes to present a
communication, petition, order, resolution, ordinance or other original matter,
he or she shall send it to the desk of the Village Clerk, who shall read it
when reached in its proper order.
('73 Code, § 2-146)
§ 31.39 DEBATE.
   (A)   Procedure.
      (1)   No member of the Village Board of Trustees shall speak more than
once on the same question, except by unanimous consent, and then not until
every other member desiring to speak shall have had an opportunity to do so;
provided, the proponent of the matter under consideration or the Chairman of
the committee whose report is under consideration, as the case may be, shall
have the right to open and close debate.
      (2)   No member shall speak longer than ten minutes at any one time,
except by consent of the Board, and in closing debate on any question as above
provided, the speaker shall be limited to five minutes, except by special
consent of the Board.
   (B)   Distractions. While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any
private discussion, nor pass between the speaker and the Chair.
('73 Code, § 2-147)
§ 31.40 CALL OF MEMBER TO ORDER.
   A member of the Village Board of Trustees, when called to order by the
chair, shall thereupon discontinue speaking and take his or her seat and the
order or ruling of the chair shall be binding and conclusive, subject only to
the right of appeal.
('73 Code, § 2-148)
§ 31.41 APPEAL OF DECISIONS OF CHAIR.
   Any member of the Village Board of Trustees may appeal to the Board from a
ruling of the chair and, if the appeal is seconded, the member making the
appeal may briefly state his or her reason for the same and the chair may
briefly explain his or her ruling; however, there shall be no debate on the
appeal and no other member shall participate in the discussion. The chair shall
then put the question, “Shall the decision of the chair be sustained?” If a
majority of the members present vote no, the decision of the chair shall be
overruled; otherwise, it shall be sustained.
('73 Code, § 2-149)
§ 31.42 PRIVILEGED QUESTIONS.
   The right of a member of the Village Board of Trustees to address the Board
on a question of personal privilege shall be limited to cases in which his or
her integrity, character or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned.
('73 Code, § 2-150)
§ 31.43 DUTY TO VOTE; CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   Every member of the Village Board of Trustees who shall be present when a
question is stated from the chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the
Board or unless he or she is personally interested in the question, in which
case he or she shall not vote.
('73 Code, § 2-151)
§ 31.44 DESIGNATION OF MATTERS AS SPECIAL ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   Any matter before the Village Board of Trustees may be set down as a special
order of business at a time certain, if 2/3 of the Trustees present vote in the
affirmative, but not other otherwise.
('73 Code, § 2-152)
§ 31.45 DIVISION OF QUESTIONS.
   If any question under consideration contains several distinct propositions,
the Village Board of Trustees, by a majority vote of the members present, may
divide the question.
('73 Code, § 2-164)
§ 31.46 ROBERTS RULES OF ORDER APPLICABLE.
   The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published
edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern the Village
Board of Trustees in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they
are not inconsistent with special rules of this Board.
('73 Code, § 2-171)
§ 31.47 TEMPORARY SUSPENSION OF RULES.
   The rules of order set out in this subchapter may be temporarily suspended
by a vote of 2/3 of all the members of the Village Board of Trustees entitled
by law to be elected.
('73 Code, § 2-172)
§ 31.48 AMENDMENT OF RULES.
   The rules of order set out in this subchapter shall not be altered or
amended, unless by a concurrence of 2/3 of all the members of the Village Board
of Trustees entitled by law to be elected.
('73 Code, § 2-173)
§ 31.49 REMOTE PARTICIPATION.
   Any member of the Village of Schiller Park, Illinois, public body may attend
and participate in any meeting of such public body as defined in the Open
Meetings Act from a remote location by way of telephone, video or internet
connection, provided that such attendance and participation is in compliance
with the Remote Participation Policy set forth in this Division and any other
applicable state or local laws.
   (A)   Policy Statement. It is the policy of the Village of Schiller Park
that a member of any group associated with this unit of government which is
subject to the provisions of the Open Meetings Act (herein "Subject Group") may
attend and participate in any open or closed meeting of that Subject Group from
a remote location by way of telephone, video or internet connection, provided
that such attendance and participation is in compliance with this policy and
any other applicable state or local laws.
   (B)   Prerequisites. A member of the Subject Group of the Village of
Schiller Park shall be provided the opportunity to attend an open and closed
meeting or only one of such meetings from a remote location if the member meets
the following conditions and a majority of the members present of the Subject
Body votes to approve the remote attendance.
      (1)   The member must notify the clerk or recording secretary of the
Subject Body at least twenty-four (24) hours before the meeting unless advance
notice is impractical.
      (2)   The member must assert one of three reasons described herein why he
or she is unable to physically attend the meeting, including either: (1) that
the member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability; (2) the
member cannot attend because of requirements of employment or the business of
the Village of Schiller Park; or (3) the member cannot attend because of a
family or other emergency; and
      (3)   A quorum of the Subject Body must be physically present.
   (C)   Voting Procedures. After roll call, a vote for the Subject Body shall
be taken, considering the prerequisites set forth in the above mentioned
Section, (B)(2), on whether to allow an off-site board member to participate
remotely. All of the members physically present are permitted to vote on
whether remote participation will be allowed. A vote may be taken to permit
remote participation for a stated series of meetings if the same reason applies
to each case. Otherwise, a vote must be taken to allow each instance of remote
participation.
   (D)   Quorum and Vote Required. A quorum of physically present members must
be established at any meeting before it can be considered whether to allow a
member to participate in the meeting remotely. A vote of a majority of the
members present shall be necessary to decide the issue. For the meeting to
continue, there shall always need to be a quorum physically present.
   (E)   Minutes. The member participating remotely shall be considered an off-
site participant and counted as present by means of video or audio conference
for that meeting if the member is allowed to participate. The meeting minutes
of the Village of Schiller Park shall also reflect and state specifically
whether each member is physically present, present by video, or present by
audio means.
   (F)   Rights of Remote Member. The member permitted to participate remotely
will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate
in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all
general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to.
The remote member shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken.
Accordingly, the name of any remote member shall be called during any vote
taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the Clerk or secretary and
placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member participating
remotely may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member, provided
the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and
returning. A member participating remotely must be able to hear all of the
meeting clearly without interruption and the Subject Group and public must be
able to hear the member participating remotely.
   (G)   Closed Meetings. A quorum of the Village of Schiller Park's members
must be physically present at any closed meeting. Members participating
remotely shall otherwise be entitled to participate in closed meetings by video
or audio conference as provided above.
   (H)   Costs. A member participating remotely by way of telephone shall be
reimbursed for the cost of the telephone call upon a valid receipt shown. Any
other costs associated with remote participation, including video conferencing
and other audio and video equipment, must be approved by the Village of
Schiller Park.
(Ord. 13-2939, passed 10-3-13)
ORDINANCES
§ 31.60 STYLE.
   The style of all ordinances shall be: “BE IT ORDAINED by the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park,” as is provided by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-127)
§ 31.61 PUBLICATION; APPROVAL AND VETO.
   (A)   All resolutions and motions which create any liability against the
Village, or which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, or
the sale of any Village property, and all ordinances passed by the Village
shall be published as required by law.
   (B)   All ordinances passed by the Village Board of Trustees shall be
deposited with the Village Clerk. If the Village President approves of them, he
or she shall sign them. Those of which he or she disapproves shall be returned
to the Board, with the President's written objections, at the next regular
meeting of the Board occurring not less than five days after their passage. If
the President fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution with
his or her written objections within the designated time, it shall become
effective despite the absence of his or her signature.
   (C)   The Village President may disapprove any sums appropriated in any
ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation and, if so, the
remainder shall be effective. However, the President may disapprove entirely an
ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation.
('73 Code, § 2-128)
§ 31.62 RECONSIDERING; OVER-RIDING VETO.
   Every resolution and motion specified in §
31.61(B), and every ordinance which is returned to the Village Board of
Trustees by the Village President, shall be reconsidered by the Board. If,
after the reconsideration, 2/3 of all Trustees elected to the Board shall agree
to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the President's
refusal to approve it, it shall be effective. The vote on the question of
passage over the Presidents' veto shall be by yeas and nays and shall be
recorded in the minutes.
('73 Code, § 2-129)
§ 31.63 PUBLICATION.
   All ordinances imposing any penalty for a violation thereof or making any
appropriation shall be published as required by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-130)
§ 31.64 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   No ordinance which must be published to comply with §
31.63 shall go into effect until ten days after it is so published, and all
other ordinances shall go into effect on the passage and approval thereof, as
provided by statute.
('73 Code, § 2-131)
MOTIONS
§ 31.70 GENERALLY.
   (A)   When a question is under debate, the following shall be in order and
shall have precedence over order, as listed:
      (1)   To adjourn to a day certain.
      (2)   To adjourn.
      (3)   To take a recess.
      (4)   To lay the table (postpone temporarily).
      (5)   To put the previous question (vote immediately).
      (6)   To refer (to committee, etc).
      (7)   To amend.
      (8)   To defer or postpone to a time certain.
      (9)   To defer or postpone (without reference to time).
      (10)   To defer or postpone indefinitely.
   (B)   Motions (2), (4) and (5) shall be decided without debate.
('73 Code, § 2-153)
§ 31.71 ADJOURNMENT; WHEN IN ORDER; PROCEDURE.
   (A)   A motion to adjourn the Village Board of Trustees shall always be in
order, except:
      (1)   When a member is in possession of the floor.
      (2)   While the yeas and nays are being called.
      (3)   When the members are voting.
      (4)   When adjournment was the last preceding motion.
      (5)   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
   (B)   A motion simply to adjourn shall not be subject to amendment or
debate, but a motion to adjourn to a time certain shall be.
   (C)   The Board, at any time, may adjourn one or more regular meetings on a
vote of a majority of all the Trustees authorized by law to be elected.
('73 Code, § 2-154)
§ 31.72 SECONDING REQUIRED; CERTAIN MOTIONS TO BE IN WRITING.
   No motion shall be put to or debated by the Village Board of Trustees or in
committee unless it is seconded. When a motion is seconded, it shall be stated
by the presiding officer before debate, and every motion before the Board
except motions of procedure shall be reduced to writing, if required by a
member, and the proponent of the motion shall be entitled to the floor.
('73 Code, § 2-155)
§ 31.73 WITHDRAWAL OF MOTION OR RESOLUTION.
   After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it shall be
deemed to be in possession of the Village Board of Trustees, but it may be
withdrawn at any time before decision, by consent of the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-156)
§ 31.74 RECORD.
   In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered in the journal, the
name of the member moving the same shall be entered also.
('73 Code, § 2-157)
§ 31.75 PREVIOUS QUESTION.
   When a previous question is moved on the main question and seconded, it
shall be put in this form: “Shall the main question now be put?” If the motion
is carried, all further amendment and all further motions and debate shall be
excluded, and the question put without delay, upon the pending amendments in
proper order and then upon the main question.
('73 Code, § 2-158)
§ 31.76 TO LAY ON OR TAKE OFF TABLE.
   (A)   A motion simply to lay a question on the table shall not be debatable,
but a motion to lay on the table and publish, or with any other condition,
shall be subject to amendment and debate.
   (B)   A motion to take any motion or other proposition the table shall apply
to that motion or proposition only. An amendment to the main question or other
pending question may be laid on the table and neither the main question or the
other pending question shall be affected thereby.
('73 Code, 2-159)
§ 31.77 POSTPONEMENT.
   (A)   When consideration of a motion or other proposal is postponed
indefinitely, it shall not be taken up at the meeting.
   (B)   A motion to postpone indefinitely shall not open the main question to
debate.
   (C)   A motion to defer or postpone without any reference to time shall not
be construed as a motion to postpone indefinitely, but shall be considered to
be of the same and to possess the same general nature and to possess the same
general attributes, as far as applicable under these rules, as a motion to
postpone indefinitely or to a time certain.
('73 Code, § 2-160)
§ 31.78 REFERRAL.
   A motion to refer to a standing committee shall precedence over a similar
motion to refer to a special committee.
('73 Code, § 2-161)
§ 31.79 AMENDMENTS.
   (A)   A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an
amendment to an amendment shall entertained.
   (B)   An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order,
but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
   (C)   An amendment to “strike out and insert,” the paragraph to be amended
shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken out,
then those to be inserted, and finally the paragraph as it will stand if so
amended shall be read.
   (D)   An amendment to the main question or other pending question may be
referred to a committee and neither the main question nor the other pending
question shall be affected thereby.
('73 Code, § 2-162)
§ 31.80 SUBSTITUTION.
   A substitute for any original proposition under debate or for any pending
amendment to the proposition may be entertained, notwithstanding that when
further amendment is admissible, and, if accepted by vote of the Village Board
of Trustees, shall entirely supersede the original proposition or amendment, as
the case may be, and cut off all amendment thereto.
('73 Code, § 2-163)
VOTING
§ 31.90 PROCEDURE.
   (A)   If any member requires it, the “yeas” and the ”nays” upon any question
shall be taken and entered in the journal, but the “yeas” and “nays” shall not
be taken unless called for previously to any vote on the question.
   (B)   When the Village Clerk has commenced to call the roll of the Village
Board of Trustees for the taking of a vote by “yeas” and ”nays” all debate on
the question before the Board shall be deemed concluded, and during the taking
of the vote no member shall be permitted to explain his or her vote but shall
respond to the calling of his name by the Clerk with “yea” or “nay,” as the
case may be.
('73 Code, 2-165)
§ 31.91 ANNOUNCEMENT OF VOTES; WHEN CHANGES NOT PERMITTED.
   The result of all votes by “yeas” and “nays” shall not be announced by the
Village Clerk but shall be handed by the Clerk to the Chairman for
announcement, and no vote shall be changed after the tally list has passed from
the hands of the Clerk.
('73 Code, § 2-166)
§ 31.92 RECONSIDERATION; PROCEDURE.
   (A)   A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same
meeting or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration, having been once made and decided in the negative, shall not
be renewed nor shall a motion to reconsider be reconsidered.
   (B)   A motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by members who voted
on the prevailing side of the question to considered, unless otherwise provided
by law; provided, where a motion has received a majority vote in the
affirmative but is declared lost solely on the ground that a greater number of
affirmative votes is required by statute for the passage or adoption of the
motion, a motion to reconsider may be made and seconded only by those who voted
in the affirmative on the question to be reconsidered.
('73 Code, § 2-167)
§ 31.93 YEAS AND NAYS.
   (A)   The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances
and on all propositions to create any liability against the Village, or for the
expenditure or appropriation of its money and in all other cases at the request
of any member of the Board of Trustees. The vote shall be entered in the
minutes of the proceedings, as is provided by statute.
   (B)   The concurrence of a majority of the Trustees or three Trustees and
the Village President is necessary for the passage of any ordinance or any
proposition, except where the statute requires the favorable vote of 2/3 or 3/
4 of the Board.
('73 Code, § 2-169)
§ 31.94 WHEN PRESIDENT MAY VOTE.
   (A)   The Village President shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or
motion except:
      (1)   Where the vote of the Board of Trustees has resulted in a tie.
      (2)   Where ½ of the Trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance,
resolution or motion, even though there is no tie vote.
   (B)   In both instances specified in division (A) above, the Village
President shall vote.
   (C)   Nothing in this section shall deprive a President Pro Tem from voting
in his or her capacity as Trustee, but he or she shall not be entitled to
another vote in his capacity as President Pro Tem.
('73 Code, § 2-170)
