GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 32.01 ESTABLISHED; PERSONNEL.
   (A)   It hereby is established, a fire department, an executive department.
The classified service of the department shall include such members in number
and rank as may be provided for from time to time by an ordinance amending
subsection (B) of this section, adopted by the President and Board of Trustees.
In addition, the non-classified service of the department shall include such
civilians, clerks and other employees, which the President and Board of
Trustees may provide by adoption of the annual Village budget and which at the
recommendation of the Fire Chief and with the approval of the majority of
Corporate Authorities hire.
   (B)   All members holding classified positions shall have been appointed to
those classified positions by the Fire and Police Commission in accordance with
and shall be subject to the rules of the Fire and Police Commission. The
uniformed fire service of the Fire Department shall be comprised of
lieutenants, firefighter/paramedics, and such other members of the uniformed
fire service all as may be authorized from time to time by the President and
Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Office of Chief. There is created hereby the office of Chief of the
Fire Department, a position exempt from appointment by the Village Fire and
Police Commission. The Chief of the Fire Department is a sworn firefighter and
shall be appointed by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the
President and Board of Trustees; provided that if the person appointed chief
was, at the time of his appointment, a member of the department, he shall
retain his status and rank while serving as Fire Chief and shall revert to such
status and rank when his or her term as chief has ended unless he retires as
Fire Chief. The following shall apply:
      (1)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be qualified through
training and experience to administer the Fire Department. The Chief shall work
under the direction of the Village Manager and Village President. The Chief may
issue such general orders or directives consistent with this Code in
furtherance of the operation of the Department as he or she sees fit. The Chief
shall have all firefighting duties allocated by the Village and State of
Illinois to participate and control, on the scene, fires within the Village.
      (2)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall serve at the discretion of
the Village President and shall receive such compensation as will be fixed by
the President and Board of Trustees from time to time.
      (3)   All authorities granted to a fire chief by Illinois State statutes
shall apply to the Chief of the Fire Department. The Chief of the Fire
Department shall be responsible for the direction and performance of all Fire
Department functions including all fire personnel of the Village, whether
members of the classified service or members of the non-classified service. The
Chief of the Fire Department is required to ensure the efficient operation of
the Fire Department and all members of the Fire Department shall obey the
orders, rules and regulations given or set by the Chief of the Fire Department
for the conduct and guidance of the members of the Fire Department.
      (4)   Whenever in this Code reference is made to "Superintendent of the
Fire Department" or "Fire Chief, such reference shall be to the "Chief of the
Fire Department".
   (D)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be reserved the power to
appoint the positions of, but not limited to, Battalion Chiefs/Commanders, EMS
Coordinator, Fire Prevention Coordinator and Training Officer provided that the
person so appointed at the time of appointment is in the uniformed fire service
and at a minimum rank of Lieutenant within the Schiller Park Fire Department.
   (E)   Upon appointment, all sworn firefighters shall execute the prescribed
oath of office before entering upon their respective duties.
   (F)   Compensation. All members of the Fire Department shall be paid as
provided from time to time by the Village President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 08-2683, passed 6-24-08; Am. Ord. 09-
2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 12-2892, passed 5-22-12; Am. Ord. 14-2971,
passed 8-7-14; Am. Ord. 15-3009, passed 6-4-15; Am. Ord. 16-3053, passed 5-5-
16; Am. Ord. 17-3089, passed 1-5-17; Am. Ord. 22-4327, passed 10-20-22)
§ 32.02 DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS.
   (A)   Classified Service. It shall be the function of the Fire Department
and the duty of each sworn firefighter to prevent and extinguish fires and to
act as a firefighter/paramedic (emergency medical technician) in incidents of
medical emergency occurring in the Village and to sites of fire to which the
department will respond in rendering auto/mutual aid; to enforce all ordinances
relating to fire hazards within the Village; and to undertake such other duties
as may be assigned from time to time.
   (B)   Non-Classified Service. Civilians may be hired from time to time by
the Village President to undertake work in accordance with orders given by the
Chief of the Fire Department, including but not limited to secretarial tasks
with the approval and consent of the Village President and Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Duty to Appear as Witness. Each member of the Fire Department shall
appear as a witness whenever necessary in the prosecution of a violation of an
ordinance or of any state or federal law. No member shall retain any witness
fee for the service as witness in any action or suit to which the Village is a
party. Any fees for such service shall be forwarded to the Chief of the Fire
Department who shall deposit them with the Village Treasurer.
   (D)   Each member of the Fire Department shall appear for and honor civil
subpoenas for oral depositions in any civil action where testimony of the
member is sought. For those oral depositions in cases where the Village is not
a party, the depositions of members of the Fire Department shall be conducted
at the Village Hall during the deponent's regularly scheduled shift, unless an
order of court provides otherwise. The member shall forward any fees for such
service to the Chief of the Fire Department who shall deposit them with the
Village Treasurer.
   (E)   Upon receipt of a subpoena, the member shall immediately forward a
copy of the subpoena to the Chief of the Fire Department who shall forward a
copy to the Corporation Counsel's office. The Chief of the Fire Department or
the Corporation Counsel shall promptly notify the party who caused the issuance
of the subpoena about the existence of this section.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 12-
2880, passed 2-14-12; Am. Ord. 15-3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.03 ADOPTION OF RULES.
   The Chief of the Fire Department is authorized hereby to establish and order
such rules and regulations as the Department Chief sees fit for the guidance of
members of the Fire Department in the management and operation of the Fire
Department provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall not be
inconsistent with this Code and/or the Rules and Regulations of the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners of the Village.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.04 CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE; ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the duty of all persons in the classified service of the Fire
Department and all police officers of the Village to see that the provisions of
this chapter and
Chapter 92 of this Code are enforced and to arrest on view any person who shall
be found violating any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall hinder,
resist or refuse to obey any such officer in the discharge of duty and to that
end, all persons in the classified service of the Fire Department are made
hereby conservators of the peace.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.05 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Within 180 days of the successful completion of his probationary
period, an appointee to a position in the uniformed fire service of the Village
shall be required to move within the area bounded on the north and the east by
the Illinois State line, on the south by Interstate 80, and on the west by
Illinois State Route 47.
   (B)   Residence requirements modified or newly adopted for positions in the
uniformed fire service of the Village shall apply to employees already
appointed thereto, whether such employee has already been certified therein or
is within the probationary period therefor. All such employees shall be
required to comply with modified or newly adopted residence requirements within
twelve (12) months of the adoption thereof.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.06 USE OF VOLUNTEERS AUTHORIZED.
   The Director of the Fire Department is authorized to call to duty any
appointed and trained Volunteer Firefighter of the Village to supplement the
needs of the regular Fire Department when there is a situation which, in the
opinion of the Director, requires the use of additional fire personnel.
   (A)   Composition of Auxiliary Firefighter Group. This group may consist of
the following part-time Volunteer Firefighters to supplement and assist the
Department: One (1) captain, one (1) lieutenant, and further part-time
Volunteer Firefighters as, from time to time, may be hired by the Village
President.
   (B)   Appointment; Termination. To further the Fire Department's needs, the
Village President is authorized hereby to appoint residents as Volunteer
Firefighters in a number as the Village President may deem necessary, with the
advice and consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The term of
appointment of Volunteer Firefighters appointed hereunder shall be at the
pleasure of the Village President and may be terminated by the
VillagePresident, with the understanding that failure to reside within the
corporate limits of the Village shall constitute automatic termination of
employment.
   (C)   Other Provisions Incorporated by Reference. Volunteer Firefighters are
part-time employees and are subject to the orders and directions of the
Director of the Fire Department and the provisions of this chapter and all
rules and regulations of the Fire Department that are not in conflict with this
section.
   (D)   Training. No person appointed as a Volunteer Firefighter shall
commence work as a Volunteer before receiving proper training in fire fighting
technology and until proficient therein as determined by the Director of the
Fire Department.
   (E)   Compensation. Volunteer Firefighters shall be paid as provided from
time to time by the Village President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.07 FIRE CADET PROGRAM.
   A Village Fire Cadet Program, consisting of a 200-hour course in
firefighting skills, is established hereby, which shall be operated under the
supervision of the Director of the Fire Department. Fire cadets will be trained
by Village employees who are in the Classified Service.
   (A)   Purpose; Rules.
      (1)   The purpose of the Fire Cadet Program is to provide a training
regimen in fire safety and technology for Village youths between the ages of
sixteen (16) and twenty (20) years.
      (2)   The Director of the Fire Department shall make such rules and
regulations regarding fire cadets as are consistent with the rules of the
Department, this chapter, and as the Department Director may deem necessary for
the Fire Cadet Program.
   (B)   Release of Village. Prior to admission to the program, each person
seeking to be a fire cadet shall provide the Village with a medical certificate
of good health and a release of the Village from liability for injury or
damages resulting from participation in the program.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§§ 32.08 — 32.10 RESERVED.
ADMINISTRATION
§ 32.11 CONTROL AND SUPERVISION.
   (A)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have the control and
supervision, subject to the order and direction of the Village President, of
the Fire Department and all fire apparatus and equipment belonging to the
Village.
   (B)   At the scene of any fire or medical emergency: In the absence of the
Chief of the Fire Department, the person having the highest rank in the
classified service of the Fire Department shall take command of all sworn
firefighters on the scene and direct the management thereof for the suppression
of the fire, in the best manner possible, and when it may be necessary for the
protection of other property to prevent the spread of the conflagration, such
person may cause buildings to be torn down, removed or destroyed in the best
manner possible.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.12 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT; DUTIES; COMPENSATION.
   The Chief of the Fire Department is authorized to appoint an administrative
assistant, at a minimum rank of Lieutenant, as the Chief of the Fire Department
may deem necessary, from time to time, for the efficient operation of the
Department and in the absence of the Chief, from time to time, shall have the
same duties and responsibilities as the Chief of the Fire Department. This
administrative assistant shall perform the duties as may be ordered by the
Chief of the Fire Department and shall receive compensation in the amount as
may be established by ordinance from time to time.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.13 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   (A)   All persons in the uniformed fire service are required to have a
physical examination every two (2) years at the expense of the Village, and at
the time and place and with the medical personnel who shall perform physical
examinations as designated by the Chief of the Fire Department, who shall
maintain a record of all such physical examinations.
   (B)   A physical examination that is conducted by medical personnel other
than those designated by the Chief of the Fire Department shall not satisfy the
requirements of this section.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.14 CLOTHING AND EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   In addition to all other compensation provided to the employees of the
Village, each of those in the classified service shall receive an annual
allowance for clothing and equipment in an amount as established by the
President and Board of Trustees from time to time.
   (B)   At his own expense, any Volunteer Firefighter or person in the
Classified Service may equip a motor vehicle owned and operated solely by him
with not to exceed two (2) lamps, each of which shall emit a blue flashing
light without glare while such person is responding to a fire.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§§ 32.15 — 32.20 RESERVED.
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE
§ 32.21 MEETINGS; ELECTION OF OFFICERS; DUTIES.
   (A)   Those in the Classified Service and in the Non-Classified Service of
the Fire Department shall hold regular meetings, as provided in the rules
prescribed pursuant to §
32.03. During a meeting held in the month of April each year, those in the
Classified Service and in the Non-Classified Service of the Department shall
elect a Secretary and Treasurer, who shall act in that capacity for a term of
one (1) year. The duties of the Secretary and Treasurer shall be as specified
in this section.
   (B)   The Secretary of the Fire Department shall keep minutes of all
meetings of those in the Classified Service of the Department.
   (C)   Treasurer: Bond and Duties.
      (1)   The Treasurer of the Fire Department, before taking office, shall
execute and file with the Village Clerk a sufficient bond in an amount to be
determined from time to time by the Village President and Board of Trustees, in
favor of the Village, to be approved by the President and Board, conditioned
for the faithful performance of the Treasurer's duties.
      (2)   The Treasurer shall receive all money collected for and on behalf
of the Department, including the tax or license fee for foreign fire insurance
companies, and shall pay the same upon the order of the Department for the
purpose of maintenance, use and benefit of the Department.
      (3)   The books, records and accounts of the Treasurer shall be kept
faithfully and at all times shall be open to inspection and an audit of the
President and Board of Trustees.
      (4)   At the expiration of a Treasurer's term of office, each such
Treasurer shall surrender, pay and deliver to his or her successor in office
all books, records, accounts and money held as Treasurer.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§§ 32.22 — 32.24 RESERVED.
BUREAU OF EMERGENCY
MEDICAL SERVICES
§ 32.25 BUREAU ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION.
   There is established hereby the Bureau of Emergency Medical Services, which
shall operate under the supervision of the Department Chief. The Bureau shall
consist of the EMS Coordinator, which shall be a licensed paramedic and sworn
officer with the rank no lower than that of lieutenant, as well as other
regular firefighter/paramedic personnel and civilian paramedic personnel all of
which personnel shall have been specifically trained in emergency cardiac and
non-cardiac care in a training program approved by the Illinois Department of
Public Health and certified thereby to render emergency medical services at the
level of emergency technician-paramedic—in such number as the President and
Board of Trustees may provide salaries from time to time.
   (A)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall appoint the EMS Coordinator
with the approval and consent of the Village President and Board of Trustees.
   (B)   The duties of the EMS Coordinator shall be as specified in the rules
and regulations of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 12-
2892, passed 5-22-12; Am. Ord. 14-2971, passed 8-7-14; Am. Ord. 15-3009, passed
6-4-15)
§ 32.26 DUTIES OF BUREAU, GENERALLY.
   It shall be the duty of the members of the EMS Bureau to provide emergency
basic life support services, advanced life support-mobile intensive care
services and pre-hospital care to the public. They shall operate and maintain
Village emergency vehicles and equipment and shall perform other duties as may
be required by the rules and regulations of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.27 EMERGENCY SERVICE USER FEES.
   (A)   Remuneration. The recipients of basic life support services and/or
advanced life support-mobile intensive care services from the firefighter/
paramedic service program of the Village are obligated to pay a fee each and
every time the services are provided by the Village for the use and operation
of a Village ambulance or the EMS paramedic program, in an amount and in
accordance with the following schedule:
      BASIC LIFE SUPPORT RATES
         Service                   Fee   
      BLS Treat/Transport                $3,861.00*   
      ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT RATES
         Service                   Fee
      ALS Treat/No Transport               $3,861.00*
      ALS Treat/Transport               $3,861.00*
      ALS2 Treat/Transport                $3,861.00*
   *The above referenced fees shall be increased or decreased, without further
action of the Corporate Authorities, in accordance with the rates as approved
for the Ground Emergency Medical Transportation Program.
      MILEAGE
         Fee             
      $26.00 per transported mile**          
   **The mileage fee shall be increased annually effective January 1 of each
year, without further action of the Corporate Authorities, pursuant to the
Medicare ambulance inflation factor or three (3) percent, whichever is greater.
All recipients of the service shall be billed for the service after completion
thereof, and no person shall be denied service for reason of failure to pay
past amounts billed or for reason of lack of residency within the corporate
limits of the Village of Schiller Park.
   (B)   Responsibility for Payment of Fee. Primary responsibility for the
payment of the user fees for firefighter/paramedic or ambulance services shall
be upon the recipient of the services. Notwithstanding, third parties may
consent voluntarily to the invoicing of the recipient where payment is made by
third parties. The Village Comptroller is authorized hereby to establish
necessary billing procedures not inconsistent with the provisions of this
section and, if necessary, to utilize the services of a billing and collection
company in order to process the invoices and collection of user fees. The
Village Comptroller and the Chief of the Fire Department are authorized to
establish necessary policies, procedures, and regulations to administer and
process the imposition and collection of user fees.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 10-
2765, passed 3-9-10; Am. Ord. 19-4133, passed 3-21-19; Am. Ord. 20-4231, passed
7-2-20; Am. Ord. 21-4279, passed 6-3-21)
§§ 32.28 — 32.30 RESERVED.
BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION
§ 32.31 ESTABLISHED; DESIGNATION OF INSPECTORS.
   (A)   The Bureau of Fire Prevention in the Fire Department hereby is
established, which shall be operated under the supervision of the Fire Chief.
   (B)   The President and Board of Trustees also may designate from time to
time the number of additional inspectors to serve in the Bureau of Fire
Prevention, as they shall deem necessary to perform such inspectional services
of the Village.
   (C)   The duties of the Fire Prevention Coordinator shall be as specified in
the General Orders and Rules and Regulations of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.32 GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES OF FIREFIGHTERS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the officers of the Bureau of Fire Prevention
to enforce all laws and ordinances of the state, county and Village, including
the following:
      (1)   The prevention of fires.
      (2)   The storage and use of explosives and flammables.
      (3)   The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm
systems and fire extinguishing equipment.
      (4)   The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes.
      (5)   The means and adequacy of exits in case of fire from factories,
schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters,
amphitheaters and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or
congregate, from time to time, for any purpose.
      (6)   The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fires.
   (B)   They shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as are
set forth in other sections of this chapter, and as may be conferred and
imposed from time to time by law. The Department Director may delegate any
powers or duties under this section to the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.33 ESTABLISHMENT OF FEE SCHEDULE FOR INSPECTIONS AND SERVICES PERFORMED BY
BUREAU.
   The Bureau of Fire Prevention shall establish a fee schedule for each
inspection, plan review and other service performed after determining a
reasonable charge. The Fire Chief shall from time to time review the fee
schedule and present any amendment to the fee schedule to the Board of Trustees
for approval. Each inspection, plan review or other service performed shall be
billed in accordance with the fee schedule adopted by the Board of Trustees.
All recipients of a service shall be billed in accordance with the policies and
procedures of the Bureau of Fire Prevention and the Village.
(Ord. 19-4197, passed 12-19-19)
§ 32.34 BUREAU TO INVESTIGATE FIRES AND REPORT.
   (A)   The Bureau of Fire Prevention shall investigate the cause, origin and
circumstance of every fire occurring in the Village by which property has been
destroyed or damaged, and so far as possible, shall determine whether the fire
is the result of carelessness or design.
      (1)   The investigations shall begin immediately upon the occurrence of
fire and, if it appears to the officer making the investigation that the fires
are of suspicious origin, the Department Director shall be notified immediately
of the fact.
      (2)   The Department Director shall take charge immediately of the
physical evidence, shall cause notice of the fire to be given to the proper
authorities designated by law to pursue the investigation of the matters, and
shall cooperate further with the authorities in the collection of evidence and
in the prosecution of the case.
   (B)   Every fire shall be reported in writing to the Bureau within two (2)
days after the occurrence of it by the officer in charge. The report shall be
in the form as shall be prescribed by the Department Director and shall contain
a statement of all facts relating to the cause, origin and circumstances of the
fire, the extent of the damage thereof, and the insurance upon the property,
and other information as may be necessary for the enforcement of the laws and
ordinances governing the same and for safeguarding of life and property from
fire.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.35 REQUIRED INSPECTIONS; ORDERS.
   The Department Director and Chief Inspector shall cause inspections to be
made as often as may be necessary, but not less than once a year, of all:
specially hazardous manufacturing processes; storage or installations of
acetylene or other gases, chemicals, oils, explosives and flammable materials;
interior fire alarms and automatic sprinkler systems; otherhazardous conditions
or appliances as they shall designate; industrial buildings; and commercial
buildings, including all restaurants and other places purveying foodstuffs.
Following each such inspection they shall make or cause to be made such orders
as may be necessary for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances governing
the above specified uses and for the safeguarding of public health, life, and
property.
   (A)   As often as may be necessary but not less than once a year, it shall
be the duty of the Chief Inspector to inspect or cause to be inspected by the
Bureau of Fire Prevention, which may be assisted by other members of the Fire
Department, all buildings and premises located within the corporate limits of
the Village, except the interiors of private dwellings, for the purpose of
ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire or
any violations of the provisions or intent of any ordinance of the Village
affecting the fire hazard.
   (B)   When any inspection reveals the existence of combustible or explosive
matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or unnecessary accumulation of
waste paper, boxes, shavings or any highly flammable materials especially
liable to fire in or about any building or upon any other premises, and which
is so situated as to endanger property or shall find obstructions to or upon
fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows, liable to interfere with
the operations of the Fire Department or egress of occupants in case of fire,
the Chief Inspector or any assistant shall order the obstructions to be removed
or remedied, and the order shall be complied with forthwith by the owner or
occupant of the premises or buildings, subject to appeal within twenty-four
(24) hours to the Department Director, as provided in §
32.38.
   (C)   Any owner or occupant failing to comply with the order within a
reasonable period after the service of the order shall be liable to a penalty,
as hereinafter provided.
   (D)   The service of any such order may be made upon the occupant of the
premises to whom it is directed, either by delivering a copy of it to the
occupant personally or by delivering it to and leaving it with any person in
charge of the premises, or in case no such person is found upon the premises,
by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance
of the premises. When it may be necessary to serve such an order upon the owner
of the premises, the order may be served either by delivering to and leaving
with the person a copy of the order or, if the owner is absent from the
jurisdiction of the officer making the order, by mailing the copy to the
owner's last known address.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09)
§ 32.36 GENERAL AUTHORITY INSPECT; ORDERS; APPEALS.
   (A)   The Department Chief or any inspector or inspectors of the Bureau of
Fire Prevention, upon the complaint of any person or whenever any of them shall
deem it necessary, shall inspect all buildings and premises within the
corporate limits of the Village.
   (B)   When any of the inspectors shall find any building or other structure
which, for want of repairs, lack of or insufficient required fire escapes,
automatic or other fire alarm apparatus or fire extinguishing equipment or by
reason of age or dilapidated conditions, or from any other cause, is especially
liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other property or the
occupants thereof, and when any such inspector shall find in any building
combustible or explosive matter or flammable conditions dangerous to the safety
of the building or the occupants thereof, such inspector shall order the
dangerous conditions to be abated and any such dangerous materials to be
removed and the order shall be complied with forthwith by the owner or occupant
of the premises or building.
   (C)   Any person to whom it is directed may appeal any order made by the
Bureau of Fire Prevention to the Department Chief within twenty-four (24) hours
of such order. Within five (5) days, the Department Chief shall review the
order and file a decision thereon. Unless the Department Chief revokes or
modifies it, the order shall remain in full force and be complied with within
the time fixed in the order or any extension thereof granted by the Department
Chief.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.37 OFFICERS' RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   At all reasonable hours, the Department Chief and/or any one (1) or more
inspectors of the Bureau of Fire Prevention may enter any building or premises
within the corporate limits of the Village for the purpose of making any
inspection or investigation which, under the provisions of this chapter, he or
they may deem necessary.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.38 CORPORATION COUNSEL TO ASSIST IN INVESTIGATION.
   Upon request of the Bureau of Fire Prevention and/or the Department Chief,
the Corporation Counsel shall assist the inspectors in the investigation of any
fire that, in their opinion, is of suspicious origin.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.39 RECORD OF FIRES.
   The Department Chief shall keep in the office of the Bureau of Fire
Prevention a record of all fines and of all facts concerning the same,
including statistics as to the extent of the fires and the damage caused
thereby, and whether the losses were covered by insurance and, if so, in what
amount. The record shall be made daily from the reports made by the inspectors
under the provisions of this chapter. All of these records shall be public
records.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§ 32.40 ANNUAL REPORT.
   On or before each April 30, the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall make an
annual report and transmit it to the Department Chief and to the Village
President and Board of Trustees. The report shall contain a summary of all
proceedings undertaken by the Bureau of Fire Prevention during the previous
calendar year and may include the statistics the Bureau of Fire Prevention may
wish to include.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 15-
3009, passed 6-4-15)
§§ 32.41 — 32.70 RESERVED.
RULES OF CONSTRUCTION
AND DEFINITIONS
§ 32.71 CONSTRUCTION; DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   The language in this chapter shall be interpreted in accordance with
the following rules of construction: (i) the word "may" is permissive and the
word "shall" is mandatory; and (ii) except where the context reveals the
contrary: The singular includes the plural and the plural includes the
singular, and the masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   (B)   When used in this chapter, the following words in bold font have the
meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (B), as follows:
   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT- MOBILE INTENSIVE CARE SERVICES. Services provided by
a member of the EMS Bureau wherein communication is established with a hospital
for the performance with the approval of the Illinois Department of Public
Health of pre-hospital emergency medical care by the EMS Bureau under the
direction of a project medical director. Ambulance/paramedic services that
necessitate or result in the implementation of the operating procedures and
guidelines of the then-current EMS systems provider shall be deemed an advanced
life support-mobile intensive care service.
   BASIC LIFE SUPPORT SERVICES. All services provided by the EMS Bureau, other
than those services provided as advanced life support-mobile intensive care
services.
   BATTALION CHIEF/COMMANDER. A sworn officer, taken from the civil service
rank of Fire Department Lieutenant, holding the rank and title of a subordinate
fire chief or commanding officer in the firefighting command structure,
appointed by the Fire Chief with the advice and consent of the Mayor and Board
of Trustees.
   BUREAU OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES or EMS BUREAU. The Village Bureau of
Emergency Medical Services, which shall consist of the EMS Coordinator as well
as other firefighter/ paramedic personnel and may include civilian paramedic
personnel.
   CIVILIAN. An employee of the Fire Department who is hired by the President
and Board of Trustees and not appointed by the Fire and Police Commission.
   CLASSIFIED POSITION. A position held by any employee in the uniformed fire
service as a result of appointment by the Village Fire and Police Commission.
   CLASSIFIED SERVICE. Holding an exempt position or a classified position in
the Fire Department.
   CODE. The New Millennium Code of the Village of Schiller Park, as amended.
   CORPORATION COUNSEL. The Corporation Counsel of the Village.
   DEPARTMENT CHIEF or CHIEF OF THE DEPARTMENT. An exempt position, the holder
of which is the highest ranking sworn firefighter in the Fire Department; who
shall be the Chief of the Fire Department.
   EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES SYSTEMS or (EMS) SYSTEMS. An organization of
providers, which, through a program plan submitted to and approved by the
Illinois Department of Public Health, entitles a hospital to utilize qualified
EMS Bureau personnel to provide or coordinate pre-hospital and inter-hospital
emergency care at an advanced or intermediate level to victims of illness or
injury within the area specified in the program plan.
   EMS COORDINATOR. A position held by a person licensed as a paramedic by the
State of Illinois, and who is a sworn officer holding the ranking of Lieutenant
or higher, who shall be the supervisor of the Bureau of Emergency Medical
Services and operate under the supervision of the Department Chief.
   EXAMINATION. The series of tests prescribed by the Village Fire and Police
Commission to which every applicant for a Classified Position must be subjected
and which each must complete successfully in order to be certified by the Fire
and Police Commission for appointment to a classified position.
   EXEMPT POSITION. A position in the classified service declared hereby
"exempt" from examination and appointment by the Village Fire and Police
Commission and held by a sworn firefighter in the uniformed fire service as a
result of appointment by the Village President, with the understanding the
holder of such exempt position may also hold a classified position if he has
not previously resigned such classified position.
   FIREFIGHTER/PARAMEDIC. The lowest rank in the uniformed fire service.
   FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSION. The Fire and Police Commission of the Village.
   FIRE CHIEF or CHIEF OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT. A member of the uniformed fire
service who is Chief of the Fire Department, an exempt position, and who shall
be deemed to be on furlough from the classified position held by such member so
long as such member is the Department Chief.
   FIRE DEPARTMENT or DEPARTMENT. The Village Fire Department.
   NON-CLASSIFIED SERVICE. Any civilian who is hired by the President and Board
of Trustees for service other than as a sworn firefighter.
   OATH OF OFFICE. Every person appointed as a sworn firefighter shall take and
sign the following oath, which may be administered by the Village Clerk or any
member of the Fire and Police Commission or the Village President:
   “I                       , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support
the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of
Illinois and the ordinances of the Village of Schiller Park as well as the
rules of the Department, and that I will faithfully perform the duties of the
Position of             of the Village of Schiller Park, Illinois, according to
the best of my ability.
      Signed:
      Witness:      ”
   POSITION. A defined office, occupation, or place within the employment of
the Fire Department. See also CLASSIFIED POSITION and EXEMPT POSITION.
   PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and Board of Trustees of the
Village.
   PROBATION. The testing of a person's on-the-job conduct and performance in
and suitability for a given classified position undertaken over a period of
time, commencing with his appointment to such classified position.
   PROBATIONARY PERIOD. The time period of probation immediately following an
employee's original appointment, during which time period such employee can be
dismissed without a hearing before the Fire and Police Commission.
   SWORN FIREFIGHTER. The Chief of the Fire Department and all members of the
classified service who have executed the prescribed oath of office.
   UNIFORMED FIRE SERVICE. Other than those holding an exempt position or a
position, those persons in the employ of the Village who meet the definition of
a "firefighter" under the provisions of Section 4-106 of the Illinois Pension
Fund Act.
   VILLAGE. The Village of Schiller Park, an Illinois municipal corporation and
Home Rule Unit as described in the Illinois Constitution.
   VILLAGE PRESIDENT. Also known as "Mayor", the Village President of the
Village.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 12-
2892, passed 5-22-12; Am. Ord. 15-3009, passed 6-4-15)
§§ 32.72 — 32.72 — 32.90 RESERVED.
TECHNICAL RESCUE SERVICE FEES; SPECIALIZED RESCUE SERVICE FEES; AND HAZARDOUS
MATERIAL LEAKS AND SPILLS REQUIRING REIMBURSEMENT
§ 32.91 TECHNICAL RESCUE SERVICE FEES.
   (A)   The Village shall fix, charge and collect reasonable fees for
technical rescue services provided by the Fire Department. The total amount
collected may not exceed the reasonable cost of providing the technical rescue
services and will include charges for personnel and equipment costs.
Reimbursement for the reasonable fees incurred for technical rescue services
shall include but not be limited to any and all personnel cost and the
replacement and/or repair costs incurred by the Village for equipment and
materials used, damaged, lost, spent, destroyed or rendered irreparable in
connection with a technical rescue services provided.
   (B)   The Fire Department shall prepare and forward to the person or entity
causing a technical rescue service response a bill for the total costs and
expenses incurred for which such person is responsible pursuant to this
section; provided, however, any cost in connection with any independent cleanup
contractor shall be billed directly by such contractor. Payment of the total
bill shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt. Any bill or portion of a
bill remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days of receipt shall accrue interest
on the unpaid balance at the rate of two (2) percent per month. Any uncollected
portion of the bill not paid after ninety (90) days will be forwarded to the
Village’s collection agency. If more than one person or entity requires such
technical rescue services, each shall be jointly or jointly and severally
liable for all costs of the technical rescue services.
(Ord. 19-4184, passed 10-9-19)
§ 32.92 SPECIALIZED RESCUE SERVICES FEES.
   (A)   Notwithstanding any other provision or rule of law, the Village shall
fix, charge and collect reasonable fees for specialized rescue services
provided by the Fire Department. The following persons or entities shall be
jointly or jointly and severally liable for all costs of the specialized rescue
services, as set forth herein:
      (1)   The owner of the property on which the specialized rescue services
occurred;
      (2)   Any person involved in an activity that caused or contributed to
the emergency;
      (3)   In cases involving the rescue or recovery of an individual, the
individual and his/her employer, if the person was acting in furtherance of the
employer’s interest; or
      (4)   In cases involving the recovery of property, the owner of the
property or any person having control or custody of the property at the time of
the emergency.
   (B)   Any party described in subsection (A) of this section causing a
specialized rescue service emergency response by a rescue team in a structural
collapse rescue, tactical rescue, high angle rescue, underwater rescue and
recovery, confined space rescue, below grade rescue or trench rescue who has
been determined by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration or
Illinois Department of Labor to be at fault, shall be responsible for and
assume all liability for all of the following:
      (1)   Reimbursement in full for any and all costs incurred by the Village
in connection with the operation, maintenance and staffing required to respond
to such specialized rescue incident at the rate based upon ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5,
§ 11-6-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code in effect at the time of the incident,
regardless of residence status, at the maximum rate per hour, per vehicle,
rounded up to the next full hour, including back-fill overtime costs, for each
employee who participates in such response to a specialized rescue incident
including any assisting governmental agencies and private contractors.
      (2)   Reimbursement in full for any and all replacement and/or repair
costs incurred by the Village for equipment and materials used, damaged, lost,
spent, destroyed or rendered irreparable in connection with a specialized
rescue incident.
      (3)   Assumption of any and all liability and the costs for any cleanup
or removal resulting from a specialized rescue incident including but not
limited to any independent cleanup contractor necessitated by such specialized
rescue incident.
      (4)   Any administrative costs generated in conjunction with an expense
recovery.
      (5)   The Fire Department shall prepare and forward to the person or
persons causing or permitting a specialized rescue response or any person set
forth in subsection (A) of this section, a bill for the total costs and
expenses incurred for which such person is responsible pursuant to this
section; provided, however, any cost in connection with any independent cleanup
contractor shall be billed directly by such contractor. Payment of the total
bill shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt. Any bill or portion of a
bill remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days of receipt shall accrue interest
on the unpaid balance at the rate of two (2) percent per month. Any uncollected
portion of the bill not paid after ninety (90) days will be forwarded to the
Village's collection agency.
(Ord. 19-4184, passed 10-9-19)
§ 32.93 REIMBURSEMENT FOR COSTS, EXPENSES AND FEES INVOLVED IN A HAZARDOUS
MATERIALS RESPONSE.
   (A)   Definition of words and phrases. The following words and phrases when
used in this section shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them,
except when the context otherwise requires and except where another definition
is set forth and applicable to that term or a designated part thereof.
      COSTS. All expenses incurred by the Village or by another emergency
response agency for any removal, mitigation or remedial action required or
determined necessary, rounded up to the next full hour. The cost of Village
vehicles shall not be less than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per
hour per vehicle. The cost of Village personnel, including overtime cost to the
Village, incurred as a result of the removal or remediation action shall be no
less than seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour. The full cost of all materials and
equipment used, expended, depleted, destroyed, replaced or removed from service
as a result of a response shall be reimbursed to the Village. Cost of vehicles,
equipment, personnel or other services or goods provided by an independent
contractor or other emergency response agency shall be that as reasonably
determined by said contractor or other emergency response agency.
      FACILITY. Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or
pipeline including but not limited to any pipe into a sewer or publicly owned
treatment works, well, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill, storage
container, tank, motor vehicle, truck trailer, rolling stock or aircraft. Also,
any site or area where a hazardous material has been deposited, stored,
disposed of, abandoned, placed, or otherwise come to be located.
      HAZARDOUS MATERIALS. Any material, substance or mixture of materials or
substances which are toxic, flammable, corrosive, explosive, carcinogenic or
radioactive including, but not limited to, any substance or material which is
designated a hazardous material pursuant to the “Hazardous Materials
Transportation Act” (49 U.S.C.A. §§ 1801 et seq.) or as defined in ILCS Ch.
415, Act 5, §§ 1 et seq., in a quantity and form which may pose a substantial
present or potential hazard to human health, property or the environment when
improperly released, treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise
managed.
      PERSON. Any individual, business, firm, partnership, corporation,
association, trust, estate, joint venture or other legal entity, or their legal
representative, agent or assign.
      RELEASE. Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, escaping,
emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping or disposing of a hazardous
material into or on any land, air, water, well, stream, sewer or pipe so that
such hazardous material or any constituent thereof may enter the environment.
      REMEDIAL ACTION. Any action consistent with permanent remedy taken
instead of or in addition to removal actions in the event of a release or
threatened release of a hazardous material into the environment, to prevent or
minimize the release of hazardous materials so that they do not migrate to
cause a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property or
the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, such actions at the
location of the release as storage, confinement, perimeter protection using
dikes, trenches, or ditches, clay cover, neutralization, cleanup of released
hazardous materials or contaminated materials, recycling or reuse, diversion,
destruction, segregation of reactive wastes, repair or replacement of leaking
containers, collection of leachate and runoff, onsite treatment or
incineration, provision of alternate water supplies, and any monitoring
reasonably required to assure that such actions protect the public health and
welfare and the environment.
      REMOVAL. The cleanup or removal of released hazardous materials from the
environment, such actions as may be necessary or appropriate to monitor,
assess, and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous materials,
the disposal of removed material, or the taking of such action as may be
necessary to prevent, minimize, or mitigate damage to the public health or
welfare or the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, security
fencing, provision of alternative water supplies, and temporary evacuation of
threatened individuals.
      RESPONSE. Any removal or remedial action.
   (B)   Prohibited acts. No person shall cause, threaten or allow the release
of hazardous materials into the environment unless such release is in
accordance with an appropriate permit granted by the Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency or other state or federal agency having primary jurisdiction
over the release but only to the extent that such release is made in accordance
with all applicable laws, regulations and permit requirements and in such place
or manner as to not create a substantial present or potential hazard to human
health, property or the environment.
   (C)   Response authority.
      (1)   The Chief of the Fire Department or his or her authorized
representative shall have authority to respond to any release or threatened
release of hazardous materials within the Village or affecting any public
utility of the Village or in response for assistance by or to aid any other
emergency response agency, department or authorized requesting authority. This
authority includes, but is not limited to, remedial action and removal.
      (2)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have primary authority to
respond to any release or threatened release of hazardous materials as
described above. The Chief of the Fire Department or his or her authorized
representative shall report any release or threatened release of hazardous
materials to all appropriate federal. State and local public health, safety and
emergency agencies of any substantial release of hazardous materials, as
required by law.
      (3)   The Chief of the Fire Department or his or her authorized
representative, during such time as response authority is vested in said
individual, shall be authorized to utilize all Village personnel and equipment
and take such remedial or removal action as may be deemed necessary or
appropriate to respond to the release or threatened release of hazardous
materials.
      (4)   The Village, its agents, officers and employees, and the Chief of
the Fire Department shall not have any liability or responsibility for any
claim, injury, or damage of any kind resulting from a release or threatened
release of hazardous materials to which the Village or any of its departments,
officers, agents, or employees or the Chief of the Fire Department respond.
   (D)   Liability for costs. Notwithstanding any other provision or rule of
law, and subject only to the defenses set forth in this section, the following
persons shall be jointly and severally liable for all costs of removal and
remedial action incurred by the Village as a result of a release or threatened
release of a hazardous material:
      (1)   The owner and operator of a facility or vessel from which there is
a release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous material;
      (2)   Any person who, at the time of disposal, transport, storage or
treatment of a hazardous material, owned or operated the facility or vessel
used for such disposal, transport, treatment or storage from which there was a
release or substantial threat of a release of any such hazardous material;
      (3)   Any person who by contract, agreement, or otherwise has arranged
with another party or entity for transport, storage, disposal or treatment of
hazardous materials owned, controlled or possessed by such person at a facility
owned or operated by another party or entity from which facility there is a
release or substantial threat of a release of such hazardous materials;
      (4)   Any person who accepts or accepted any hazardous materials for
transport to disposal, storage or treatment facilities or sites from which
there is a release or a substantial threat of a release of a hazardous
material.
      There shall be no liability under this subchapter for a person otherwise
liable who can establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the release or
substantial threat of release of a hazardous material and the resulting damages
occurred under one of the permitted defenses set forth in ILCS Ch. 415, Act 5,
§ 22.2(j).
      The Fire Department shall prepare and forward to the person or entity a
bill for the total costs and expenses incurred for which such person is a
recipient of or responsible for the response; provided, however, any cost in
connection with any independent cleanup contractor shall be billed directly by
such contractor. Payment of the total bill shall be made within thirty (30)
days of receipt. Any bill or portion of a bill remaining unpaid after thirty
(30) days of receipt shall accrue interest on the unpaid balance at the rate of
two (2) percent per month. Any uncollected portion of the bill not paid after
ninety (90) days will be forwarded to the Village's collection agency. If more
than one (1) person or entity is involved, each shall be jointly or jointly and
severally liable for all costs incurred by the Village.
   (E)   Failure to take remedial action. In addition to any other remedy
provided herein or in law, any person who is liable for the release or
threatened release of a hazardous material who fails without sufficient cause
to pay for or provide removal or remedial action upon or in accordance with a
notice and request of the response authority, or in accordance with any order
of any court having jurisdiction of the matter, shall be liable to the Village
for any costs incurred by the Village as a result of such failure to provide or
take such removal or remedial action, together with the cost of any removal or
remedial action taken by the Village in accordance with this section. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day on which a violation
occurs and continues.
   (F)   Contractual indemnification; subrogation. No conveyance, transfer,
sale, indemnification, hold harmless, or similar agreement shall be effective
to release the owner or operator of any facility or vessel or any person who
may be liable for a release or threat of release under this section from the
liability imposed under this section. Nothing herein shall bar any agreement to
insure, hold harmless or indemnify a party to such agreement for any liability
under this section. Nothing in this section shall bar a cause of action that an
owner or operator or any other person subject to liability under this section,
or a guarantor, has or would have, by reason of subrogation or otherwise
against any person.
(Ord. 19-4184, passed 10-9-19)
§ 32.94 CALL IN SEPARATE, INDEPENDENT OR SPECIALIZED SERVICE.
   In the event that the Chief of the Fire Department, or his or her authorized
representative, deems it necessary, said individual shall be authorized to call
in a separate, independent or specialized service, including but not limited to
a clean-up contractor.
(Ord. 19-2184, passed 10-9-19)
§§ 32.95 — 32.98 RESERVED.
PENALTY
§ 32.99 FINE.
   (A)    Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity who violates any
provision of this chapter for which another penalty is not specifically
provided shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding seven
hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day a violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity violating any of the
provisions of §§
32.30 through
32.43, or neglecting to comply with any order issued pursuant to any section
thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined
up to seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense and, in
addition thereto, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each day the violation is permitted to exist beyond a reasonable period after
service, as provided in that subchapter.
   (C)   Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity that refuses to pay or
fails to pay any of the charges listed in §§
32.91 through
32.94 within sixty (60) days of the notice of the charge, will be deemed to
have violated this chapter and will incur a fine of not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each offense, plus all legal fees and all costs caused by enforcement. Such
fees and costs shall include, but not be limited to, attorneys' fees and the
cost of collection. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day
on which a violation occurs and continues. In addition to any other remedy
provided herein or in law, any person, firm, corporation, or other entity
guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of §§
32.91 through
32.94 shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed for each day on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 08-2677, passed 5-27-08; Am. Ord. 09-2717, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 19-
2184, passed 10-9-19)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 33.01 ESTABLISHED; PERSONNEL.
   (A)   There hereby is established a Police Department, an executive
department. The Classified Service of the Department shall include such members
in number and rank as may be provided for from time to time by an ordinance
amending subsection (B) of this section, adopted by the President and Board of
Trustees. In addition, the Non-Classified Service of the Department shall
include such Civilian clerks, and radio and communication personnel; Auxiliary
Police Officers; and other Civilians and employees as the President and Board
of Trustees may provide by adoption of the annual Village budget.
   (B)   All members holding Classified Positions shall be appointed by the
Fire and Police Commission and shall be subject to the rules of the Fire and
Police Commission. The Classified Service of the Police Department shall be
comprised of lieutenants*, sergeants, patrolmen or patrolwomen, and such other
members all as may be authorized from time to time by the President and Board
of Trustees.
*   See §
33.20 (“Director of Police”) and see §
33.21 (“Deputy Chief of Police”) for the creation and rank reversion
specifications.
   (C)   All Civilian members of the Non-Classified Service shall be hired by
the Village President or the duly authorized agent of the Village President.
Auxiliary Police Officers and persons holding Civilian Positions and Exempt
Positions shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and
consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Village President is
authorized hereby to appoint the number of Auxiliary Police Officers, as
employees of the Village in the Non-Classified Service of the Police
Department, as the Village President may deem necessary to serve the law
enforcement needs of the Village. The appointment of any or all Auxiliary
Police Officers appointed hereunder shall be for the one (1) year and may be
terminated, at any time with or without cause, by the Village President.
   (D)   Upon appointment, all Sworn Police Officers shall execute the
prescribed Oath of Office before entering upon their respective duties.
('73 Code, § 27-16) (Ord. 91-1788, passed 11-7-91; Am. Ord. 93-1842, passed 7-
13-93; Am. Ord. 94-1896, passed 11-22-94; Am. Ord. 97-2070, passed 7-8-97; Am.
Ord. 00-2242, passed 8-17-00; Am. Ord. 01-2284, passed 6-26-01; Am. Ord. 01-
2301, passed 12-11-01; Am. Ord. 02-2366, passed 9-24-02; Am. Ord. 03-2445,

passed 10-20-22)
§ 33.02 DUTIES.
   (A)   Classified Service. It shall be the duty of all Sworn Police Officers
to see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the Village and all statutes, to
obey the lawful orders of their superiors, and to preserve peace and prevent
infractions of the law. Every Sworn Police Officer is hereby declared to be a
Conservator of the Peace and shall have all of the powers of a police officer,
including the power (i) to arrest or cause to be arrested, with or without
process, all persons who break the peace or are found violating any municipal
ordinance or any criminal law of the State, (ii) to commit arrested persons for
examination, (iii) if necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody
overnight or Sunday in any safe place or until they can be brought before the
proper court, and (iv) to exercise all other powers as Conservators of the
Peace prescribed from time to time by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Non-Classified Service.
      (1)   Civilians who are not Auxiliary Police Officers and who are not
holding Civilian Positions may be hired from time to time by the Village
President to undertake clerical work in accordance with orders given by the
Chief of Police, including but not limited to dispatching and secretarial
tasks.
      (2)   Although they shall be supervised by Village employees in the
Classified Service pursuant to orders given by the Chief of Police or his duly
authorized agents, Auxiliary Police Officers shall not be members of the
regular Police Department and shall not supplement members of the regular
Police Department. Auxiliary Police Officers shall not have Conservator of the
Peace powers and shall only be assigned to perform the following duties: (i) to
aid or direct traffic within the Village; (ii) to aid in control of natural or
manmade disasters; and (iii) to aid in case of civil disorder as directed by a
Village employee holding a Position in the Classified Service. When it is
impractical for members of the regular Police Department to perform those
normal and regular police duties, the Chief of Police may assign Auxiliary
Police Officers to perform those normal and regular police duties.
('73 Code, § 27-17) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-89; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-
9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11)
Cross-reference:
   Aid in enforcement of electrical provisions, see § 50.05
§ 33.03 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   When appointed, all Auxiliary Police Officers shall reside within the
boundaries of Leyden Township and shall continue such residence throughout his
or her term as an Auxiliary Police Officer.
   (B)   Except as set forth in this subsection, all members of the Classified
Service of the Police Department shall reside within the following Area of
Residency: The territory bounded on the north and the east by the Illinois
state line, on the south by Interstate 80, and on the west by Illinois State
Route 47.
      (1)   Within 180 days of the successful completion of his probationary
period, an appointee to a position in the Classified Service of the Police
Department shall reside in the above-described Area of Residency.
      (2)   In the event the above-described Area of Residency is modified by
an ordinance amending this subsection (B), adopted by the President and Board
of Trustees, all members of the Classified Service of the Police Department
shall comply therewith within twelve (12) months of the date of such adoption.
('73 Code, § 27-20) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 81-1448, passed 5-
21-81; Am. Ord. 90-1740, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 94-1886, passed 7-12-94; Am.
