2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 22-4317, passed 5-19-22)
§ 33.04 UNIFORMS OF SWORN POLICE OFFICERS AND EQUIPMENT.
   Identification symbols worn by Auxiliary Police Officers shall be different
and distinct from those used by the members of the Classified Service of the
Police Department and shall be chosen by the Chief of Police. In addition,
Auxiliary Police Officers shall not carry firearms unless they have completed a
40-Hour Mandatory Firearms Training Course as specified in ILCS Ch. 50, Act
710, § 2, and then any given Auxiliary Police Officer may carry a firearm only
when in uniform and in the performance of his duty, provided the Chief of
Police has first given his permission to such Auxiliary Police Officer to carry
a firearm.
('73 Code, § 27-21) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-89; Am. Ord. 87-1666, passed 9-
21-87; Am. Ord. 95-1918, passed 4-11-95; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am.
Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11)
§ 33.05 DISCHARGES.
   (A)   Other than a person holding a Classified Position who has not
completed the term of his Probationary Period, no one holding a Classified
Position shall be discharged from the Police Department, except after a hearing
on charges before the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners as provided by
law; provided, this shall not be construed as affecting the power of the
Village President and Board of Trustees to appoint and remove persons from
Civilian Positions and Exempt Positions.
   (B)   Any member of the Classified Service who has not completed the term of
his Probationary Period, any persons holding Civilian Positions or Exempt
Positions, and any member of the Non-Classified Service may be discharged from
the employ of the Village at any time, with or without cause, by the Village
President or the duly authorized agent of the Village President.
('73 Code, § 27-23) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-
9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07)
§ 33.06 COMPENSATION.
   All members of the Police Department shall be paid as provided from time to
time by the Village President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07)
§ 33.07 CONDUCT OF MEMBERS.
   It shall be the duty of every member of the Police Department to conduct
himself in a proper and law- abiding manner and to avoid the use of unnecessary
force.
('73 Code, § 27-27) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-
9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07)
§ 33.08 SERVICE OF PROCESS.
   No member of the Police Department shall serve any process except on order
of the Chief of Police.
('73 Code, § 27-26) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-
9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11)
§ 33.09 DUTY TO APPEAR AS WITNESS.
   (A)   Each member of the Police Department shall appear as a witness
whenever this is necessary in the prosecution for a violation of an ordinance
or of any state or federal law. No member shall retain any witness fee for the
service as witness in any action or suit to which the Village is a party. Any
fees for such service shall be forwarded to the Chief of Police who shall
deposit them with the Village Treasurer.
   (B)   Each member of the Police Department shall appear for and honor civil
subpoenas for oral depositions in any civil action where testimony of the
member is sought. For those oral depositions in cases where the Village is not
a party, the depositions of members of the Police Department shall be conducted
at the Village Hall during the deponent's regularly scheduled shift, unless an
order of court provides otherwise. The member shall forward any fees for such
service to the Chief of Police who shall deposit them with the Village
Treasurer.
   (C)   Upon receipt of a subpoena, the member shall immediately forward a
copy of the subpoena to the Chief of Police who shall forward a copy to the
Corporation Counsel's office. The Chief of Police or the Corporation Counsel
shall promptly notify the party who caused the issuance of the subpoena about
the existence of this ordinance.
('73 Code, § 27-28) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-
9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 07-2650, passed 11-13-07; Am.
Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11)
§ 33.10 PART-TIME POLICE.
   (A)   Employment. The Village of Schiller Park may employ part-time police
officers from time to time, as they deem necessary.
   (B)   Duties. A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities
of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the
General Orders of the Schiller Park Police Department, but the number of hours
a part-time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part-time
police officers should not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time police
officers. Part-time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the
Illinois Police Training Act (50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.) and the rules and
requirements of the ILETSB.
   (C)   Hiring Standards. Any person employed, as a part-time police officer,
must meet the following standards:
      (1)   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health
and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
      (2)   Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age.
      (3)   Pass a medical examination.
      (4)   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
      (5)   Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license.
      (6)   Possess no prior felony convictions.
      (7)   Any individual whom has served in the United States military must
have been honorably discharged.
   (D)   Discipline. Part-time officers shall be under the disciplinary
jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part-time police officers serve at the
discretion of the Village authorities, shall not have any property rights in
said employment and may be removed by Village authorities at any time. Part-
time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and General orders
issued by the Police Department.
(Ord. 13-2932, passed 6-25-13)
§ 33.11 LATERAL APPOINTMENT OF CERTIFIED POLICE OFFICERS.
   The process of lateral appointment of police officers by the Village
President is established as a method of recruiting experienced police officers
from other Illinois jurisdictions who have obtained and maintained Illinois
peace officer training and certification.
   (A)   The Director of Police or Police Chief shall advertise for
applications from police officer candidates and shall establish a list of
eligible lateral appointment candidates based on the criteria set forth in this
Section. At a minimum, a police officer candidate for lateral appointment must:
      (1)   Possess a full-time Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards
Board ("ILETSB") police officer certification;
      (2)   Have previously been a full-time sworn officer of a regular police
department in any municipal, county, or State law enforcement agency;
      (3)   Have been with his or her respective law enforcement agency within
the State for at least two (2) years;
      (4)   Be at least 23 years old and a U.S. citizen at the time of
appointment;
      (5)   Possess a valid Class "D" Illinois driver's license in good
standing or a valid out-of-state driver's license of similar classification in
good standing;
      (6)   Have no felony convictions or misdemeanor convictions involving
moral turpitude, be of excellent moral character, and not be under
investigation by current department; and
      (7)   Have completed 60 college credit hours from an accredited college
or university at the time of application, or must have served 24 months of
active duty or 180 days of combat duty in the United States Armed Forces as
designated by the Department of Defense, and have not been discharged under
circumstances other than honorable.
   (B)   In addition, as with candidates for appointment under the rules of the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, candidates being considered for lateral
appointment shall be evaluated based on the following criteria;
      (1)   The results of a thorough background investigation;
      (2)   The results of an oral interview and examination;
      (3)   The results of a physical examination;
      (4)   The results of a medical evaluation, including a psychological
evaluation and drug screening;
      (5)   The results of a polygraph examination; and
      (6)   Evidence that the candidates for appointment under this procedure
meet the minimum qualifications for appointment to the position of police
officer as may, from time to time, be enforced for candidates who participate
in the competitive Board of Fire and Police Commissioners hiring process,
including the requirement that candidates must be under the age of 36 years old
at the time of placement on the eligibility list for lateral appointment. The
age limit in this Section does not apply if the candidate (a) was previously
employed as a police officer in a municipality and is under age 40 at the time
of application; (b) served as an auxiliary police officer for at least five (5)
years and is under age 40 at the time of application; (c) served as a sheriffs
deputy and meets the applicable training requirements and is under age 40 at
time of application; or (d) served as a sworn officer of the Illinois State
Police and is under age 40 at the time of application.
   (C)   All candidates shall undergo the same evaluation/testing process based
on the criteria set forth above and as recommended by the Director of Police or
Police Chief and the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. Once the
evaluations are completed, the Director of Police or Police Chief, in
collaboration with the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, shall rank all
eligible candidates for lateral appointment, based on the results of the
candidate-evaluation criteria and any applicable preference points under State
law, on a list which shall be valid for two (2) years from the date of
establishment. The Director of Police or Police Chief shall transmit a copy of
the original lateral-appointment eligibility list to the Village President and
the Chairman of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, and make copies of
the eligibility list available to others upon request. Any candidate on the
original lateral appointment eligibility list who fails to maintain his or her
full-time ILETSB police-officer certification shall be automatically stricken
from the list.
   (D)   When a vacancy for the position of police officer exists, the Director
of Police or Police Chief shall consult with the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners on eligible candidates, after which the Director of Police or
Police Chief may recommend the appointment of a candidate to the Village
President. The Village President, at his or her sole discretion, may draw from
the lateral appointment eligibility list as needed for any vacancy. In the
event that the selection process identifies lateral applicants who have certain
knowledge, skills, and abilities that make those applicants more desirable for
the position sought to be filled, the Village President may choose to recommend
appointment of those applicants.
   (E)   Seniority for police officers appointed under this Section for all
matters other than salary shall be determined based on the date of hire as a
full-time sworn police officer for the Village.
   (F)   Police officers appointed under this Section shall receive
compensation at a rate in accordance with the applicable collective-bargaining
agreement in effect on the date of hire.
   (G)   Police officers appointed under this Section shall be required to
successfully complete a field-training program and 18-month probation period,
in accordance with the applicable collective-bargaining agreement in effect on
the date of hire.
(Ord. 21-4294, passed 9-16-21)
ADMINISTRATION
§ 33.20 DIRECTOR OF POLICE.
   There is created hereby the office of Director of Police, an administrative
civilian position exempt from appointment by the Village Fire and Police
Commission. The Director of Police shall be deemed a confidential supervisory
position appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees. The Director of Police shall be appointed annually, or
portion thereof, but may continue thereafter until such time as a successor is
duly qualified. The Village President is authorized to suspend or discharge the
Director of Police with or without cause. The Director of Police shall receive
such compensation as will be fixed by the President and Board of Trustees. The
Director of Police shall not make written application to the Village Police
Pension Board to qualify to come under the provisions of Article 3 of the
Police Pension Fund.
   (A)   The Director of Police shall be qualified through training and
experience to advise and oversee the Police Department. The Director of Police
shall not have powers of arrest and shall not be required to carry a firearm,
but may do so if authorized in accordance with the law.
   (B)   To the extent that it is consistent with the duties of the Director of
Police as set forth herein, any references in this Code to the “Chief of
Police” or “Police Chief” shall mean and refer to the “Director of Police.” In
all other cases required by law, any reference to “Chief of Police” or “Police
Chief” shall hereinafter mean and refer to the Deputy Chief of Police.
('73 Code, § 27-18) (Ord. 81-1448, passed 5-21-81; Am. Ord. 89-1721, passed 10-
5-89; Am. Ord. 93-1832, passed 6-8-93; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am.
Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11; Am. Ord. 16-
3047, passed 4-21-16; Am. Ord. 17-4029, passed 11-2-17; Am. Ord. 18-4092,
passed 9-6-18)
§ 33.21 DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE.
   There is created hereby the office of Deputy Chief of Police, a Civilian
Position exempt from appointment by the Village Fire and Police Commission. The
Deputy Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Director of Police. The Deputy
Chief of Police shall be selected from the rank of lieutenant, provided such
officer has at least ten (10) years of full time service as a police officer
within the department. The Deputy Chief of Police shall serve at the discretion
of the Director of Police and, if removed, shall revert to the rank held
immediately prior to appointment as Deputy Chief of Police.
   The Deputy Chief of Police shall provide those services as required or
directed by the Director of Police. In the event there is a vacancy in the
office of Director of Police or in the event the Director of Police is
incapacitated or otherwise not able to perform the duties of the office, the
Deputy Chief of Police shall have the same administrative powers and duties
generally as that of the Director of Police, during any vacancy in that office
or during the incapacity of the Director of Police. The Deputy Chief of Police
shall possess such administrative powers and duties until such time as the
vacancy in the office of Director of Police is filled, or until such time as
the Director of Police is no longer incapacitated. Compensation for the Deputy
Chief of Police shall be established from time to time by the President and
Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 17-4029, passed 11-2-17; Am. Ord. 18-4092, passed 9-6-18)
§ 33.22 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR OF POLICE AND THE DEPUTY CHIEF OF
POLICE.
   All authorities granted the Director of Police by State statute shall apply
to the Director of Police. The Director of Police shall be responsible for the
direction and performance of all Police Department functions including all
police personnel of the Village, whether members of the Classified Service or
members of the Non-Classified Service. The Director of Police is required to
ensure the efficient operation of the Police Department, and all members of the
Police Department shall obey the orders, rules and regulations given or set by
the Director of Police for the conduct and guidance of the members of the
Police Department. In addition:
   (A)   All police records and original reports shall be preserved and
maintained pursuant to the direction of the office of the Director of Police
and shall be made available to the public only as duly authorized by State
statute.
   (B)   The Deputy Chief of Police shall be the keeper of the Village Jail and
shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein.
      (1)   Until a person shall be brought before a judge for a hearing or
until a person shall be transferred lawfully to some other place of
incarceration or until a person shall be otherwise lawfully released, the
Village Jail may be used only for the incarceration of a person arrested for
violating any law of any state or the United States or for violating any
Village ordinance.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to escape, attempt to escape or
to assist any prisoner to escape or attempt to escape from the Village Jail.
      (3)   It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate with any
prisoner held in the Village Jail without the permission of the Deputy Chief of
Police or the police officer in charge.
   (C)   The Director of Police shall keep such records and make such reports
concerning the activities of the Police Department as may be required by
federal, State or local law or Village ordinance.
   (D)   Civilian personnel of the Non-Classified Service:
      (1)   Shall have the work hours and assume the duties set forth by the
Director of Police.
      (2)   Shall have the compensation and time off for the holidays
designated by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (E)   The Director of Police shall have custody of all lost, abandoned or
stolen property recovered by the Village.
('73 Code, § 27-19) (Ord. 79-1362, passed 7-27-79; Am. Ord. 81-1448, passed 5-
21-81; Am. Ord. 90-1730, passed 1-18-90; Am. Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am.
Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-2816, passed 1-25-11; Am. Ord. 17-
4029, passed 11-2-17; Am. Ord. 18-4092, passed 9-6-18)
POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
§ 33.60 ESTABLISHED.
   There shall be a Police Pension Fund Board of Trustees consisting of five
members. Of these members, two shall be appointed by the Village President; two
shall be elected from the regular police force of the Village and one shall be
elected from the beneficiaries of the Fund. Each member shall serve for two
years and elected members shall be selected in the manner provided by law.
('73 Code, § 28-1) (Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-
23-07)
§ 33.61 DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Pension Fund Board of
Trustees to manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all money
pertaining thereto in the manner provided by statute.
('73 Code, § 28-2) (Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-
23-07)
RULES OF CONSTRUCTION AND DEFINITIONS
§ 33.70 CONSTRUCTION; DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   The language in this Chapter shall be interpreted in accordance with
the following rules of construction: (a) The word "may" is permissive and the
word "shall" is mandatory; and (b) except where the context reveals the
contrary: The singular includes the plural and the plural includes the
singular, and the masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   (B)   When used in this Chapter, the following words shall have the
following meanings:
      AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS. Sworn Police Officers in the Non-Classified
Service.
         CIVILIAN. A non-appointed employee of the Police Department who is
hired by the Village President for Non-Classified Service.
      CIVILIAN POSITION. A Position held by a Sworn Police Officer not in the
Uniformed Police Service but holding, without Examination, a Position in the
Classified Service as a result of appointment by the Village President, which
Position is declared hereby "exempt" from Examination and appointment by the
Village Fire and Police Commission.
      CLASSIFIED POSITION. Any employee who is a Sworn Police Officer in the
Uniformed Police Service as a result of Appointment by the Village Fire and
Police Commission.
      CLASSIFIED SERVICE. Persons holding a Civilian Position, an Exempt
Position, or a Classified Position.
      CONSERVATOR OF THE PEACE. Provided they have each received a certificate
attesting to the successful completion of a training course administered by the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board: The Village President,
Village Trustees, and Sworn Police Officers.
      DEPUTY POLICE CHIEF. An appointee from the rank of lieutenant of the
Police Department, the holder of which shall serve at the discretion of the
Director of Police.
      DIRECTOR OF POLICE. A civilian qualified through training and experience
to advise and oversee the Police Department.
      EXAMINATION. The series of tests prescribed by the Village Fire and
Police Commission to which every applicant for a Classified Position must be
subjected and which each must complete successfully in order to be certified by
the Commission for appointment to a Classified Position.
      EXEMPT POSITION. A Sworn Police Officer in the Uniformed Police Service
holding,  without Examination, a Position created in this Chapter in the
Classified Service as a result of appointment by the Village President, and
declared hereby "exempt" from Examination and appointment by the Village Fire
and Police Commission.
      JAIL. The place in the Village heretofore established and used as the
jail, or any other place which hereafter may be used for that purpose, hereby
is declared to be the Village jail.
      NON-CLASSIFIED SERVICE. Any Civilian who is hired, or any person who is
appointed as an Auxiliary Police Officer, by the Village President and
rendering service as a Civilian or Auxiliary Police Officer, as the case may
be, in accordance with the rules of the Police Department and the Village
Ordinances.
      OATH OF OFFICE. Every person appointed as a Sworn Police Officer shall
take and sign the following oath, which may be administered by the Village
Clerk or any member of the Fire and Police Commission or the Village President:
         "I                         , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will
support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State
of Illinois and the ordinances of the Village of Schiller Park as well as the
rules of the Department, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the
Position of                    of the Village of Schiller Park, Illinois,
according to the best of my ability.
            Signed:
            Witness:                   "
      ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT. Designation by the Village Fire and Police
Commission of a person to the lowest ranking office in the Uniformed Police
Service.
      POLICE DEPARTMENT or DEPARTMENT. The Village Police Department.
      POSITION. A defined office, occupation, or place within the employment of
the Police Department.
      PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and Board of Trustees of
the Village.
      PROBATION. The testing of a person's on-the-job conduct and performance
in and suitability for a given Classified Position undertaken over a period of
time, commencing with his appointment to such Classified Position.
      PROBATIONARY PERIOD. The time period of Probation immediately following
an Employee's Original Appointment, during which time period such Employee can
be dismissed without a hearing before the Commission.
      SWORN POLICE OFFICER. The Chief of Police, all members of the Classified
Service of the Police Department and all Auxiliary Police Officers who have
executed the prescribed Oath of Office.
      UNIFORMED POLICE SERVICE. Those Sworn Police Officers, other than those
holding a Civilian Position or a Position as an Auxiliary Police Officer, who
meet the definition of a "Police Officer" under the provisions of Section 3-106
of the Illinois Police Pension Fund Act.
      VILLAGE. The Village of Schiller Park, an Illinois municipal corporation
and Home Rule Unit.
      VILLAGE PRESIDENT. The Village President, also known as "Mayor", of the
Village.
(Ord. 03-2445, passed 12-9-03; Am. Ord. 07-2621, passed 1-23-07; Am. Ord. 11-
2816, passed 1-25-11; Am. Ord. 17-4029, passed 11-2-17; Am. Ord. 18-4092,
passed 9-6-18)

AWARDS COMMITTEE
§ 34.001 COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; MEETINGS; DUTIES.
   (A)   The Village President, by and with the consent and approval of the
Village Board of Trustees, may appoint a committee to be designated as the
Awards Committee, consisting of not fewer than five nor more than seven members
who broadly represent all segments of the Village.
   (B)   The Committee shall meet at least annually and also at the call of the
duly appointed Chairman for the purpose of considering nominees for various
awards.
   (C)   A vote of 3/4 of all members of the committee attending the meeting
shall be necessary for qualification for an award. The recommendation of the
Committee shall be forwarded to the President and Board for consideration and
presentation as hereinafter provided.
   (D)   In exceptional instances, a cash award of $100 also may be given to
the recipient of one of the awards identified in §
34.003.
('73 Code, § 2-262) (Ord. 75-1125, passed 2-20-75; Am. Ord. 81-1444, passed 4-
16-81; Am. Ord. 83-1524, passed 11-17-83)
§ 34.002 PRESIDENT AND BOARD TO ACT AS COMMITTEE.
   In the event no Awards Committee is appointed or in the absence of activity
of the Committee, the Village President and Board of Trustees, at their
discretion and by an extraordinary vote of not less than 3/4 of the members of
the Board, may designate and present to any person or persons any award
provided in §
34.003.
('73 Code, § 2-263) (Ord. 75-1125, passed 2-20-75; Am. Ord. 83-1524, passed 11-
17-83)
§ 34.003 AWARDS ENUMERATED.
   The following awards hereby are designated as official awards for the
Village:
   (A)   Department of Police Honorable Mention Award, to be awarded for an
exceptional act of bravery involving risk of life by a police officer.
   (B)   Department of Fire Honorable Mention Award, to be awarded for an
exceptional act of bravery involving risk of life by a firefighter.
   (C)   Village of Schiller Park Certificate of Merit, for recognition of acts
bringing honor and distinction to the community.
('73 Code, § 2-261) (Ord. 75-1125, passed 2-20-75; Am. Ord. 83-1524, passed 11-
17-83)
§ 34.004 MAYOR'S COMMENDATION AWARD.
   In addition to the awards provided in §
34.003, there is further created the Village Mayor's Commendation Award, which
shall be awarded by the Village President to persons he or she deems entitled
thereto in appreciation of praiseworthy contributions to the Village and in
recognition of faithful and devoted service to the citizens thereof.
('73 Code, § 2-265) (Ord. 75-1125, passed 2-20-75; Am. Ord. 83-1524, passed 11-
17-83)
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
§ 34.010 BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby created a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, which
shall exist and have all of the powers and duties provided by law as enacted by
the Illinois General Assembly, except that where such law is inconsistent with
this municipal code, the terms of this code shall apply and control. The Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners shall consist of three members, who shall be
appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. All members of the Commission shall be residents of the Village of
Schiller Park.
(Ord. 96-2009, passed 7-9-96; Am. Ord. 97-2065, passed 6-10-97)
§ 34.011 RESPONSIBILITIES AND AUTHORITY.
   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall exercise the authority
conferred upon it by the Illinois Compiled Statutes and by the ordinances
adopted by the Board of Trustees. Where any such statute is inconsistent with
this municipal code, the terms of this code shall apply and control.
(Ord. 96-2009, passed 7-9-96)
Cross-reference:
   Fire Department, see
Chapter 32
   Police Department, see
Chapter 33
§ 34.012 RULES; PUBLICATION.
   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall make rules, authorized by
the Board of Trustees, to carry out the purpose of the law and this code. The
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, from time to time, may make changes to
those rules, which shall be effective upon the review and authorization thereof
by ordinance adopted by the Board of Trustees.
   (A)   Upon such authorization, all such rules and changes thereof shall be
printed immediately for distribution and the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners shall give notice of the place where the printed rules may be
obtained. This notice shall be posted in the Village Hall and all fire and
police stations within the Village.
   (B)   No such rule shall be made to govern the operation of the Police or
Fire Departments.
   (C)   Except as hereinafter provided, no member of the Fire Department or
Police Department shall be removed or discharged or suspended for more than 30
days, except for cause, upon written charges, an after an opportunity to be
heard in his own defense. If certain members of the Fire Department or Police
Department hold exempt positions appointed in the manner provided by ordinance,
they may be removed or discharged by the appointing authority in the manner
provided by ordinance.
   (D)   In those cases wherein a hearing is required to be held by the Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
shall conduct a fair and impartial hearing of the charges, to be commenced
within 45 days of the filing thereof, which hearing may be continued from time
to time. During such time following the filing of charges until the hearing is
held, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may suspend, for not exceeding
30 days, any such member of the Fire Department or the Police Department, as
the case may be, with or without pay. In accord with Illinois Compiled
Statutes, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall have the power to
secure by its subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the
production of books and papers relevant to the hearing. During the hearing,
each member of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall have the power
to administer oaths and affirmations.
      (1)   In the event a member is found guilty of any charge, the Board or
the Police Department, as the case may be, or may suspend such member not
exceeding 30 days without pay.
      (2)   In the event the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners determines
that the charges are not sustained, such member shall be reimbursed for all
wages withheld, if any.
   (E)   Nothing herein shall be construed as modifying the procedures set
forth in the Illinois Compiled Statutes providing for review under the
Administration Review Law, so that the provisions of the Administrative Review
Law, and all amendments and modifications thereof, and the rules adopted
pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern all proceedings for the judicial
review of all final administrative decisions (as such term is defined in the
Illinois Code of Civil Procedure) of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners.
(Ord. 96-2009, passed 7-9-96)
§ 34.013 REPORTS AND ANNUAL BUDGET REQUEST.
   On or before February 1 of each year, the Commission shall make a budget
request for the ensuing fiscal year to the President and Board of Trustees. The
Commission shall also forward its report monthly to the President and Board of
Trustees, in the form of the minutes of its meetings conducted by the
Commission during the prior month.
(Ord. 96-2009, passed 7-9-96)
§ 34.014 EXEMPT POSITIONS.
   (A)   The following members of the Fire Department and the Police Department
shall not be appointed by the Board of Fire and Police Com-missioners, but
instead shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees or respected chief of such department, as herein
applicable:
      (1)   The Chief of the Fire Department;
      (2)   The Chief and Deputy Chief of Police of the Police Department;
      (3)   Emergency Medical Technicians (Para-medics) who had been assigned
to the Department of Emergency Medical Services prior to the merger of that
department with the Fire Department;
      (4)   All non-sworn clerical personnel in both the Fire Department and
the Police Department; and
      (5)   All non-sworn radio operator/dis-patchers.
   (B)   Each such member of the Fire Department and the Police Department not
appointed by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may be removed or
discharged at any time from the employ of the Village by the Village President.
(Ord. 96-2009, passed 7-9-96; Am. Ord. 17-4029, passed 11-2-17)

§ 34.040 ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION.
   There hereby is established the Board of Local Improvements for the Village,
which shall consist of the Village President and all the members of the Board
of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 2-215)

ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
§ 34.090 ESTABLISHED.
   There hereby is established an electrical Commission for the Village,
pursuant to the authority granted by ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-37-2.
('73 Code, § 10-78)
§ 34.091 MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT.
   The Electrical Commission shall consist of six members, as provided by ILCS
Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-37-2, and shall be appointed by the Village President with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. All members of the Commission
shall be residents of the Village of Schiller Park.
('73 Code, § 10-79) (Am. Ord. 97-2065, passed 6-10-97)
§ 34.092 RECOMMENDATIONS.
   (A)   The Electrical Commission shall recommend:
      (1)   Safe and practical standards and specifications for the
installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment designed to meet the
necessities and conditions of the particular locality.
      (2)   Reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits
by the Electrical Inspection Department.
      (3)   Reasonable fees to be paid for the inspection by the Inspection
Department of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the Village.
   (B)   The standards, specifications, rules, regulations and fees so
recommended shall not become effective until adopted by ordinance by the
corporate authorities of the Village. All fees so adopted shall be paid to the
Village treasury.
('73 Code, § 10-80)

   Electricity, see

§ 34.093 COMPENSATION.
   The members of the Electrical Commission shall be paid compensation as may
be determined by the Village President and Board of Trustees from time to time.
('73 Code, § 10-81)
HISTORICAL SOCIETY
§ 34.120 ESTABLISHED.
   There hereby is established and created a special citizens commission of the
Village which shall be known as the Village Historical Society and which shall
be a commission of the Village.
('73 Code, § 16¼-1) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.121 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Historical Society shall be to:
   (A)   Identify and foster an awareness and appreciation of landmarks,
buildings, documents and personal property of historical importance to the
Village.
   (B)   Seek preservation, restoration, protection, exhibition, study and
enjoyment of these when possible.
   (C)   Record and preserve and make available for study and enjoyment
information and knowledge pertinent to the history of the Village.
   (D)   Develop, support and maintain a not-for-profit entity designed to
accept donations and other funds to support the Historical Society.
('73 Code, § 16¼-2) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.122 GENERAL MEMBERSHIPS.
   General Membership in the Historical Society shall be open to all those
interested in the history of the Village. Honorary Memberships may be granted
in recognition of a contribution of historical significance. Patron Memberships
may be awarded in recognition of a monetary gift.
('73 Code, § 16¼-4) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 04-2447, passed 1-
13-04; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.123 EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby created an Executive Committee of the Schiller Park
Historical Society, which shall have seven members, appointed by the Village
President for a term of two years. Vacancies upon the Executive Committee shall
be filled by appointment of the Village President for the unexpired term of the
member whose place has become vacant.
('73 Code, § 16¼-3) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 94-1881, passed 5-
10-94; Am. Ord. 04-2447, passed 1-13-04; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-8-08; Am.
Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14; Am. Ord. 17-4018, passed 9-7-17)
§ 34.124 OFFICERS.
   Officers of the Historical Society shall be chosen by and from members of
the Executive Committee. They shall be: a Chairman, a Vice Chairman, a
Treasurer and a Recording/Corresponding Secretary. Officers shall be chosen for
a term of two years. Their duties shall be described in the bylaws of the
Society.
('73 Code, § 16¼-5) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.125 BYLAWS.
   The Executive Committee of the Historical Society shall prepare and adopt
and may amend the bylaws of the Society subject to the approval of the Village
President and Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 16¼-6) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.126 DUTY TO REPORT.
   The Executive Committee of the Historical Society shall make an annual
report to the Village Board of Trustees on the actions and activities of the
Society.
('73 Code, § 16¼-7) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.127 CORRESPONDENCE.
   Correspondence of the Historical Society shall be copied, and a copy sent to
the Village Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 16¼-8) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
§ 34.128 EXPENDITURE AND COLLECTION OF FUNDS.
   The Historical Society shall not sign contracts or expend funds or collect
or receive money without specific authorization by the Village Board of
Trustees, or as approved in the bylaws.
('73 Code, § 16¼-9) (Ord. 90-1742, passed 4-19-90; Am. Ord. 08-2664, passed 1-
8-08; Am. Ord. 14-2968, passed 7-3-14)
PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD
§ 34.150 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS.
   There is established hereby a Parks and Recreation Department to be operated
by the Parks and Recreation Board also established hereby. Such Parks and
Recreation Board shall consist of five members, who shall be appointed by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the President and Board of
Trustees. All members of the Board shall be residents of the Village of
Schiller Park. Members shall receive the compensation as shall be fixed from
time to time by the President and Board of Trustees. The Parks and Recreation
Department shall operate in the public parks and the recreation center building
of the Village.
('73 Code, § 23-5) (Ord. 79-1377, 12-6-79; Am. Ord. 96-2004, passed 5-28-96;
Am. Ord. 97-2065, passed 6-10-97)
§ 34.151 TERMS.
   The term of office for each member of the Parks and Recreation Board shall
be five years. However, all members appointed to the Parks and Recreation Board
after April 30, 1996 shall be appointed for a three-year term. Once appointed,
a member shall hold office until his successor is appointed and has qualified.
In the event of a vacancy in office, the Village President shall appoint, with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, a successor to serve for the
unexpired term of the member who had held such office.
('73 Code, § 23-6) (Ord. 79-1377, passed 12-6-79; Am. Ord. 96-2004, passed 5-
28-96)
§ 34.152 POWERS.
   Except as modified by this municipal code, the Parks and Recreation Board
shall possess all of the powers and responsibilities of the President and Board
of Trustees set forth in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 11-95-1 et seq. and as same may
hereafter be amended from time to time.
('73 Code, § 23-7) (Ord. 79-1377, passed 12-6-79; Am. Ord. 96-2004, passed 5-
28-96)
Cross-reference:
   Parks and recreation, see
Chapter 95
ZONING, PLANNING, AND APPEALS COMMISSION
§ 34.160 ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   The Zoning, Planning, and Appeals Commission is established hereby.
   (B)   Whenever, throughout this Code, reference is made to “Zoning Board of
Appeals,” “Board of Appeals,” “Zoning Commission,” “Plan Commission,” “Planning
and Zoning Commission,” and/or “Zoning, Planning, and Appeals Commission,” such
term shall be construed to mean “Zoning, Planning and Appeals Commission.”
   (C)   Whenever, throughout this Code, reference is made to “Building
Official,” “Chief Inspector,” and/or “Chief Inspector of the Bureau of Fire
Prevention,” such term shall be construed to mean “Building Official.”
   (D)   Whenever, throughout this Code, reference is made to “Zoning
Administrator,” such term shall be construed to mean “Director of Community
Development.”
('73 Code, § 2-228) (Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-
11-02)
§ 34.161 MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Appointment and Vacancies.  The Zoning, Planning, and Appeals
Commission (in this section hereinafter referred to as “Commission”) shall
consist of a Chairman and eight other members appointed by the Village
President with the approval of the President and Board of Trustees. All members
of the Commission shall be residents of the Village of Schiller Park.
      (1)   In appointing the members of the Commission, the Village President
shall designate the Chairman thereof, and upon initial appointment three
members shall be appointed for the period ending at 11:59 p.m. on April 30,
1996; three members shall be appointed for the period ending at 11:59 p.m. on
April 30, 1997; and three members shall be appointed for the period ending at
11:59 p.m. on April 30, 1998. Thereafter each member shall serve for a three
year term and until his successor has been appointed. Vacancies upon the
Commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has
become vacant. The Zoning Administrator and the Director of Community
Development shall serve as nonvoting ex officio members of the Zoning, Planning
and Appeals Commission.
      (2)   The Village President shall have the power to remove any member of
the Commission at any time for cause. In the event a member desires to appeal
his removal, such member shall file with the Village Clerk a request for a
public hearing before the President and Board of Trustees. In the event of such
request, following the public hearing, the President and Board of Trustees may
affirm or reverse the decision of the Village President.
      (3)   The office of any Commission member who fails to attend three
consecutive Commission meetings without a valid reason, or who fails to attend
one half of the total of all Commission meetings scheduled or called during any
one year period, may be declared vacant by a majority vote of the remaining
members of the Commission. Upon his receipt of notice of declaration of vacancy
from the Commission, or in the event a vacancy in any office of a member of the
Commission occurs for any reason, with the advice and consent of the President
and Board of Trustees of the Village, the Village President shall appoint a
successor to fill the unexpired term of office created by the vacancy.
   (B)   Secretary. The Director of Community Development shall act ex officio
as the Secretary of the Commission and shall be responsible for all of the
correspondence, minutes, and records of the Commission. The Secretary shall not
be a member of the Commission.
      (1)   The Secretary of the Commission shall be responsible for filing the
most current rules and procedures or bylaws of the Commission, the minutes of
meetings, the record of hearings, and other documents and recommendations with
the Village Clerk and copies thereof with the Building Official.
      (2)   The Secretary shall perform such other duties as may be assigned
from time to time by the Commission.
      (3)   The Secretary may be given such clerical assistance as the
President and Board of Trustees may provide.
   (C)   Vice-Chairman.  Upon initial appointment, one of the eight members of
the Commission shall be appointed by the Village President to serve as Vice-
Chairman for one year. Thereafter, no later than its first regular meeting
following May 1 of each year, the Commission shall choose from among its
members a Vice- Chairman, who shall undertake the duties of Chairman in the
absence of the Chairman from any meetings of the Commission.
   (D)   Chairman. The Chairman, or in his absence the Vice- Chairman, shall
supervise the affairs of the Commission. The Chairman shall also act ex officio
as a member of the Design Review Committee.
   (E)   Compensation.  The compensation paid to the members of the Zoning,
Planning, and Appeals Commission shall be as established from time to time by
the President and Board of Trustees.
('73 Code, § 2-229) (Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-
11-02; Am. Ord. 18-4095, passed 9-20-18)
§ 34.162 MEETINGS AND HEARINGS OF THE COMMISSION.
   (A)   All hearings and all meetings of the Commission shall be open to the
public, and the records and minutes thereof shall be available for examination
in the office of the Village Clerk during regular business hours. At hearings
and meetings of the Commission, any interested person may appear or may be
represented by duly authorized agents or attorneys.
   (B)   All regular meetings of the Commission shall be held on the second
Wednesday of each month beginning in the month of June 2017 at the hour of 7:00
p.m., provided that when a day fixed for any regular meeting of the Commission
falls on a day designated by law as a legal or national holiday, no meeting
shall be held.
      (1)   The Commission shall keep minutes of its meetings showing the vote
of each member upon every question, or if absent or if failing to vote,
indicating that fact.
      (2)   The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the Commission
present at any meeting shall be necessary to make any recommendations to the
President and Board of Trustees.
   (C)   All special meetings of the Commission shall be held at the call of
the Chairman and at such other times as the Commission shall determine.
   (D)   No testimony shall be taken and no witness heard on any appeal,
variation, and/or zoning application except at a properly convened hearing of
the Commission. All testimony at hearings before the Commission shall be given
under oath and a record of a court reporter provided for each such hearing by
the petitioner therein.
      (1)   The Chairman, or in his absence the Vice-Chairman, shall administer
or authorize the administration of oaths and may compel the attendance of
witnesses, and shall otherwise have such similar authority as the Chairman and/
or acting chairman of a board of appeals in the general law.
      (2)   No vote upon any recommendation of the Commission shall be had at
any hearing unless the Commission shall by rule provide that such hearing shall
be deemed a meeting and the regulations concerning quorum and maintenance of
minutes shall have been adhered to.
      (3)   The petitioner shall reimburse the Village for two certified copies
of the official court reporter's transcript of such hearing(s), which shall
thereafter be maintained by the Village Clerk as part of the official record.
      (4)   Each application filed with the Commission for zoning consideration
shall be accompanied by the following filing fees:
         (a)   An application fee equal to $300 for hearings held during
regular meetings of the Commission;
         (b)   An application fee equal to $300 for hearings held during
special meetings of the Commission; and
      (5)   The Village Clerk is authorized hereby to make such additional
charges as may be necessary to reimburse the Village for the actual cost of
court reporter fees and the mailing of notices whenever the filing fees
authorized to be collected herein are insufficient to cover the cost of such
public hearing. The amount of such additional charges shall be paid the Village
by the petitioner within ten days of receipt of the invoice therefor from the
Village.
(Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02; Am. Ord. 06-
2560, passed 2-14-06; Am. Res. 13-17, passed 5-18-17)
§ 34.163 JURISDICTION AND PURPOSE.
   The Commission shall have the following functions:
   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park adoption of a Comprehensive Plan and/or any amendment
(s) thereto for the present and future development or redevelopment of the
Village of Schiller Park.
      (1)   Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or
functional parts, each of which, when adopted by the President and Board of
Trustees, shall be the Official Comprehensive Plan, or part thereof, of the
Village of Schiller Park.
      (2)   This Plan may include reasonable requirements with reference to
streets, alleys, public grounds, and other public improvements.
      (3)   The Plan by its very terms may be made applicable to land situated
within the corporate limits of the Village of Schiller Park and contiguous
territory not more than 1-1/2 miles beyond the corporate limits, but not
included within the corporate limits of the Village of Schiller Park.
      (4)   The Official Comprehensive Plan may establish reasonable standards
of design for subdi- vision or resubdivision of unimproved land and of areas
subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements.
      (5)   The Official Comprehensive Plan may establish reasonable
requirements governing the location, width, course, and surfacing of public
streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs,
gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of
lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water drainage, water supply
and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment.
      (6)   The Official Comprehensive Plan may designate land suitable for
annexation to the Village of Schiller Park, along with recommended zoning
classification for such land upon annexation.
      (7)   Such Official Comprehensive Plan shall be advisory and in and of
itself shall not be construed to regulate or control the use of private
property in any way, except as to such part of the said plan as has been
implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the President and Board of Trustees
of the Village of Schiller Park.
      (8)   Said Official Comprehensive Plan and the ordinance implementing
same shall be placed on file with the Village Clerk and shall be available at
all times during regular business hours for public inspection.
      (9)   Copies of said Official Comprehensive Plan, all ordinances
implementing same, and the official map shall be available to all interested
parties upon payment by said parties of a fee therefor as established from time
to time by the President and Board of Trustees, in order to reimburse the
general fund of the Village of Schiller Park for the cost of printing and
distributing same.
      (10)    No Comprehensive Plan or amendment thereto shall be adopted and
made official by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller
Park that has not been submitted to the Commission.
         (a)   Upon submission by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park of any suggested Comprehensive Plan, part thereof, or
amendment to an existing Comprehensive Plan to the Plan Commission for
consideration and recommendation, the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park may require a report thereon from the Commission with
its recommendation within 90 days from the date of such submission.
         (b)   If the Commission shall fail to make such report within the said
90 days, then the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller
Park may proceed to consider for adoption such Comprehensive Plan, or part
thereof, or an amendment to an existing Official Comprehensive Plan, including
arranging for and holding a public hearing thereon in accordance with the
provisions hereinafter contained in the same manner as if the Commission had
made its recommendation.
      (11)    Upon submission of a Comprehensive Plan by the Commission, or the
submission of a proposed amendment to an existing Official Comprehensive Plan,
the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park shall
schedule a public hearing thereon to be held at a meeting of the Zoning,
Planning, and Appeals Commission which shall forward its written recommendation
to the President and Board of Trustees within 30 days after the conclusion of
said public hearing.
         (a)   Not less than 15 days' notice of the proposed hearings, and the
time and date and place thereof, shall be given by publication in a newspaper
of general circulation in the County of Cook, in which the Village of Schiller
Park and contiguous unincorporated areas are located.
         (b)   The hearing shall be informal, but all persons desiring to be
heard in support of or opposed to the Comprehensive Plan or amendment shall be
afforded such opportunity to be heard and may submit their statements orally or
in writing.
         (c)   The hearing may be recessed to another date if not concluded,
provided that notice of the time and place thereof is publicly announced at the
hearing at the time of such recess or notice is given by newspaper publication
not less than five days prior to the recessed hearing.
      (12)   Within 90 days after the conclusion of the final hearing, the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park, after
consideration of the recommendations of the Commission and of such information
as shall have been derived from the hearing, shall either adopt the
Comprehensive Plan or amendment in whole or in part, or reject the entire
Comprehensive Plan or amendment in whole or in part, or reject the entire
Comprehensive Plan or amendment.
         (a)   If adopted, such adoption shall be by ordinance enacted by the
President and Board of Trustees, which ordinance shall include a map or maps
drawn to scale, reasonably accurate, showing north point and section lines and
numbers, and consisting of the whole area included within the Official
Comprehensive Plan or, if an amendment, one or more separate geographical or
functional parts, and all of any part of the contiguous unincorporated area
within 1-1/2 miles from the corporate limits of the Village.
         (b)   If, at the expiration of such 90 days, the President and Board
of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park have taken no formal action, the
Comprehensive Plan or amendment thereto may thereafter not be acted upon by the
said President and Board of Trustees without again complying with the
provisions of notice and hearing heretofore provided.
         (c)   The Comprehensive Plan or amendment, if approved and adopted,
shall become effective upon the expiration of ten days after the date of
adoption of the ordinance implementing the Official Comprehensive Plan or
amendment.
   (B)   To recommend changes, from time to time, in the Official Comprehensive
Plan.
   (C)   To prepare and recommend to the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park, from time to time, suggestions for improvements in
pursuance of the official Comprehensive Plan, including a plan to implement the
proper residential development and economic balance within the corporate limits
of the Village of Schiller Park.
   (D)   To review and recommend the denial or the approval of plats of
subdivision.
      (1)   Following the adopting of an official Comprehensive Plan in the
manner prescribed in the Zoning Ordinance, no map or plat of any subdivision or
resubdivision presented for record, affecting land within the corporate limits
of the Village of Schiller Park or contiguous territory outside of but not more
distant than 1-1/2 miles from such limits of the Village of Schiller Park,
shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the subdivision thereon
shall meet the subdivision regulations of the Village of Schiller Park and
otherwise conform to any requirements thereto shown in the official
Comprehensive Plan of the Village of Schiller Park.
      (2)   The procedures for review of such maps or plats of subdivision
shall be as established within the subdivision regulations of the Village of
Schiller Park.
   (E)   To hold public hearings on requests for amendments to the Zoning
Ordinance, to make and to forward findings of fact and recommendations thereon
to the President and Board of Trustees.
      (1)   The regulations imposed and the districts created by the Zoning
Ordinance may be amended from time to time by ordinance after the ordinance
establishing same has gone into effect, but no amendments shall be made without
a hearing before the Commission.
      (2)   All applications for amendment to this subchapter shall be filed
with the Secretary in such form and accompanied by such information as required
by the Commission and shall include a disclosure of beneficial interests. In
the case of applications to amend the Zoning Map, such applications shall be
filed by the legal or beneficial owner of the property for which an amendment
is sought. All such applications shall be forwarded to the Commission at the
Commission's next available agenda after all required notices have been
provided in accordance with state statutes and Village ordinances.
   (F)   To hear all applications for special use permits and/or conditional
use permits and submit its recommendations thereon to the President and Board
of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park.
   (G)   To prepare and recommend to the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Schiller Park schemes for regulating or forbidding structures or
activities which may hinder access to solar energy necessary for the proper
functioning of solar energy systems, as defined in Section 1.2 of the
Comprehensive Solar Energy Act of 1977, or to recommend changes in such
schemes.
   (H)   To hear all applications for variations from the regulations and
restrictions contained in the Zoning Ordinance and to submit its
recommendations thereon to the President and Board of Trustees of the Village
of Schiller Park.
      (1)   To hear appeals from any order, requirement, decision or
determination made by the Zoning Administrator in the administration or
enforcement of this subchapter and/or any other ordinance of the Village of
Schiller Park upon which the Commission is required to pass and to submit its
recommendation thereon to the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Schiller Park.
   (I)   To hear and decide, or make recommen- dations on such other matters as
may from time to time be committed to its jurisdiction by the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park.
(Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95)
§ 34.164 RULES OF THE COMMISSION.
   The Commission shall adopt rules governing its proceedings, a copy of which
shall be and remain on file in the office of the Village Clerk. The adoption,
revision, or amendment of such rules shall be by majority vote of the
Commission, and each member of the Commission shall be furnished a copy of such
rules. Such rules shall include but shall not be limited to nor conflict with
the following:
   (A)   All meetings and hearings of the Commission shall be open to the
public, and although a quorum of the Commission shall be necessary for the
conduct of Commission business at any regular and special meeting thereof, any
two or more members thereof sitting at any lawfully noticed hearing of the
Commission shall constitute a committee of the Commission for the conduct of a
public hearing:
      (1)   At meetings of the Commission, a quorum shall consist of five
members;
      (2)   Any member who was absent during a public hearing may vote on any
motion of the Commission in connection with such hearing, provided that such
member certifies that he has read the court reporter's transcript of such
hearing;
   (B)   Each member shall be entitled to one vote upon the deliberations of
the Commission;
   (C)   The Commission shall keep minutes of its meetings, showing the vote of
each member upon every question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating
that fact.
   (D)   In cases wherein a public hearing is required by ordinance, decisions
and recommendations of the Commission shall be reached only after such a
hearing has been held pursuant to proper notice of all hearings to all parties
in interest;
   (E)   At all hearings, any interested party may appear in person or by agent
or by attorney, offer evidence and testimony, and cross-examine witnesses;
   (F)   The Chairman, or in his absence the Vice- Chairman, shall administer
or authorize the admini- stration of oaths and may compel the attendance of
witnesses.
   (G)   All testimony before the Commission shall be given under oath or
affirmation and a record of a court reporter provided by the petitioner therein
for each case so heard;
      (1)   All evidence and testimony shall be presented publicly.
      (2)   The Commission may take judicial notice of facts to the same extent
and in the same manner as courts of record and may consider any relevant facts
within the personal knowledge of any member of the Commission which are stated
into the record by such member;
   (H)   The petitioner shall provide two certified copies of the official
court reporter's transcript of each hearing, which shall thereafter be
maintained by the Village Clerk as part of the official record of each case.
   (I)   (1)   At such meetings and within its jurisdiction granted under the
ordinances of the Village, the Commission shall make its decision or its
recommendation on all matters presented to it within a reasonable time.
      (2)   The Commission may reverse or confirm, wholly or partly modify, or
amend any order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from to the
extent and in the manner the Commission may decide to be fitting and proper
subject to the provisions contained in this subchapter or in the applicable
statutes of the state.
         (a)   The concurring vote of five members of the Commission shall be
necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the
Director of Community Development;
         (b)   The concurring vote of five members of the Commission shall be
necessary to recommend or grant a variation from the terms of this subchapter,
or to recommend or decide in favor of the petitioner on any matter, other than
that listed in division (I)(2)(a) above, upon which the Commission is required
to pass under this subchapter or any other ordinance of the Village of Schiller
Park.
(Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95)
§ 34.165 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   The language set forth in the text of this subchapter shall be
interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction:
      (1)   The singular number includes the plural number and the plural the
singular.
      (2)   The word SHALL is mandatory; the word MAY is permissive.
      (3)   The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   (B)   Whenever, in this Municipal Code the following words and phrases have
been used, they shall, for the purposes of this subchapter and said code, have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except when the
context otherwise indicates:
      ADMINISTRATOR or ZONING ADMINI- STRATOR. The Director of Community
Develop- ment of the Village of Schiller Park and such deputies or assistants
as have been or shall be duly appointed. That officer is hereby authorized and
it is his duty to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter, making
such determinations, interpretations, and orders as are necessary therefor and
requiring such plats, plans, and other descriptive material in connection with
applications for permits as are necessary for him to judge compliance herewith.
      BOARD OF TRUSTEES. See PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES.
      CHIEF INSPECTOR OF THE BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION. The Chief Inspector of
the Bureau of Fire Prevention of the Village of Schiller Park.
      COMMISSION. The Planning, Zoning, and Appeals Commission of the Village
of Schiller Park.
      DIRECTOR or DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT or SECRETARY. The Director
of Community Development of the Village of Schiller Park.
      PERSON. Any individual, firm, partner- ship, limited partnership,
association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind.
      PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES or BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The President and
Board of Trustees of the Village of Schiller Park.
      SECRETARY. See DIRECTOR.
      VILLAGE. The Village of Schiller Park, an Illinois home rule unit.
      VILLAGE CLERK. The Village Clerk of the Village of Schiller Park.
      VILLAGE PRESIDENT. The President of the Board of Trustees of the Village
of Schiller Park.
      ZONING ADMINISTRATOR. See ADMINISTRATOR.
(Ord. 95-1929, passed 5-23-95; Am. Ord. 02-2344, passed 6-11-02)
DESIGN REVIEW COMMITTEE
§ 34.170 DESIGN REVIEW COMMITTEE; CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   Availability. Before the issuance of any building permit required
under this Code for the construction, reconstruction or substantial alteration
of the exterior design of any structure or that involves an exterior design
feature of a property, an applicant shall secure a Design Review Approval
Certificate (in this Section hereinafter referred to as "Certificate") if the
requested building permit is for a non-residential use. No application for a
Design Review Approval Certificate shall be processed until the Zoning,
Planning and Appeals Commission (in this Section hereinafter referred to as
"Commission") has approved all applicable zoning, if required.
   (B)   Submissions. Pursuant to §
34.170(A) of this Code, a required applicant shall file a Design Review
Certificate Application (in this Section hereinafter referred to as
"Application") with the Building Department. The Building Official, or
designee, shall prepare the Application, which shall identify required
submissions. The Building Official, or designee, shall determine whether the
submitted Application is complete. If the Application is determined to be
incomplete, the Building Official, or designee, shall inform the applicant in
writing about the Application's deficiencies. The Building Official shall not
review the Application for issuance of a Certificate unless and until the
applicant resubmits the Application with the deficiencies corrected. A
prospective applicant may request a meeting to discuss the overall design
concept prior to submission of a complete Application but only after all
applicable zoning, if required, is obtained.
   (C)   Review by Building Official. The Building Official shall review each
properly completed Application and issue a Certificate to the applicant if, in
the sole judgment of the Building Official, the Application adheres to the
design objectives in §
34.170(E) of this Code. The fact that a completed Application has been filed
and is pending shall not unreasonable cause a delay in the review of building
plans while the Application is pending.
      (1)   Consultation with Design Review Committee. There is hereby
established a Design Review Committee (in this Section hereinafter referred to
as "Committee"), which shall consist of the Commission Chairman and Village
President, both acting ex officio, and the Village Engineer and any other
consultant of the Village, as deemed necessary. The Building Official may
consult with one or more member(s) of the Committee regarding an Application
for a Certificate and any proposed modifications to an Application.
      (2)   Design Review Committee Objectives. The Committee shall work to
encourage exterior design with a satisfactory visual appearance in the Village,
consult with the Building Official when necessary on an Application for
Certificate, preserve taxable values, and promote the public health, safety and
welfare of Village residents and visitors. The Committee may impose such
conditions and restrictions deemed necessary or appropriate to protect the
public health, safety and welfare or to ensure compliance with the design
review standards in §
34.170(E) of this Code. The Commission Chairman, acting ex officio, shall
additionally be required to inform the Village President of concerns regarding
the exterior design and upkeep of Village property and rights-of-way, including
ensuring applicable design review objectives in §
34.170(E) of this Code are addressed with respect to Village property and
rights-of-way, and shall be compensated an annual stipend as established from
time to time by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (D)   Determination by Building Official; Appeal. The Building Official
shall issue a written determination with respect to an Application for
Certificate (in this Section hereinafter referred to as "Determination"). The
Determination shall be one of the following: an approval of an Application,
approval of an Application with suggested modifications incorporated, or denial
of an Application. The Building Director shall be required to issue a
Determination within sixty (60) days after the submission of a completed
Application. Failure of the Building Director to issue a Determination on a
completed Application within said time frame shall be deemed to be a decision
denying the Application.
      (1)   If an applicant agrees with the Determination and, if applicable,
incorporates any suggested modifications to the Application, the Building
Official shall issue the Certificate.
      (2)   If an applicant objects to the Determination, the applicant shall
submit any objections in writing, along with the Application and Determination,
to the Village Manager for review (in this Section hereinafter referred to as
"Appeal"). The Village Manager shall set a date for a meeting regarding the
Appeal within 15 days after receipt of the Appeal. Following such meeting, the
Village Manager shall act as promptly as possible on an Appeal. The decision of
the Village Manager with regard to the Appeal shall be final and binding.
   (E)   Design Review Standards. An Application shall be reviewed for
adherence to the following objectives:
      (1)   Location of structures, accessory structures, signs, landscaping,
traffic lanes, and parking that ensures safe and efficient vehicular and
pedestrian traffic flow;
      (2)   Location of structures, accessory structures, signs, landscaping,
traffic lanes, and parking that complements the exterior character and promotes
the uniformity of the street or neighborhood;
      (3)   Sensitivity to the natural environment and features of the street
or neighborhood;
      (4)   Respect of the architectural design of surrounding buildings in
terms of style, color, and materials so that the image of the street or
neighborhood will be more consistent and uniform;
      (5)   Location of signage that complements and does not detract from the
character of the street or neighborhood;
      (6)   Landscaping that assists in creating a suitable streetscape, buffer
or shield that enhances the exterior character and appearance of the use and
complements the image of the street or neighborhood; and
      (7)   A proposed exterior design feature will not be detrimental to the
harmonious and orderly growth of the Village.
(Ord. 18-4095, passed 9-20-18)
