CANNABIS DISPENSARIES
§ 119.085 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR CANNABIS BUSINESS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to conduct, operate or
maintain a cannabis business establishment, cannabis dispensing organization,
cannabis craft grower, cannabis cultivation center, cannabis infuser
organization or infuser, cannabis processing organization or processor,
cannabis transporting organization or transporter or otherwise, sell, offer for
sale, or possess in any manner with the intent to sell at retail, wholesale or
otherwise any cannabis within the corporate limits of the Village without
having first applied for and obtained a cannabis business license. This license
shall be in addition to any other license required by this Code and the State
of Illinois. No person shall sell at retail or wholesale, dispense, transport,
process or infuse cannabis in the Village, in any form, in violation of the
terms and conditions of this license or in violation of any provision of this
Chapter or any provision of the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act ILCS Ch. 410,
Act 705, 1-1 et seq.
(Ord. 19-4194, passed 12-19-19; Am. Ord. 20-4228, passed 6-18-20)
§ 119.086 NUMBER OF CANNABIS BUSINESS LICENSES.
   (A)   There shall be a maximum of zero (0) cannabis licenses available at
any one time in the Village.
   (B)   The total number of cannabis licenses allowed under this Chapter may
be increased or decreased from time to time, by the adoption of an ordinance
amending this Chapter, in the discretion of the Village Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 19-4194, passed 12-19-19; Am. Ord. 20-4228, passed 6-18-20)
§ 119.087 APPLICATION FOR CANNABIS BUSINESS LICENSE.
   An application for a cannabis license shall be made to the Village upon such
forms as may be provided.
(Ord. 19-4194, passed 12-19-19; Am. Ord. 20-4228, passed 6-18-20)
§ 119.088 COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS.
   No cannabis license shall be issued to any person or entity that is not in
compliance with all applicable Village, State and federal rules, regulations
and ordinances, nor shall a license be issued if the premises and building to
be used for the licensed business do not fully comply with the requirements of
the ordinances of the Village including, but not limited to, any building and
zoning regulations.
(Ord. 19-4194, passed 12-19-19; Am. Ord. 20-4228, passed 6-18-20)
CIGARETTES; CIGARS; TOBACCO PRODUCTS;
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS;
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES
§ 119.090 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR RETAIL SALE.
   Within the corporate limits of the Village, it shall be unlawful to engage
in the sale at retail of, furnish, give away, deliver or keep with the
intention of selling at retail, furnishing, giving away or delivering tobacco
products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes in any form
or in any number without first having obtained a license therefor from the
Village Clerk in the manner provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter. This license shall be in addition to any other license
required by this Code. Sales by vending machine are regulated by §
119.100.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.091 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license required by this subchapter shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
§ 119.092 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for the license required by §
119.003 shall be made to the Village Clerk on forms provided by the Clerk and
no such license shall be issued to any individual who is not a person of good
character or to any corporation that is not represented in the Village by a
person of good character.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
§ 119.093 LEGISLATIVE FINDING AND DECLARATION.
   (A)   The President and Board of Trustees expressly find and declare that:
      (1)   Cigarette smoking is dangerous to human health;
      (2)   There exists substantial scientific evidence that the use of
tobacco products causes cancer, heart disease and various other medical
disorders;
      (3)   The Surgeon General of the United States has declared that nicotine
addiction from tobacco is similar to addiction to cocaine, and is the most
widespread example of drug dependence in this country;
      (4)   The Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse has concluded
that the majority of the 320,000 Americans who die each year from cigarette
smoking became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal
consent;
      (5)   The National Institute on Drug Abuse has found that cigarette
smoking precedes and may be predictive of adolescent illicit drug abuse; and
      (6)   The Village has the authority, pursuant to the Illinois Municipal
Code ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-20-5, to do all acts and make all regulations
which may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the
suppression of diseases.
   (B)   The enactment of this subchapter directly pertains to and is in
furtherance of the health, welfare, and safety of the residents of the Village,
particularly those residents under twenty-one (21) years of age.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
§ 119.094 SANITATION.
   Premises and buildings located within the corporate limits of the Village
used for the sale of tobacco products shall be kept in clean and sanitary
condition. The Health Authority shall investigate all such places with
sufficient frequency as to ensure compliance with this section.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 11-2848, passed 11-22-11; Am. Ord. 19-
4165, passed 8-1-19)  
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.095 SALE TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE (21) YEARS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell,
offer for sale, barter, buy for, distribute samples of, furnish, deliver, give
or exchange tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic
cigarettes to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years.
   (B)   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein
shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products,
alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes and on or upon every
vending machine which offers tobacco products, alternative nicotine products,
or electronic cigarettes for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and
shall state:
      “THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS, OR
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE (21) YEARS OF AGE OR THE
MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A SALE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.”
   (C)   The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background,
said letters to be at least one inch high.
   (D)   Before selling, offering for sale, bartering, giving, or furnishing a
tobacco product, alternative nicotine product, or electronic cigarette to
another person, the person selling, offering for sale, bartering, giving, or
furnishing the tobacco product, alternative nicotine product, or electronic
cigarette shall verify that the person is at least twenty-one (21) years of age
by:
      (1)   Examining from any person that appears to be under thirty (30)
years of age a government-issued photographic identification that establishes
the person to be twenty-one (21) years of age or older; or
      (2)   For sales of tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or
electronic cigarettes made through the Internet or other remote sales methods,
performing an age verification through an independent, third party age
verification service that compares information available from public records to
the personal information entered by the person during the ordering process that
establishes the person is twenty-one (21) years of age or older.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.096 MINIMUM AGE TO SELL TOBACCO PRODUCTS, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS,
AND ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES.
   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to engage, employ or permit
any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products,
alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes upon or in any premises
licensed pursuant to this subchapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.097 PURCHASE AND POSSESSION BY PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE (21)
YEARS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21)
years to purchase tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or
electronic cigarettes, or to misrepresent their identity or age, or to display
or use any false, forged or altered identification for the purpose of
purchasing tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic
cigarettes. It shall not be a violation of this subsection for a person under
the age of twenty-one (21) years to purchase a tobacco product, alternative
nicotine product, or electronic cigarette pursuant to a plan or action to
conduct an enforcement action approved by, conducted by, or conducted on behalf
of the Illinois Department of State Police, the Cook County Sheriff, the
Village’s Police Department, the Illinois Department of Revenue, the Illinois
Department of Public Health, or a local health department.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21)
years to possess any tobacco product, alternative nicotine product, or
electronic cigarette; provided that the possession by a person under the age of
twenty-one (21) years pursuant to an enforcement action described in subsection
(A) of this Section shall not be prohibited.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, furnish,
give away or deliver tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or
electronic cigarettes within one hundred (100) feet of any school, child care
facility or other building used for education or recreational programs for
persons under the age of eighteen (18) years.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.098 CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTIONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of
selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products,
alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes, or any employee or
agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such licensee’s or
person’s business, to distribute, furnish, give away or deliver tobacco
products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes free of
charge to any person on any right-of-way, park, playground or other property
owned by the Village, any school district, any park district or any public
library.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.099 LICENSE REQUIRED; ISSUANCE.
   No person shall operate or carry on the business of selling tobacco
products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic cigarettes within the
corporate limits of the Village without having applied for and received a
license therefor from the Village Clerk in the manner provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.100 CIGARETTE, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT AND ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE
VENDING MACHINES.
    (A)   License Required.  It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at
retail of tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or electronic
cigarettes from any vending machine located within the corporate limits of the
Village without first having obtained a license for each such machine.
   (B)   License Fee. The fee for a license required by this subchapter shall
be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (C)   Application; Applicants. Application for the license required by §
119.003 shall be made to the Village Clerk on forms provided by the Clerk and
no such license shall be issued to any individual who is not a person of good
character or to any corporation that is not represented in the Village by a
person of good character.
   (D)   Locking Device. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer
for sale, furnish, give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling,
furnishing, giving away or delivering tobacco products, alternative nicotine
products, or electronic cigarettes by use of a vending machine, unless such
vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking
device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons
under the age of twenty-one (21) years. Any premises or portion thereof where
access by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years is prohibited by law,
or premises where the public is generally not permitted and where vending
machines are strictly for the use of employees of business located at such
premises twenty-one (21) years of age or older, shall be exempt from the
requirements of this subsection.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
Penalty, see § 119.101
§ 119.101 PENALTY; RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation
of any of the provisions of this subchapter by a licensee or any officer,
director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable
in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the
licensee personally.
   (B)   Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, any licensee and/or
any other person, firm or corporation found by a court of competent
jurisdiction to have violated any regulation set forth in this subchapter,
shall be fined in the amount of not less than $200 nor more than $750 for each
violation. Each day that a violation is found to have existed shall be deemed a
separate violation.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
§ 119.102 SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FINES; COSTS.
   The Manager/Comptroller shall be charged with the administration of this
subchapter. The Village Manager/Comptroller may suspend or revoke any license
issued under the provisions of this subchapter in the manner provided in §
119.015 of this Chapter, in the event the Village Manager/Comptroller
determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this
subchapter. In lieu of, or in addition to, suspension or revocation of a
license, the Village Manager/Comptroller may levy a fine on the licensee. The
fine imposed shall not be less than $200 nor exceed $750 for each violation.
Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
§ 119.103 USE OF PREMISES AFTER REVOCATION.
   Whenever any license issued pursuant to this subchapter shall have been
revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted for the conduct of the
business of selling tobacco products, alternative nicotine products, or
electronic cigarettes upon or in the premises described in such revoked license
for the period of twelve (12) months immediately following such order of
revocation.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4165, passed 8-1-19)
CLOTHING DONATION CONTAINERS
§ 119.110 DEFINITIONS.
   The term CLOTHING DONATION CONTAINER shall mean any box, bin, trailer,
vehicle, structure or other receptacle that is intended for use as a collection
point for donated clothing or other household materials at times when no
employee or representative of the sponsoring company or organization is present
to accept donations.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
§ 119.111 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Before placement of a Clothing Donation Container occurs as permitted in
this chapter, a license shall first be obtained from the Village. Any applicant
for a license pursuant to this section shall complete an application on a form
to be determined by the Village. The fee for said license shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00). The license shall be renewed on a yearly basis.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
§ 119.112 REQUIREMENTS; MAINTENANCE; LOCATION.
   Every requirement herein contained shall apply to any Clothing Donation
Container currently situated or to be placed within the corporate boundaries of
the Village.
   (A)   The organization or company benefitting from a Clothing Donation
Container or the host site on whose property a Clothing Donation Container is
situated, shall indicate the following information on a Clothing Donation
Container: name of organization or company, address, contact telephone number.
   (B)   All signage on a Clothing Donation Container shall be in compliance
with all requirements contained in the New Millennium Code of the Village of
Schiller Park.
   (C)   A Clothing Donation Container shall be painted and in good condition
and appearance, with no structural damage, no holes in the receptacle that
would allow leaks, no visible rust and free of graffiti or advertising other
than the name of the host site or organization or company benefitting from a
Clothing Donation Container.
   (D)   A Clothing Donation Container shall only be used as a collection
receptacle for clothing or other household materials. The collection or storage
of clothing or other household materials outside of a Clothing Donation
Container and the collection or storage around a Clothing Donation Container of
bulk materials, including appliances, mattresses or furniture, is prohibited.
   (E)   No Clothing Donation Container shall be located anywhere outside of a
building. A Clothing Donation Container shall only be placed within a fully
enclosed and principal building situated on a lot. No Clothing Donation
Container shall be situated in a fully enclosed and principal building in
violation of any requirement contained in the New Millennium Code of the
Village of Schiller Park. No accessory building or secondary structure on a lot
shall contain a Clothing Donation Container.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
§ 119.113 ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   The organization or company benefitting from a Clothing Donation
Container will be held primarily responsible for the maintenance, upkeep and
servicing of a Clothing Donation Container. However, in the event the
organization fails to adequately maintain and service a Clothing Donation
Container, the business owner, or host site, on whose property a Clothing
Donation Container is placed shall also be responsible.
   (B)   Failure to properly maintain, upkeep or service a Clothing Donation
Container shall result in a fine pursuant to the penalty provision contained in
§
119.115.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
§ 119.114 RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to limit the Village in any way to
use any or all other means available to remove the nuisance, or summarily
eliminate immediate hazards to the public health, safety or welfare as granted
in any ordinances of the Village of Schiller Park or the laws or Constitution
of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
§ 119.115 PENALTY.
   Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person, firm or corporation
violating any section of this chapter shall be fined not more than two hundred
and fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation
continues shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 11-2839, passed 6-28-11)
DRUG, CHEMICAL & PAINT FACTORIES
§ 119.125 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to operate a drug, chemical or paint factory within the
corporate limits of the Village except in compliance with the provisions of
this subchapter. It shall be unlawful to operate a drug, chemical or paint
factory within the Village unless such person has applied for and obtained a
license from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of the Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.126 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license for a drug, chemical or paint factory shall be as
provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.127 APPLICATION.
   Application for the license required by this subchapter shall be made in
compliance with the ordinance provisions relating thereto.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.128 SANITATION.
   All drug, chemical or paint factory premises shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all dirt, refuse and
debris at least once every 24 hours. Each building or part thereof used for
those purposes shall be adequately equipped with devices to remove and
eliminate all fumes, odors and dust. Adequate and convenient washing and toilet
facilities for employees shall be provided.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.129 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made
inspections as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this subchapter
and the provisions of all ordinances relating to fire and health hazards
applicable to those premises.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS
§ 119.135 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of electrical contractor within
the corporate limits of the Village except in compliance with the provisions of
this Subchapter. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of electrical
contractor unless such person has applied for and obtained an annual license
from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
   (B)   However, any such contractor who is licensed in another municipality
shall not be required to obtain a license from the Village unless such person
has his or her principal place of business within the corporate limits of the
Village.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.136 ANNUAL REGISTRATION OF ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS.
   (A)   Every person desiring to engage in the business of an electrical
contractor in the Village shall first register with the Village Clerk and pay
the fee provided in §
119.008 therefor.
   (B)   Registration shall occur annually and on the forms provided by the
Village Clerk requiring:
      (1)   Name of the registrant.
      (2)   Residence and business address of the registrant.
      (3)   Statement as to whether or not the registrant has ever been
convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance,
and, if so, the nature of the offense, the penalty or punishment assessed
therefor.
   (C)   However, an electrical contractor who is registered in another
municipality shall not be required to register in the Village of Schiller Park.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.137 LICENSE AND REGISTRATION FEES
   (A)   The annual fee to be paid for licenses shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (B)   The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be
$25, provided that if an application is made after the expiration of the first
six months of the register year, a certificate shall be issued upon payment of
half this fee.
   (C)    Out-of-Town Contractors. Any electrical contractor who is registered
as such in any other city or village in this state shall not be required to pay
a fee for being registered in this Village; every person doing business in the
Village as an electrical contractor shall secure a certificate of registration.
The certificate shall be issued without charge to the electrical contractor
registered as such under the ordinances of another city or village in this
state.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.138 REGULATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this
subchapter to install any electrical appliances, wiring or fixtures without
strict compliance with the ordinances relating to the fixtures and it shall be
unlawful for any person to do any work without having obtained the permits as
may be required.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
EXPRESSMEN AND DRAYMEN

   No person shall conduct the business of drayman, carter, trucker or

of drayman, carter, trucker or expressman within the Village unless such person
has applied for and obtained a license from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.146 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a drayman's license shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.147 APPLICATION.
   Application for the license required by this subchapter shall be made to the
Village Clerk and shall designate thereon the name of the licensee, the
location of his or her business and the number of vehicles intended to be used
by the licensee.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.148 VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS.
    Every vehicle used in the drayman's business shall have printed thereon in
a place easily visible from its side the name and address of the owner in
letters legible to a person of normal eyesight at a distance of twenty five
feet (25').
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.149 RECEIVING STOLEN PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
   No drayman, carter, expressman or trucker shall receive, move or conceal any
goods or articles which he knows or has reason to suspect are stolen.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)

FLORISTS AND NURSERIES
§ 119.160 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale in any
building or structure, or in any open or vacant lot or parcel, any flowers,
shrubs, ornamental plants, trees or Christmas trees; unless and until such
person has applied for and obtained such business license from the Village
Clerk in the manner provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.161 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a florist's license shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
 § 119.162 GENERAL OPERATING REQUIREMENTS.
   The following operating requirements shall apply to florists and nurseries
licensed in accordance with this Subchapter:
   (A)   No owner or operator of a florist shop shall permit any dead or dying
vegetation to remain in or upon the premises so as to cause noxious or
disagreeable odors.
   (B)   No licensee shall sell Christmas trees, unless the location of such
sale of Christmas trees has been inspected and approved by the Director of
Community Development in order to determine that the conduct of such business
at such location will not constitute a fire hazard or endanger the safety of
the public. No licensee shall be authorized to sell Christmas trees, unless the
licensee shall deposit with the Director of Finance a cash bond in the amount
of two hundred fifty dollars ($250) for each location for which a license is
issued. Such bond shall be refunded to the licensee within five (5) days after
the discontinuance or termination of such sale, provided that all trees,
branches and parts thereof have been removed from the premises and that the
premises have been left in a clean and orderly condition.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.163 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Director of Community Development to inspect
every establishment licensed under this Subchapter as often as necessary to
insure compliance with this Subchapter and all other ordinances relating
thereto.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
§ 119.170 COMPLIANCE.
   It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association not incorporated
under the laws of this state to engage in underwriting fire insurance in the
Village without fully complying with the provisions of this subchapter and the
law of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.171 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   The fee for a license to operate a foreign fire insurance company shall be
as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.172 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license to operate a foreign fire insurance company shall be
as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.173 GROSS PROFITS ASSESSMENT.
   Any corporation described in this subchapter shall pay to the Village
Treasurer a sum of money equal to 2% of the gross receipts each year received
for premiums by any and all agents of any such corporation or association for
fire insurance policies on any property in the Village. The payments shall be
made for the year ending July 1 of each year.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.174 REPORTS OF PREMIUMS.
   Every person acting as representative for or on behalf of any such company
or association shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the Village
Treasurer a full, just and true account verified under his or her oath, of all
premiums which shall have been received by him or her on behalf of the company
during the year preceding July 1 on the fire insurance policies.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.175 TIME FOR PAYMENT OF GROSS PROFITS ASSESSMENT.
   All payments under the provisions of this subchapter shall be made on or
before July 15 following the termination of the year for which payments are
due.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)

GARAGE SALES; YARD SALES
§ 119.200 INTERPRETATION.
   This subchapter is specifically intended to apply to those activities
commonly referred to as “garage sales,” “yard sales,” and similar activities
involving the open display of the lot owner's used household merchandise and
materials for resale.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.201 COMPLIANCE WITH WHOLESALE AND RETAIL REGULATIONS.
   Any person conducting, participating in, allowing upon his or her real
property or otherwise offering to sell used household merchandise and materials
while engaged in garage/yard sale activities within a residential district
shall comply with all ordinances and regulations of the Village applicable to
the types of used household merchandise and materials being offered for resale.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.202 FREQUENCY, DURATION, LOCATION AND PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Frequency.  No garage or yard sale shall be held more than twice in
any 12-month period.
   (B)   Duration. No such sale shall extend for a greater period of time than
72 consecutive hours.
   (C)   Location.  No used household merchandise or materials shall be
displayed within any of the required front or side yards established by the
zoning district in which the zoning lot is situated.
   (D)   Permits. A permit to conduct a garage or yard sale activity must be
obtained from the office of the Village Clerk before commencing that activity.
The permit will be issued at no charge and must be predominantly displayed
during the course of the garage/yard sale activity.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.203 COMPLIANCE WITH SIGN REGULATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person engaging in, conducting, participating
in, allowing upon his or her real property or otherwise offering to sell used
household merchandise and materials while engaged in garage/yard sale
activities within a residential district to allow the posting of any signs or
similar devices in a manner that is not in compliance with the provisions of
this subchapter, the Village's zoning ordinance or any other ordinances or
codes of the Village. No person shall operate a garage/yard sale activity
within a residential district unless that person is a resident on the premises
where the garage/yard sale activity occurs.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
HEALTH CLUBS

§ 119.221 LICENSE FEES.
   The fee for a house mover shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.

   Persons licensed under this subchapter must comply with all of the ordinance
provisions relating to the work being done, must pay the permit fee required
for moving buildings, and must maintain lights and warnings as required by
ordinance.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.223 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made

Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.225 PLANKING OF STREET.
   The pavement of any street, alley or sidewalk on or along which any house is
moved shall be protected by two-inch planks along the route.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
JUNK DEALERS
§ 119.255 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate or carry on the business of junk dealer within the
corporate limits of the Village without having applied for and received a
license therefor from the Village Clerk in the manner provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.256 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license for a junk dealer shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.257 GENERAL OPERATING REQUIREMENTS FOR JUNK DEALERS.
   (A)   Every keeper of a junk shop who shall receive or be in possession of
any good articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall,
upon demand, produce such article or thing to any member of the Police
Department for examination.
   (B)   Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business,
shall bear thereon in legible characters, the name and address of the owner and
proprietor thereof.
   (C)   It shall be the duty of the Health Authority to inspect every
establishment licensed under this Subchapter as often as necessary to insure
compliance with this Subchapter and all other ordinances relating thereto.
   (D)    No person shall operate or maintain a junk yard within the corporate
limits of the Village.

KENNELS AND SMALL ANIMAL STORES
§ 119.265 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a kennel or small animal store within the corporate
limits of the Village unless such person has applied for and received a license
therefor from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.266 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for any location required to have a license pursuant to the
regulations contained in this Subchapter shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.267 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.
   This Subchapter shall apply to any place that raises, trains, boards or
sells dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or other small animals for hire or profit.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.268 SANITARY CONDITIONS.
   (A)   Every place covered by this Subchapter shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
   (B)   Every place kept as a kennel or small animal store shall be kept in a
clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed
to remain thereon for more than twenty four (24) hours.
   (C)   All parts of such buildings, premises or enclosures shall be
disinfected from time to time and shall be kept in a sanitary condition.
   (D)   All animals shall be humanely treated and any animal having any
disease shall be properly isolated, quarantined and treated.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
LAUNDRY AND DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS
§ 119.280 LAUNDRIES.
   (A)   License Required: No person shall operate or conduct a laundry within
the corporate limits of the Village except in compliance with the provisions of
this Section. It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a laundry within the
Village unless such person has applied for and has obtained a license from the
Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
   (B)   License Fee: The fee for a laundry license required by this Section
shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (C)   Sanitary Conditions:
      1.   Premises: Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition. No refuse of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate on
such premises, and the premises must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin.
      2.   Employees:  It shall be unlawful for any person with a contagious
disease to be employed in or by any laundry.
   (D)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the official designated by the
President and Board of Trustees to inspect every establishment licensed under
this section at least once every six (6) months. Any violations which are
discovered under the terms of this subchapter shall be reported to the
President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.281 LAUNDROMATS.
   (A)   Definition: The term “laundromat” as used in this Section shall mean
any establishment in which coin-operated facilities are available for washing
and/or for drying clothes, or both, which is open and available to the general
public for use.
   (B)   License and Compliance Required: No person shall establish or operate
any laundromat within the corporate limits of the Village except in compliance
with the provisions of this Section. It shall be unlawful to establish or
operate any laundromat within the Village unless such person has applied for
and has obtained a license from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
   (C)   License Fee: The fee for a license for a laundromat shall be as
required in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (D)   Equipment Installation: Installation of all equipment in such
establishments shall be in conformity with the ordinances relating to such
establishments.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.282 DRY CLEANERS.
   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of dry cleaning within the
corporate limits of the Village except in compliance with the provisions of
this Section. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of dry cleaning
within the Village unless such person has applied for and obtained a license
from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
   (B)   The fee for a license for a dry cleaning business shall be as provided
in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (C)   The Inspectors of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall investigate or
cause to be investigated the premises to be used and shall report the result of
the investigation to the President and Board of Trustees before the issuance of
a license.
   (D)   No license shall be issued to any person not complying with all of the
provisions of the building and zoning ordinances, Chapter 154 of this Code of
ordinances and the provisions of the fire prevention code of
Chapter 92 relating to flammable liquids.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.283 AUTOMATIC DRY CLEANING MACHINES.
   (A)   Definition: An “automatic dry cleaning machine”, as used in this
Section, shall mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or
fabrics, designed to be used or operated only by the owner or his employee,
which makes use of or contains perchloroethylene or any other chemical solvent
or substance which may cause harm to human beings through inhalation or
contact.
   (B)   License and Compliance Required: No person shall engage in the
business of maintaining any automatic dry cleaning machine for use by the
public within the corporate limits of the Village except in compliance with the
provisions of this Section. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of
maintaining any automatic dry cleaning machine for use by the public within the
Village unless such person has applied for and obtained a license from the
Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
   (C)   License Fee:  The fee for a license for an automatic dry cleaning
machine for public use shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
   (D)   Construction and Installation Requirements:
      (1)   Generally:  Each automatic dry cleaning machine shall be so
designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage of liquids, gases or vapors.
      (2)   Cabinets and Hoods:
         (a)   Each automatic dry cleaning machine shall be completely enclosed
by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and the outlet at or
near the bottom of such machine.
         (b)   Groups of machines may be entirely enclosed or supported on all
open sides by enclosure topped with a hood vented for each individual machine.
      (3)   Exhaust System: An exhaust system for each automatic dry cleaning
machine shall be required. It must maintain a minimum flow of one hundred (100)
cubic feet per minute face velocity through the loading door of the machine
whenever it is open.
      (4)   Discharge Stack: A discharge stack for both automatic dry cleaning
machines for and the room in which they are located shall be required. It shall
extend at least two feet (2') above the level of any window which can be opened
which is located within fifty feet (50') of the outlet of the stack and shall
be at least fifty feet (50') from any fresh air intake leading to any of the
premises.
      (5)   Portals and Loading Doors: 
         (a)   Each automatic dry cleaning machine shall be equipped with a
transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the
cleaning cycle.
         (b)   All such machines shall be so con- structed as to prevent the
loading door from being opened during the normal cycle of operation.
      (6)   Water and Sewer Connections:
         (a)   Any connection of an automatic dry cleaning machine with the
water supply system must be equipped with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the
line upstream from the condenser; no control valves shall be downstream from
such gap or breaker.
         (b)   Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap.
   (E)   Building and Premises Requirements:
      (1)   Ventilation: The rooms in which auto- matic dry cleaning machines
are installed shall be ventilated so that, from the area to which the public is
admitted, there shall be the following minimum cubic feet per minute airflow
requirements per machine:
Number of   Cubic Feet of Airflow
Machines*   Per Minute Per Machine*
3 or less   500
8 or less   400
16 or less   375
17 or more   360
* For the purpose of this subsection, each cleaning cell shall be considered as
one machine.
      (2)   Signs Required:
         (a)   There shall be warning signs posted in premises containing
automatic dry cleaning machines in places of easy observation warning of the
dangers in the event of leakage of liquids, gases or vapors.
         (b)   Owner's Sign:  At least one legible sign shall be maintained in
premises containing automatic dry cleaning machines in a place available to
customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the
establishment and of the service department or agency responsible for the
proper maintenance of the machines.
   (F)   Operation of Machines and Business:
      (1)   Operation of Machines Generally: No automatic dry cleaning machine
shall be operated unless all equipment is properly installed and in good
operating condition.
      (2)   Attendant Required:  No establishment containing an automatic dry
cleaning machine shall be open for business or admit the public or customers
into the room where such machines are located unless there is on duty in the
establishment at all times a competent person in charge of them.
   (G)   Disposal of Residues: No automatic dry cleaning machine residue-
containing solvent shall flow into the Village's sewer system. Tightly covered
metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such  waste outside the
building containing the machines. Such containers shall bear labels indicating
the contents and dangers involved in handling and shall be locked if in an
unenclosed place.
   (H)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the Village Manager/Comptroller
to cause such inspections to be made as are necessary to see to the enforcement
of the provisions of this Section.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999

§ 119.297 SANITARY CONDITIONS.
   (A)   No building, structure or part thereof used for or in connection with
any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or property of the
employees in such building or structure.
   (B)   The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager of all machine shops
shall cause all floors or other surfaces around or beneath any machine or
workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and
convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving the waste and cloths used in and
about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or
which are intended for any other use.
   (C)   No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease
shall be employed in or about any machine, and all cutting compounds or fluid
shall be kept free from infectious or harmful matter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.298 NIGHT OPERATION IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.
   No machine shop shall be operated between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00
a.m. in any place in which a majority of the buildings within a radius of 400
feet are used exclusively for residence purposes.

Penalty, see § 119.999

§ 119.403 PLANS OR BLUEPRINTS.
   (A)   Scale drawings or blueprints shall be submitted in triplicate to the
Director of Community Development of the Village as well as to the Bureau of
Fire Prevention of the Schiller Park Fire Department and approved by each
before any construction of, addition to or remodeling of any service station is
undertaken. Such drawings shall carry the name of the person proposing the
installation and the location and shall show the following additional
information:
      (1)   The plot to be utilized and its immediate surroundings on all
sides, with all property lines designated and adjacent streets and highways
named.
      (2)   The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their
capacity, pumps, buildings, drives and all other equipment.
      (3)   The clearance from the tanks to property lines.
      (4)   The type of construction of the buildings with a clear drawing
showing that there will be no basement, cellar or excavation under any portion.
      (5)   The location of all the basements, cellars or pits of other
buildings on the property or on adjacent property and the location of tanks
with reference thereto. If a building has no basement, cellar or pit, a note
shall be made to that effect.
      (6)   The location of sewers, manholes, catch basins, cesspools, septic
tanks, wells or cisterns, whether the property, adjacent property or in
adjoining streets, highways or alleys, and the location of the tanks with
reference thereto. If there is no sewer, manhole or catch basin in a street or
alley, or no sewer, manhole or cesspool, no septic tank, well or cistern on any
property, a note to that effect shall be made in the proper place.
      (7)   The location of vent pipe outlets and fill pipes.
   (B)   All drawings shall be accompanied by an application for approval made
out in triplicate on blanks furnished by the Village Clerk.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.404 GENERAL OPERATING REQUIREMENTS.
   The following general operating requirements shall apply to all business
licenses in accordance with this Chapter:
   (A)   License Posted:  The license issued pursuant to this Chapter shall be
plainly displayed on the business premises.
   (B)   Gasoline Sales Restrictions:
      (1)   Sale of gasoline in portable containers prohibited.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell motor fuel at retail
from any gasoline buggy or other vehicle equipped with a tank (the tank in
which motor fuel is carried for the operation of said vehicle being excepted)
having a capacity greater than five (5) gallons or containing separate
container or containers in the aggregate of more than five (5) gallons.
      (3)   No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except
into fuel tanks of motor vehicles when such tanks are connected with the
carburetion system of such vehicles; provided, however, that individual sales
up to five (5) gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and
labeled in full conformity with the Illinois Red Can Gasoline Law; such
individual sales to be limited to five (5) gallons to any one person.
   (C)   Dispensing Gasoline: Motor fuel dispensing shall be undertaken as
follows:
      (1)   General Requirements for Dispensing Devices:
         (a)   All flammable liquid gauging, vending and dispensing devices
shall be of substantial construction and firmly secured to concrete foundation
so located and designed as to prevent motor vehicles damaging such devices.
         (b)   Systems wherein continuous pressure is maintained or water is
used to displace liquid from storage tanks shall not be permitted.
         (c)   The use of aboveground storage tanks, tank cars, tank trucks or
portable tanks in connection with gauging, vending and dispensing devices shall
not be permitted.
         (d)   All dispensing devices shall be located so that all parts of the
vehicles being served will be on private property.
         (e)   In no case shall the dispensing hose be longer than eighteen
feet (18') feet for filling station and private locations.
      (2)   Leak Detectors: Every remote pumping system shall be equipped with
an Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., listed leak detector valve or device
located as close as possible to or within the pumping unit. An Underwriters'
Laboratories, Inc., listed impact check valve shall be at the base of each
dispenser.
      (3)   Automatic Devices: Automatic hose nozzle, valves with latch-open
devices or any automatic device shall not be permitted inside a building.
      Where dispensing equipment is used exclusively for trucks or other larger
vehicles, automatic hose retrievers may be used and shall not exceed forty feet
(40') of hose.
      (4)   Motor and Ignition Shut Off; Signs: No motor vehicle fuel tank
shall be serviced until motor and ignition of such vehicle has been shut off.
Warning signs shall be posted in a conspicuous location at each service island.
Such signs shall be metal or other material designed to withstand weather and
shall have a white background with the words “No Smoking” and “Turn Off Engine”
in red letters a minimum of one inch (1”) high with a minimum of three-
sixteenths inch (3/16”) stroke. No portion of such signs shall be any higher
than eight feet (8') above ground. The mounting and location of said signs
shall be subject to the approval of the Director of Community Development of
the Village.
      (5)   Self-Service Dispensing Devices: The installation and use of
unattended coin-operated or self-service dispensing devices for service
stations and/or filling stations is prohibited except as permitted hereunder.
         (a)   A service station and/or filling station owner, or an employee
or agent of such an owner, shall not permit any person who does not possess a
valid driver's license to operate a self-service device.
         (b)   Self-service equipment and safety devices shall be constructed,
installed and/or located as follows:
            1.   All pipes supplying flammable liquids to approved self-service
dispensing devices shall be equipped with electrically operated shut-off
valves.
            All controls to such valves shall be in a centrally located area
remote from all dispensing devices and adequately protected from the weather
and mechanical injury. The valves shall be so designed as to close
automatically in case of electrical power failure.
            All electrical equipment shall be listed for use in said areas.
            2.   Each such station shall provide an attendant during those
hours self-service equipment is available for use by the general public. The
sole responsibility of such attendant shall be to oversee the use of such
dispensing device.
            3.   Signs instructing customers concerning filling operations
shall be posted in a conspicuous location at each island. Such signs shall be
metal or other material designed to withstand weather and shall have a white
background with words in black letters, which letters shall be a minimum of
one-half inch (1/2”) high with a minimum of one-sixteenth inch (1/16”) stroke.
Such signs shall contain instructions bearing the following words:
“Warning”
“Stop Engine”
“No Smoking”
“It is unlawful and dangerous for anyone other than the attendant to dispense
gasoline into approved containers.”
“It is unlawful and dangerous for any person or persons not having a driver's
license to dispense gasoline.”
Signs with directions for operation of the dispensing devices shall also be
provided. No portion of such signs shall be any higher than eight feet (8')
above ground. The mounting and location of said signs shall be subject to the
approval of the Director of Community Development of the Village.
            4.   Automatic hose nozzle valves with latch-open devices are
prohibited.
            5.   Every service station and/or filling station owner or manager
shall be responsible for:
               a.   Instructions of all employees in the use of the emergency
shut off controls, fire extinguishing equipment, and all other self-service
dispensing equipment;
               b   Proper maintenance and operation of all safety equipment;
                  (i)   if any shut off controls are inoperative, the owner or
manager shall cause the facility to close until such time as the emergency
equipment is repaired and in full operating condition;
                  (ii)   if any fire-extinguishing equipment is inoperative,
that portion of the facility shall be made inoperative until the equipment is
restored to operating status.
   (D)   Private Filling Stations: Any person maintaining or operating any
storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles of the owner, lessee,
employees or agents of such person shall comply with all of the provisions of
this Subchapter other than the requirement for the payment of a fee.
   (E)   Open Flames Prohibited: No open lights or flames shall be permitted
except within a stove within the service station building.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.405 VEHICLE PARKING PROHIBITIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park or store any vehicle on any service
station premises, except in conjunction with normal and usual service station
business, without a permit allowing a parking lot on the premises.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on a service station premises
for the purpose of displaying it for sale.

the provisions of this Subchapter other than the licensing requirement.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)

VETERINARY HOSPITALS
§ 119.440 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a veterinary hospital within the corporate limits of
the Village unless such person has applied for and received a license therefor
from the Village Clerk as provided in §
119.007 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
 § 119.441 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for any location required to have a license pursuant to the
regulations contained in this Subchapter shall be as provided in §
119.008 of this Chapter.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
§ 119.442 SANITARY CONDITIONS.
   (A)   All veterinary hospitals shall be kept free and clean from decaying
food and from filth of any kind.
   (B)   Every place kept as a veterinary hospital shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain
thereon for more than twenty four (24) hours.
   (C)   All parts of such buildings, premises or enclosures shall be
disinfected from time to time and shall be kept in a sanitary condition.
   (D)   All animals shall be humanely treated and any animal having any
disease shall be properly isolated and quarantined.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02)
Penalty, see § 119.999
§ 119.443 INSPECTIONS.
   The Health Authority shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises
named and described in an application for a veterinary hospital for the purpose
of determining the fitness and suitability of said premises for the purpose of
determining the fitness and suitability of said premises for such business from
a sanitary standpoint, and the Health Authority shall periodically inspect each
veterinary hospital to determine whether health and sanitation requirements are
being followed.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 11-2848, passed 11-22-11)
§ 119.999 PENALTY; ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   In lieu of, or in addition to, the denial, suspension and revocation
provisions set forth in this Chapter, any person, firm, or corporation who
violates any provisions of this Chapter for which another penalty is not
specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not
exceeding $750. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day a
violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   Any person violating any provisions of §§
119.200 through
119.203 shall, upon conviction, be fined an amount not to exceed $750. Each and
every day a violation of the provisions of those sections shall continue shall
be deemed a separate offense.
   (C)   Whenever a person, firm, or corporation shall neglect or refuse to
procure any license, permit, or registration required by this Code, or
otherwise violates any of the provisions of this Chapter, the Village may cause
appropriate legal actions and proceedings, in law or in equity, to be
instituted and maintained to enforce compliance herewith.
   (D)   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation
of any of the provisions of this Chapter by a licensee or any officer,
director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such licensee, and such licensee shall be punishable
in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the
licensee personally.
   (E)   The Village shall take all necessary and appropriate action to compel
compliance with the provisions of this Chapter. When necessary and expedient,
the Director of Police may be called upon to assist in such enforcement, and it
shall be the duty of the Director of Police to perform, or to direct such
police officers as he shall determine to perform, such enforcement acts as may
be required. All Village employees duly authorized and acting as inspectors
hereunder shall be conservators of the peace with police powers for the purpose
of enforcing the provisions of this Chapter and other Village ordinances
relating to the licensing of businesses and occupations and their regulations.
(Ord. 02-2350, passed 7-9-02; Am. Ord. 19-4150, passed 4-18-19; Am. Ord. 19-
4166, passed 8-1-19)
